PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Harold Young) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.
Notice of Intention to Withdraw Notice of Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that it is my intention, at the time for giving notices of motion on the next day of sitting, to withdraw Business of the Senate, Notice of Motion No. 1, standing in my name, for the disallowance of the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1982, No. 117, and made under the Compensation ( Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971. I seek leave to make a short statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —When giving notice, on behalf of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, of disallowance of these regulations, I indicated to the Senate that the Committee had not had the opportunity to consider a response from the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) relating to the retrospectivity of the regulations. The Committee considered the Minister's letter at its meeting this morning and accepts the reasons he has given for the retrospective operation of the regulations. In view of the complex nature of the matters discussed in the letter, I seek leave for the correspondence between the Committee and the Minister to be incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
STANDING COMMITTEE ON REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES
13 September 1982 Senator the Honourable F. M. Chaney,
Minister for Social Security,
Parliament House,
CANBERRA. A.C.T. 2600
My dear Minister,

The Committee has considered the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Regulations (Amendment) contained in Statutory Rules 1982, No. 117, which are retrospective in operation to 21 April 1980.

The Committee has noted from the Explanatory Statement that, prior to the making of the Regulations, compensation claims by employees of the High Court of Australia ''have been handled by ex-gratia arrangements'' and would like to know , firstly, why such arrangements were made, and, secondly, the reasons for the delay in making Regulations governing compensation for High Court employees.
Yours sincerely,
AUSTIN LEWIS Chairman
Minister for Social Security Parliament House Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
27 September 1982
My dear Senator
I refer to your letter of 13 September 1982 wherein you sought information concerning the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Regulations contained in Statutory Rules 1982, No. 117.

By way of background I should explain that when the High Court of Australia Act 1979 came into operation on 21 April 1980, the High Court was given responsibility for its own administrative affairs in accordance with the provisions of the Act. Unfortunately this legislation did not make reference to the application of the provisions of the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971 to the staff employed under the High Court of Australia Act. As a consequence some degree of doubt arose as to whether certain staff of the High Court were persons to whom the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act applied.

Legal advice received from the Attorney-General's Department in November 1980 suggested that there was a measure of doubt whether in all the circumstances the Compensation Act applied to persons the subject of arrangements under section 26 (6) of the High Court of Australia Act and employees engaged under section 26 (3 ) of that Act. It was suggested that such doubt could be removed if appropriately worded regulations were made under section 7 (5) of the Compensation Act.

At the time of receiving this advice my department was working on a review of the provisions of Regulation 11 of the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Regulations which provided statutory workers compensation coverage to certain classes of persons in special relationship with the Commonwealth. This review envisaged possible amendments to Regulation 11 and it was intended that the High Court issue be resolved at the time of the other possible amendments.

The broader review raised policy difficulties which have still to be resolved. When my Department realised that delay was resulting, the High Court issue was excised from the broader question. I approved the issuance of instructions for the drafting of the necessary amendment to Regulation 11 to put beyond doubt the application of the Compensation Act to employees of the High Court on 4 October 1981.

While doubt was expressed as to whether some staff of the High Court were persons to whom the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act applied , it did appear that the High Court could be under an obligation to provide workers' compensation coverage for its staff under state or territorial legislation if coverage was not available under the Commonwealth Act.
As an interim measure, the High Court, with the concurrence of the Department of Finance, adopted an administrative arrangement for the handling of any compensation that arose.

The interim arrangement was that the Court would request the Commissioner for Employees' Compensation-the statutory office-holder charged with determining claims under the Compensation Act-to examine each claim that arose as if the claimants were employees of the Commonwealth and to advise the amount of compensation that would be payable if the claimants were such employees. Pursuant to its powers under section 17 of the High Court Act, the Court would pay such amounts of compensation as the Commissioner advised from funds appropriated by Parliament for the purpose of the Court under section 35 of the High Court of Australia Act. I am advised that twelve compensation claims have been handled on this basis.

I should point out to the Committee that similar administrative arrangements apply the benefits of the Compensation Act to Ministers, Senators and Members of Parliament. Payment of such claims are by way of an act of grace authorised by the Minister for Finance acting pursuant to section 34A of the Audit Act 1901.

As mentioned in the explanatory statement which accompanied Statutory Rules 1982, No. 117, the purpose of applying the regulation retrospectively was to ensure that employees of the High Court who suffered injury or disease prior to the making of Rule 117 would have a right to review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal if they were dissatisfied with a decision made in respect of such a claim.
Yours sincerely
F. M. CHANEY Senator A. W. R. Lewis
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, Parliament House
CANBERRA, A.C.T. 2600

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF ADMINISTRATIVE SERVICES: PUBLIC ISSUES SURVEYS

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. Did the Minister for Finance, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, reveal to a Senate Estimates committee that $52m was spent by the Government on consultants in 1981-82? Did this amount include $2.8m spent by the Department of Administrative Services? Has the Department of Administrative Services budgeted for an expenditure of $270,000 this financial year for a series of surveys on major public issues including unemployment, pensions and education? Will the Minister provide the results of these surveys in detail, as they become available to the Government, since they are being funded by taxpayers' money?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am unable to confirm the particulars outlined by Senator Button as regards the payments to consultants in 1981-82. Nor am I able to confirm the amount included in the Budget for this year. I would need to check that with the Minister and I undertake to do so. The honourable senator mentioned an amount of $270,000 in regard to surveys. I take it that that relates to the total information services that are provided by the Department of Administrative Services. They are included in the total vote we discussed in this place yesterday during the debate on a matter of public importance. However , I will check that matter also for Senator Button.

ANSWER.PARA: I imagine that it would require special consideration to determine whether any information obtained as a result of this kind of survey, which obviously relates to the formation of advertising, marketing and information material of various kinds, ought to be made public. I will refer that part of the question to my colleague and endeavour to obtain a reply for Senator Button as soon as possible .

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister prepared to accept the principle that the expenditure of taxpayers' money entitles taxpayers to receive information about how that money is spent?
—What rubbish!
—I am not interested in what Senator Lewis has to say. I ask the Minister whether he accepts that principle, as the Government did with regard to the $12,000 that it spent on its Budget survey.

—I reiterate the point I made: Clearly this matter would obviously relate to the formation of advertising and/or information services. I would need to consider with my colleague whether the material is of such a confidential nature that it ought not to be disclosed to the public. We would also need to consider whether the material is relevant to any of the points which Senator Button sought to make in his question. I will endeavour to do that in the next few hours. I will bring down a reply for Senator Button as quickly as possible.

—I have a much more intelligent question which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Support. The question refers to a newspaper report that Japan's Toyota group has won a contract worth more than $ 5m for the sale of 832 vehicles to the Australian Army by early next year. The contract comprises 417 commuter buses and 215 diesel four-wheel drive Land Cruisers. The vehicles are to be supplied through the national commercial marketing distributor for the group, Thiess Toyota Pty Ltd. What is the Australian content of the vehicles in this contract? Has there been any arrangement for offsets for the foreign component of this contract?

—Senator Lewis has asked a very intelligent question. It is one which is of very significant concern to the Australian public at this time when there is considerable interest in the future development of Australian industry. The question highlights the importance of the creation of the Department of Defence Support which was established on 7 May this year and indicates the Government's willingness and intention to develop Australian industry from that source.
—Stop reading your answer.

—That part of it was not read. The honourable senator suggested in the question that the contract was worth $5m. I understand that there are two contracts aggregated to approximately $5.1m. The value of the commuter buses is $2.836m of which there is a 21.69 per cent Australian content.
—You are on the ball this morning.
—The figure was firmly in my mind. The value of the Land Cruisers is $2.319m of which 34.4 per cent is Australian content.
—Go on!

—Yes, it is true. I recall the figure very well. Offsets were not sought against the vehicles purchased. The value of Australian content approximates the normal offsets target of around 30 per cent. Clearly, the purpose behind Senator Lewis's question is well evidenced by his interest in Australian industry. He, like the Government, is concerned to ensure that Australian industry does get a fair share of this kind of Department of Defence Support business. This question demonstrates the Government's concern in that area. Advantages will flow to Australian industry as a result.
—Mr President, I ask that the Minister table the document from which he has quoted.
—Yes, I do so.

—I ask the Minister for Social Security whether an amendment currently before the Parliament corrects what the Government regards as a drafting error in the Social Security Act in relation to the payment of supplementary assistance to some persons who are renting government accommodation. Also, since 1 February 1982 has the Department of Social Security administered section 22 (2) of the Act according to the way in which it is actually written, or in line with the current amending legislation? Would the Minister be prepared to table any instructions or memoranda which have been circulated in the Department about the way in which this section of the Act should be administered as from 1 February 1982?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that it is in order to ask questions about legislation that is on the Notice Paper but--
—It is not on the Notice Paper here yet.
—It is; it was introduced last night.
—A precedent has been set in that regard.

—In any event, although it is perhaps in breach of Standing Orders, I think it is harmless and I do not object to dealing with it. The legislation is substantial and contains a series of amendments to implement the very many changes announced in the Budget, most of which, of course, represent extensions of pensions and benefits and indeed, in a couple of cases, the institution of totally new forms of assistance, namely, the family income supplement and the mobility allowance. It also contains some amendments which tidy up the drafting and, in a couple cases, correct what have been seen as drafting errors. The first of the two cases of drafting error that immediately spring to my mind is that referred to by Senator Colston, which affects the administration of supplementary assistance payable to those who are in welfare housing. The second is in a field in which we have had the rather odd situation that people on supporting parent's benefit have been subject to a different income test arrangement from that to which widows have been subject. So, although there is great comparability between those benefits, the recipient of supporting parent's benefit has had an advantage in cases where he or she is receiving maintenance for the children from the non-supporting spouse. Thus, amendments in the legislation introduced in the Senate last night do touch on the area raised by Senator Colston.

ANSWER.PARA: The original understanding of the Government and of the Department was that the amendments, as drafted, would ensure that the saving clause operated to permit those who were receiving supplementary assistance, and who were resident in State welfare housing, to continue to receive that assistance. That sort of grandfather clause, if you will, was included in the legislation on the basis that, for people on relatively modest incomes, the loss of income would be felt quite significantly. A pensioner receiving $5 a week in supplementary assistance who suddenly lost it would find it very difficult to make the adjustment. Therefore, a decision was taken to maintain supplementary assistance where it was being received at the time of the amending legislation. It was thought that that provision meant that if a pensioner ceased to be eligible for supplementary assistance under the pre-existing rules-which could occur where, for example, a pensioner obtained non-pension income-it would be the end of that entitlement. In other words, the objective in maintaining in the legislation the pre-existing benefit was to prevent a sudden diminution of income due to the change in the form of assistance granted. It is a difficult area because, whatever decision is made-other than to extend universal benefits-it gives rise to an awkward cut-off point. However, the decision of the Government was that we should avoid a sudden reduction in pensioner income due to a loss of entitlement to supplementary assistance.

However, where the pensioner subsequently lost the entitlement to supplementary assistance under the old rule-it could occur only through either not having to pay rent or receiving an increased income-it was thought that that would be the end of the matter. I believe that subsequently a legal opinion was obtained on it. But in any event the legislation was more closely examined and it was found that as drafted it provides that, where someone was on supplementary assistance at the time of the new legislation and ceased to be eligible for supplementary assistance, that eligibility can be revived by returning to the same condition. As that was not intended, it is proposed to amend the law to ensure that the grandfather clause operates only until the entitlement to supplementary assistance under the old rules is destroyed by a change of circumstance. The relevant changes of circumstance are either that one ceases to pay rent or that one's non-pension income increases in a way which under the income test removes the entitlement.

That would probably be one of the less clear answers I have given to the Senate . It is a complicated matter and I will carefully examine the reply I have given to Senator Colston and clarify it if necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —Say it again.
—I will not try to recapitulate. I will wait for the supplementary question that is burning in Senator Colston's bosom.
—I wish to ask a supplementary question.

—I suggest, Senator, that you are asking a question that relates to a matter on the Notice Paper. I allowed a response from the Minister because he said that he would give a very general answer rather than in specific terms dealing with the legislation. I suggest that perhaps you wait until the matter is discussed further in this chamber as it is on the Notice Paper. Raising it now is not within Standing Orders.

—I raise a point of order about your ruling, Mr President. About three weeks ago I mentioned a similar matter to you when a question was asked by a Government senator about some legislation before the Parliament. On that occasion you ruled that the question was in order.
—I have not ruled on this occasion. I have asked whether you would consider not asking a supplementary question. There is a difference in the response from the Chair.
—May I ask a supplementary question, Mr President?
—I will listen to it very carefully.

—I fully understand what Senator Chaney said but he did not answer my question. One of the questions related to the way in which the Department of Social Security has administered this part of the Act since 1 February 1982 and I ask Senator Chaney whether he can say how this was administered-whether it was administered in line with the written Act or the Government's intention of the Act. Secondly, is he prepared to table any memoranda or instructions about this part of the Act that circulated within the Department?

—I apologise to Senator Colston and to the Senate for overlooking the second part of the question. I did have a note of it but, in answering the first part at such length, it went out of my mind. As far as the administration of the section subsequent to February is concerned, it is my understanding, from memory of minutes given to me some months ago, that the Department administered the section in accordance with its understanding of the meaning of the provision . In other words, it administered it so that the entitlement was extinguished by a change of circumstance of the sort that I have outlined. Whether there was any change subsequent to the reinterpretation is a matter which I will have to check . As far as the instructions that were issued by my Department in respect of the administration of the Act are concerned, I will look at that. There is normally no difficulty about producing them and I do not envisage that there will be in this case. I will let Senator Colston have advice on that in the very near future.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and I preface it by saying briefly that no doubt the Minister is aware of the World Health Organisation's concern about the use of certain pesticides and that some countries allow the use of certain pesticides that are banned in Australia. It is something that he probably is worried about too. What tests are carried out on foods that are imported into Australia to ensure that they are free from residual pesticides which would be illegal if used here? If no action is presently being taken, will the Minister set in train some examination of this matter?

—I can appreciate Senator Townley's concern about the use of pesticides. Certain pesticides used in foods grown locally can accumulate in the human body. We can measure, for example, levels of DDT from years gone by when it was a commonly used agent. I am not certain of the extent to which imported foods would represent a health hazard. I do not know the extent to which we monitor in any regular sense pesticide levels, residual amounts of these substances, in imported foods. It would be a matter to be referred to the Minister whom I represent for detailed information. It would be an activity carried out either through the National Health and Medical Research Council or through the National Biological Standards Laboratory. In either case I shall try to obtain an answer for Senator Townley as to the current situation.
—Will you circulate it to all senators?
—Yes.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Acting Prime Minister. Did the Prime Minister, on 10 September, tell the Western Australian Premier that Western Australia had the right to take part in the sugar industry, as the Western Australian Premier claims he did? Does the Minister know of the deep concern in north Queensland about the damage to Queensland of a new sugar industry in Western Australia, especially if Western Australia dumped milled white sugar on the domestic market? Will the Fraser Government allow the Western Australian Government to proceed with its plans to import Korean capital to finance the Ord project?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of a statement by the Prime Minister on 10 September. I shall check that up. But yesterday, or the day before, I answered very specifically a series of questions, I think, from Senator Crichton -Browne. Summarising the answers, I made the point that, in the full knowledge of the tight overseas market, the declining price for sugar and the size of the domestic market, individual States had an absolute right to proceed in the development of their own agriculture. It ought to be made abundantly clear that it is a matter for a State, whether it is Queensland or Western Australia, so to do. That is so in all agriculture. If there is a matter concerning the national interest, of course the Commonwealth Government will look at it in terms of the national interest. It will look at it in terms of the overall interest of Australia.
—Of all States?
—Of all States.
—What about sugar being a poison worse than alcohol? Will you look into that, too?
—Everything is a poison. Even drinking water, if it is taken in excess, is a poison.
—Oh, come on!

—Indeed it is. I am not prepared to condemn any kind of foodstuff in extravagant terms such as 'poison'. In moderation, cane sugar and beet sugar are reasonable dietary substances. It is a matter of judgment-thank God it is a matter of judgment and not a matter of government compulsion or duress-as to the choice of diet by people. I repeat what I said in answer to Senator Crichton-Browne. The States all know the state of the world market, the size of the domestic market and the price of sugar. In that knowledge, it is quite competent for any State to promote particular agriculture. Naturally enough, the Commonwealth will take into account the overall national interest in this regard.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General. Is it correct that, since the Commonwealth first proposed the establishment of a national crimes commission many months ago, no State or Territory has supported the proposal in its present form; the States and the Northern Territory have acknowledged that there is a serious problem of organised crime which ought to be tackled as a matter of priority; and both the Australian Police Ministers Council and the Standing Committee of Attorneys- General have approached the matter very positively and have, in accordance with their own initiative and the direction of the June Premiers Conference, undertaken detailed consideration of a number of options? Is it correct that at a joint meeting of the Australian Police Ministers Council and the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General on 24 September substantial progress was made and there was substantial consensus on the kind of structure which might be established to deal with the problems, and that at that meeting it was agreed that further work would be undertaken by officers prior to another joint meeting to finalise an agreement? Finally, is it correct that, notwithstanding the extensive process of consultation and negotiation which has been undertaken between the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory in relation to a crimes commission, and notwithstanding a substantial measure of consensus, the Commonwealth proposes to proceed with the establishment of a Commonwealth crimes commission in the current session, having now unilaterally suspended further meaningful discussion with the States? Why has the Federal Government taken such action and what was the purpose of the negotiations and discussions in the first place? Were the States misled about the seriousness of these meetings?

—I am, of course, aware that there have been consultations between the Commonwealth and the States involving the Minister I represent in this place , the Acting Attorney-General, and the Minister for Administrative Services who has the Australian Federal Police interest within his jurisdiction. The matters raised, I think, require their attention and answer and I will refer the series of questions asked by Senator Crichton-Browne to those Ministers for consideration and reply.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is it the case that the Prime Minister on Tuesday clearly acknowledged, if only by implication, that the sale of the companies of which Mr John Reid was a director involved a dry Slutzkin or accummulated profits scheme and that this was confirmed on the radio program AM yesterday morning by his one time fellow director Mr Moore who stated that the shares had been sold rather than the companies being wound up in order to reduce the tax payable by the shareholders? Is the Minister further aware that the dry Slutzkin schemes involving dividend stripping were specifically outlawed in May 1981 by the new sections 177D and 177E of the Income Tax Assessment Act, being described by the Treasurer at the time as blatant, contrived, artificial and beyond the bounds of reasonableness? Finally, does the Government still maintain that it is perfectly proper to appoint to head a public inquiry into, among other things, standards in the Public Service a person who, as a company director, was knowingly involved in a tax avoidance scheme which has been roundly condemned by the Treasurer and now specifically prohibited by this Government's legislation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand the situation, and indeed as revealed by the Commissioner of Taxation and a Mr Moore who, I think, was appointed by Mr Wran as Chairman of the Public Service Board in New South Wales, the circumstances are as I now describe them. I am surprised that Senator Evans is looking selectively to one person and not to another, since the facts are similar. The fact is that the companies that are being outlawed by the recoupment of tax scheme of this Government are companies which did not pay their company tax and used the excess of company tax to be transferred by capitalisation and gain to shareholders. The Commissioner of Taxation has made it abundantly clear that in respect of the companies of which Mr Reid was a trustee and from which he gained no benefit in terms of the shares-he was acting , I think, for the estate of a deceased friend-all company tax was paid.
—What about personal tax? Stop evading it.
—You are prevaricating and obfuscating as you always do when you are on the hook.

—Since honourable senators are interjecting I point out that what Senator Evans, who must know, did not say is that the High Court of Australia had ruled that this particular situation was entirely legal. The situation about the evasion and avoidance of tax is that what had been described as a dry Slutzkin scheme had been ruled by the High Court as entirely legal. The fact of the matter is that it was ruled as entirely legal by the High Court and therefore at the time that these things were happening it was a legal act. Let us make it abundantly clear. The attempt by the Australian Labor Party and the failed attempt by Mr Hayden to smear decent Australians who go about their business-

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —Let them shout and scream. Let them remember that they are very selective. When it comes to their own friends, they protect them. But when they think it is a good thing to punch somebody else in the eye, they do it . That is about the meanest, most cowardly and despicable thing.
—Get on to the ship painters and dockers.
—Yes, indeed. The Ship Painters and Dockers Union had to disaffiliate itself. It was being defended in this Senate by Labor--
—Rubbish! That is a lie.
—That is a lie.
—Order, Senator! I would ask that you withdraw that remark. It is unparliamentary.
—It was a lie.
—Order, Senator Walsh! You will withdraw that remark too in a moment.
—Of course it is a lie.
—I ask Senator Button to withdraw.
—I withdraw, Mr President, but I will be seeking--
—Mr President, Senator Evans said: 'Of course it is a lie'.
—Of course it is a lie. You know you are lying. You lie through your teeth.
—Order, Senator! I call on the Leader of the Opposition to withdraw.
—I withdraw, Mr President. But I will be seeking leave to make a personal explanation and seeking an apology at the end of Question Time.
—I also ask Senator Walsh and Senator Evans who also used unparliamentary language to withdraw.
—I withdraw, Mr President. But I would say that if the Minister's name were Pinocchio his nose would now be two feet long.
—Senator Walsh.
—I will withdraw.
—Mr President, I take a point of order. Would you also include Senate Tate who used the same language?
—I ask that interjections please cease. I did not hear Senator Walters's remarks to the Chair at that stage because of the interjections. Senator, would you please repeat your remarks?
—Mr President, I ask that Senator Tate also be asked to withdraw similar words that he used.

—Order! I ask the Senate to come to order please. I have said many times in this place that I accept interjections as part of the cut and thrust of politics. But I can assure the Senate that if I consider interjections to be unruly or unparliamentary I will take the necessary course of action.
—What about the Minister's unparliamentary language?
—Order, Senator Gietzelt! I am still on my feet. Senator Tate, would you withdraw?
—Mr President, at your request and not at that of Senator Walters I withdraw my remark.
—Mr President, I take a point of order. Every Thursday morning we go through this charade with the Minister losing his temper and provoking people .
—Order! There is no point of order.
—He is using unparliamentary language and it should also apply to him.
—Order, Senator! Please resume your seat.
—Let me repeat what I said. Mr President, if my remarks are unparliamentary, no doubt you will direct my attention to that fact.
—Calm down. One of these days you will have a heart attack.

—The only people who will have a heart attack will be the Labor Party members. The fact is that what I said was that the Labor Party had been entirely selective. It was casting smears on decent Australians but it was being very selective in protecting and not coming out in a forthright way against those who had been associated with it. I make the point that when I said that the Ship Painters and Dockers Union had to disaffiliate itself that was when Opposition senators said that what I had said was a lie. The fact is that the Ship Painters and Dockers Union made the statement publicly that it had disaffiliated. Therefore I accept the fact that that is so and what that union said is the truth. The question related to Mr John Reid. As I understand it, Mr John Reid is a man of impeccable integrity in this country. He has served this country extremely well. He is so regarded by the community which knows that he is a man of complete integrity.
—Like Sir Andrew Grimwade.

—Mr President, the interjection is the same. There is a willingness to smear people, even if there is no evidence available at all. It goes on and on. There is a willingness to do this but not a willingness to home in on others, bearing in mind that over the years the Labor Party knew that the Ship Painters and Dockers had been guilty of murders, crimes, conspiracies and violence. Indeed, they associated all the time with these people. I repeat that over the years--
—Withers will be after you next week. We will have an election next week.

—Mr President, the attempted intimidation by snide remarks from across the floor that you are not supposed to hear ought to be noted. The fact of the matter is that, no matter what they say, over the years they knew that one of the affiliates of the Labor Party was engaged, as the Royal Commission has said, in criminal activity, operating not as a trade union but as a gang of criminals organised to recruit criminals. No amount of special pleading can say other than that they are selective in their choice. They will attack those who do not belong to them but they will in fact, as they have over the years, put a protective screen around the others.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. How does the Government explain its own selectivity and double standards in, on the one hand, attacking the Opposition for criticising the appointment of someone clearly identified as a tax avoider and, on the other hand, aggressively pursuing retrospective legislation against vendor shareholders in bottom-of-the-harbour cases who, on the Government's own account, were engaged in legal tax avoidance rather than illegal tax evasion?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fact of the matter is that the so-called wet Slutzkin, as Senator Evans ought to know, is a situation in which the vendor shareholders in a company sell their shares prior to any discharge of company tax and gain, in the capitalisation of their shares, by an increment regarding company tax. The dry Slutzkin-
—And rob every Australian taxpayer in the process.

—Order! Senator Gietzelt, I did address the whole of the chamber earlier and say that I would take the necessary action against any honourable senator who continued not so much to interject but to be unruly and unparliamentary. I suggest to you that you are continuing to interject. I hope you will take notice of my remarks.
—Well, they all rob taxpayers, Mr President.
—Please, Senator Gietzelt. I call the Minister.

—I repeat that the wet Slutzkin is a scheme, as I understand it, whereby the vendor shareholders sell their shares knowing that what they are getting for the shares in terms of value is more than the market price of the shares would be had company tax liability, which existed at the time, been discharged. So knowingly they received an extra amount of money for their shares above their ordinary value which could come about only because company tax had not been paid and therefore they gained in a capital accretion to their shares that value of money.

ANSWER.PARA: A dry Slutzkin is a situation in which the company tax had been paid. In the case of the John Reid companies, incidentally, the man was a trustee, not seeking to gain anything for himself at all, but discharging a duty for a dead friend. My gosh, how low can one get in this situation? The shares were sold after the company tax had been paid. So quite clearly that liability had gone. Also it is a situation in which the High Court of Australia has ruled that the transaction is legal. Of course, there are fundamental differences, and of course the Labor Party is trying to distort them for its own exploitation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and is along the lines of a question that was recently asked. I ask: How would directors of a shell company, who have paid their current year's company taxes, be aware that that company could end up as part of a bottom-of- the-harbour scheme? Could not the company, for example, have been sold legally to a public company? In such circumstances no further tax would be payable because of the rebate provisions. Could it not have been sold to a mining company for the purpose of recoupment of losses in earlier years? Could it not be disposed of for probate purposes or for a whole host of other legitimate reasons? In normal sale arrangements, would there be anything that would indicate that such an arrangement would necessarily end up in a bottom-of-the- harbour type scheme?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Watson's question relates to whether the recoupment tax measure that will be brought in will affect those kinds of circumstances. The legislation is lying in the Parliament at the moment but I understand it is to be withdrawn and a new Bill introduced to include the promoters. It would be necessary for me to look at the draft of the new Bill and any amendments in it before I could respond specifically to the particular examples that Senator Watson cites. I will take his question on notice and will ask the Treasurer to respond to it.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment aware of the World National Parks Congress currently being held in Bali and that attendance at the Congress, held only once every 10 years, is by invitation only? Can the Minister confirm that the Tasmanian National Parks and Wildlife Service, having been invited, had one of its officers prepare a paper on the increasing pressures for resource development in the wilderness of South West Tasmania but that the officer who prepared the paper was refused permission to attend the conference by the Tasmanian Premier? Is the Minister concerned that Australia's reputation could have been tarnished by what many believe to be an attempt at censorship over an issue of international significance? Can the Minister indicate whether, if faced with the same situation, the Federal Government would have acted in the same petty way as the Tasmanian Premier?

—Whilst I am not aware of the World National Parks Congress being held in Bali, I understand Senator Chipp is concerned that a paper which was prepared may not have been delivered. If I have understood the question correctly, the Tasmanian national parks organisation is a State instrumentality. In that event it is for the State of Tasmania to make decisions. I am not sure that the Minister whom I represent has any responsibility as to whether that paper should be presented or held back. I only observe to Senator Chipp that when papers have been presented from any department with which I have been associated, generally a process of consultation has taken place in the preparation of the papers. I imagine that is the normal way of dealing between colleagues and I imagine it is the way to get papers prepared with least friction. I cannot confirm or deny-I have no knowledge of the matter-whether the events set out by Senator Chipp did occur. Since they are not matters within Commonwealth responsibility I doubt that my colleague could add anything.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Health give a progress report on the medical fraud investigations currently being undertaken in Tasmania? Can he say approximately how many doctors and how many hospitals are being investigated, and whether records from all health insurance funds are being checked? Is only the Australian Federal Police involved in the investigation or are Department of Health personnel assisting? Is the Minister satisfied that those doing the investigations have sufficient expertise in detecting medical fraud as distinct from simply over-servicing to ensure that evidence is not overlooked? If he cannot answer these questions will he please check on these matters and let me know?

—Part of Senator Coates's question requires an answer in great detail. I will have to seek that detail. He wants to know the numbers of people involved in certain activities. I will ask my colleague, Mr Carlton, whether he can provide that information. However, I am aware that the Fraud and Over-servicing Detection System has directed itself to finding ways of detecting not only over-servicing but also fraud and that methods have been developed which are throwing up a number of these circumstances. I would not pretend-I do not think Senator Coates would expect us to pretend-that we can guarantee that every instance or case will come to light under these procedures. But, having briefly been Minister for Health and having seen the system in operation and how the officers have developed it, I have no doubt that it does bring to light a large number of doctors whose affairs need further investigation. The fact that they are thrown up by FODS does not of itself mean that they have taken part in any fraud or any over-servicing. For example, a patient with extraordinary but legitimate requirements might cause that billing experience to be thrown up by the computer. But it might turn out, on examination, that that has been entirely proper. The system does throw up people who do require further examination. It is on those people who are thrown up by the computer that inquiries are now concentrated. It is as a result of those concentrated inquiries that some examples of fraud and over-servicing are emerging. I cannot give details at present as to exactly what is going on in Tasmania. I will seek them for Senator Coates.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NATIONAL HEALTH SERVICE: PRESCRIBING OF DRUGS

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware of proposed changes with respect to the prescription of National Health Service drugs in hospitals by medical practitioners? At present medication is prescribed by a doctor on daily ward rounds and if any changes come up he phones the ward sister or the hospital and those changes are validated subsequently by a prescription being written. As I understand the new legislation for NHS drugs, the doctor will be required to be physically present to sign that script before any authorisation for change can take place. This may be possible where resident doctors are present in government hospitals. But will there not be difficulties in private hospitals if a medical practitioner has to be present to authorise that change?

—The question asked by Senator MacGibbon does cover what are some detailed administrative arrangements in the way in which drugs are prescribed. I take it that his question is restricted to the prescription of drugs in certain hospitals. Is that right?
—Yes.

—I have over many years been able to avail myself of the arrangement whereby in certain emergency situations one can make an arrangement with a pharmacist to whom one is known for drugs to be issued with a prescription to follow. A nurse can take it round soon after. Obviously some system is needed to cover emergency situations where, for example, someone needs to start some drug treatment immediately and where no delay can be countenanced. As to what is going on in hospitals or what the new administrative arrangements are, I would need to get details for Senator MacGibbon. I agree with the honourable senator that those arrangements should operate to the benefit of patients. If there could be any considerable delay in patients starting necessary drug therapy I think that is something which the Minister for Health would want to take on board and consider.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce a question concerning the distillate rebate. I draw the Minister's attention to the following statement made in the Budget:

QUESTION.PARA: The excise exemption for distillate used off-road has been removed and it is estimated that only about two-fifths of previously exempt distillate consumption will benefit from the new excise rebate arrangements.In view of that statement, does the Minister have any information that could give us an indication as to what percentage of major sectors of the community that previously had the excise exemption will now enjoy the rebate arrangements?

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have to seek those detailed figures from the Minister for Industry and Commerce. I will do so.

—Will the Minister representing the Minister for Defence confirm that the Mirage squadron presently based in Butterworth will be redeployed in the Northern Territory as promised when it leaves Malaya in 1983? Will the Minister indicate whether the squadron will be based in Darwin or at Tindal?
—I have no information on that matter. I would need to refer it to the Minister for Defence. I will do so and bring down an answer as soon as possible.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Health been drawn to an article in the July-September issue of an Institute of Public Affairs publication on Medibank Private? Is it a fact that Medibank Private has accumulated losses of millions of dollars in all States except Victoria? If so, can the Minister say whether these losses are capable of being reversed in the foreseeable future without the necessity of further Federal grants similar to the $20m granted to Medibank Private by the Government?

—I have seen the article in the journal of the Institute of Public Affairs concerning Medibank Private. Earlier in the year when I was the Acting Minister for Health and the Minister for Health I received some representations related to Medibank Private. I understand that the experience of this fund has varied between the States. There has been a difference in experience, as Senator Walters indicates in the question. For example, the operation in Victoria has been profitable but in some other States it may not have been profitable. I understand that the matter is before my colleague, the Minister for Health, at the present time. He has it under study. What his decision might be-that decision would cover some of the other parts of Senator Walters's question-I am unable to say at present. I will make her question known to him in case there is more he can tell her immediately.

—I ask a question of the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is it true that a planned visit to the South Australian industrial town of Whyalla by the Prime Minister next week has now been cancelled? Is the reason for this cancellation that the Liberal Party in South Australia has told the Prime Minister that he is not welcome during the campaign leading up to the election to be held in South Australia on 6 November, an election which will be announced by the Premier at two o'clock this afternoon? In view of the fact that the new federalism, as practised by the Prime Minister and the South Australian Premier, has given South Australia the highest unemployment rate of all mainland States, unbearably high housing interest rates, the highest taxation burden in Australian history and cutbacks in services to the community, especially in the areas of health and education, I invite the Prime Minister to review his decision and to come to South Australia to explain to the State, and especially the 50,000 unemployed in South Australia, why there is such an economic disaster at the moment. Will the Leader of the Government in the Senate convey this request to the Prime Minister?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am unaware that any proposed visit by the Prime Minister to South Australia has been cancelled. I am utterly certain that if a foreshadowed visit is now not proceeding it is not because the Prime Minister would not be welcome in South Australia. Indeed, in the weeks immediately ahead a series of senior Ministers-I believe the Prime Minister, the Deputy Prime Minister and certainly I-will be going to South Australia and visiting these various areas. I can only say, having been to these areas in recent times, that there is an enormous and welcome interest in what the Commonwealth is doing. Since Senator Bolkus has drawn attention to the difficulties facing South Australia, let me say that the difficulties of South Australia in providing industrial employment for its people lie entirely in the years when the lotus was eaten, when the Dunstan Government was in office. The Dunstan Government did nothing at all to bring employment to South Australia. The Tonkin Government is developing the pipeline from the Cooper Basin to Whyalla. I visited the Cooper Basin several weeks ago.
—Who started that project? It was a Labor government.

—The pipeline from Whyalla to Stony Point in South Australia is a development of the Tonkin Government. It will create an entirely new industry in Whyalla. The new petrochemical industry that will be created will help South Australia enormously. The South Australian Government is seeking to develop the Roxby Downs project. The Australian Labor Party Opposition is trying to destroy job opportunities for mining and metal development in South Australia. The South Australian Government is eagerly seeking to get a uranium enrichment plant for South Australia which will provide employment for hundreds, perhaps thousands, of South Australians. The Labor Party is obstructing that project. If there is anybody who ought to say: 'Physician, cure thyself'--

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Minister is obviously debating the subject at great length. I wish to make a suggestion. If it is correct that there is to be an election in South Australia in a month's time, all South Australian members of the Senate ought to be excluded from the chamber, because it is fairly obvious that the Government is engaged in lengthy debates at Question Time in particular.

—Order! There is no point of order, but I took notice of what the honourable senator said and also of the question asked of the Leader of the Government. The thought also crossed my mind that it would appear that we are getting ready for an election in a particular State. Accordingly, I ask all honourable senators not to show quite so much parochialism. Loyalty is good but let us not overdo the parochialism during the coming few weeks. If an honourable senator asks a question such as that he or she must expect an appropriate response.

—There cannot be any more important questions and answers than those relating to the democratic process that is called a general election. Therefore, I would say that it is a very proper matter on which to answer.
—Steady. You are on the Standing Orders Committee. Don't pull rank.
—Order!

—Mr President, I can understand why the Opposition seeks to distract. Why would it not want distraction in order not to be reminded of the destructive years of the previous Labor Government? Why would it not want to try to remove from the record and from the knowledge of the community all those wasted years of the Dunstan Government, when no industrial development took place? Why would it not want to hide the fact that it is opposed to Roxby Downs? Why would it not want to hide the fact that it is opposed to uranium enrichment and that, step by step, it is seeking to deny job opportunities to the people of South Australia? Why would it not want to try to confuse people about the fact that under the Tonkin Government new developments are taking place and taking place rapidly; that the exciting new liquids pipeline will bring with it great new development; that only yesterday the discovery of more coal deposits was announced; that only a few days ago--

—I rise on a point of order. In regard to all these questions about why the Labor Party is not doing this, that or the next thing, is the Leader of the Government asking them of the members of the Labor Party and, if so, who should respond?

—Order! There is no point of order. I repeat that the question did lead to the type of response that is being given; it was politically loaded. All honourable senators must give consideration to the type of question they ask. I would also request the Leader of the Government to respond to my plea.

—I repeat that a chronic unemployment situation was established in the past, and major steps are being taken by the Tonkin Government to overcome it. However, it is being obstructed at every turn by the Labor Opposition in South Australia.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology. I preface it by stating that the Landsat D remote sensing satellite project, which has proven a boon to government, government authorities and Australian private enterprise, is unique because it is the only resource and land mapping satellite that is servicing Australia. Moreover, with this in mind, reports from the United States indicate that the United States Government is pressing ahead in having Landsat made over to private enterprise. I ask: As the terms of the Outer Space Treaty of the United Nations demand a high degreee of regularisation, with heavy private investment in Landsat, what is the future for the Australian user? Will it be as difficult as has been forecast and will the Australian Government make representations to ensure that the interest of the Australian user in Landsat is safely guarded for the future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have some information on the matter but I do not believe that it addresses the precise questions asked by Senator Kilgariff. I will refer them to the Minister and seek an early response.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, refers to a letter written by the Minister to me recently regarding the provision of translator services for the transmission of national Australian Broadcasting Commission and multicultural television in the Darlinghurst-Paddington area of Sydney. In that letter the Minister said that the completion of these arrangements had been 'delayed due to difficulties connected with sharing arrangements between the Commonwealth and commercial licensees, who provide the common facilities'. I ask: Can the Minister advise the nature of the common facilities provided by the licensees, the nature of the difficulties that the Commonwealth and the licensees are experiencing, and the cost to the Commonwealth of gaining access to these translator facilities?
—The question contains details which will have to be referred to my colleague. I will refer it for his comment.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General, follows a question in this place from Senator Giles earlier today and a question asked by Senator Crichton-Browne on Tuesday. It concerns the Ord River sugar industry and refers in particular to sections 99 and 92 of the Constitution. In spite of the endeavours of the Australian Labor Party, and in particular the Western Australian Labor senators, to prevent the development of a sugar industry in Western Australia, is it the considered opinion of the Attorney that under those two sections of the Constitution the Commonwealth would not be able to refuse an export licence for sugar from the Ord River area?
—You are asking for a legal opinion. Throw it out.
—Isn't that a legal opinion?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think my old law teachers would assure the Senate that anything I say here should not be taken as a legal opinion. I will try to avoid breaching the Standing Orders in any way by simply commenting, without giving a legal opinion, on the question raised by my colleague Senator Thomas. The matter of Ord River sugar has become quite contentious and its treatment is complicated by the fact that there are national media. It is very difficult to say one thing in Queensland and something different in Western Australia. What one says in Queensland tends to follow one back to Western Australia and vice versa. A number of the important elements in the debate need to be borne very carefully in mind. One is that there is no power in the Commonwealth to control land use. The use to which land is put in Australia is a matter either for private commercial decision or for State government regulation. One important thing to be remembered is that it is not the Commonwealth which will determine whether a particular crop is grown in any particular place.

ANSWER.PARA: The Constitution guarantees certain rights to people. The provisions of section 92 are well known even to all honourable senators and indeed to many citizens. That is a substantial restriction on the ability of government to fetter interstate trade and internal commerce in Australia. As far as section 99 is concerned, I do not wish to give a legal opinion but it is certainly the view of the Government that it would not wish to use export permits in a differential way which would discriminate in favour of one part of Australia and against another. The policies of this Government will be administered on a national basis and not on a regional basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister representing the Acting Attorney- General concerns Mr Al Grassby, the Commissioner for Community Relations, whose seven-year appointment as Commissioner comes to an end on 31 October. What decision has been made about Mr Grassby's future? Given his outstanding record of support for, and championing of, the causes of ethnic minorities in this country, given the high standard of the reports that he has presented to this Parliament, and given the very high degree of acceptability which he has in ethnic communities throughout Australia, including Aboriginal communities, will the Government reappoint him?
—I will refer that question to the Acting Attorney-General.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 October Senator Walsh asked me a question regarding Mr Costigan and the inquiry into Mr Denis Horgan. I think he repeated the substance of the question yesterday. I said that I would give him a reply. I gave him an interim reply on that day, 12 October. My understanding is that the Treasurer in another place today has given a reply to a similiar question. First of all, I think Senator Walsh asked who made the actual approach on behalf of the Prime Minister. The approach was made at the level of the Department of Administrative Services, which is responsible for royal commissions. I believe that it was either the head of that Department or the Minister. There were discussions with Mr Costigan. From those discussions it emerged that he himself was considering making, over a period, some wider inquiries into Western Australia and other matters, and that the matter may take some time. He also felt that, if he were to be doing it, it would be under the Royal Commission, and that in that case perhaps the Royal Commission would need extended terms of reference. The Government felt that, if he were to do it , he might do it as a Queen's Counsel and not on the full basis of a royal commission, particularly as that would take so long. Because it was not possible for Mr Costigan to be available in the short term, the Government decided to seek, through the Law Council of Australia, an independent recommendation of another silk.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Missen asked a question earlier this week with regard to the International Telecommunications Union and the United States' intentions. When the question was answered, the Minister and the Department of Foreign Affairs had no knowledge of any public statement by the United States regarding its intentions in the event of a resolution being passed excluding Israel from the ITU. Since the time of that question being answered, advice has been received that the United States' intentions have been made public in Nairobi, where the conference is being held. The leader of the United States delegation to the conference has stated that, in the event of a reso- lution being passed which expels, suspends or excludes Israel from the ITU, the United States delegation will be withdrawn from the conference.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I should like to add to the answer that I gave yesterday to a question relating to Father Brian Gore. Senator Mason asked me about the detention of Father Brian Gore on 24 September on charges relating to the alleged discovery of explosives and anti-government documents in his parish in the Philippines. Our embassy in Manila has advised that on 28 September an arrest warrant was issued by a local judge charging Father Gore in relation to the alleged discovery of explosives. A further warrant has been issued by the judge charging Father Gore with inciting to rebellion. There is no indication yet when the warrants will be served or when Father Gore will be asked to appear in court.

DEBATE.TITLE: FEDERATED SHIP PAINTERS AND DOCKERS UNION

TALK.START.PARA: —(Victoria-Leader of the Opposition) (11.7)-I seek leave, Mr President, to make a statement in relation to a matter which arose during Question Time.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator BUTTON

TALK.START.PARA: —In the course of an answer to a question today, Senator Sir John Carrick got on to the subject of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. He said in the course of his answer that the ship painters and dockers disaffiliated themselves from the Labor Party and:

INTERJECT.PARA: They were defended in this place by Labor.

The clear implication of that statement is that the Australian Labor Party in this place defended the criminal activities of certain ship painters and dockers . For the purpose of the record, I just want to say that there is not one tittle of evidence advanced by anyone, including Senator Sir John Carrick, in support of that proposition. In the course of interjections, I happened to mention that the statement that Senator Sir John Carrick made was in my view a lie, and because of the Standing Orders I withdrew that allegation. The fact is that the criminal activities of the ship painters and dockers have not been defended by Labor politicians in this place or anywhere else.

I want to make reference to the political record in relation to this matter. The fact is that it was a Labor Government that first set up an inquiry into payments to maritime unions-the so-called Sweeney inquiry-which had the status of a royal commission. In its report to this Parliament-I do not have the document here to quote from it-Mr Justice Sweeney, as he subsequently became, sought extended terms of reference to examine questions related to tax avoidance and tax evasion involving the ship painters and dockers. It was the Fraser Government which, in 1976, terminated the activities of that inquiry by Mr Justice Sweeney, as he became, and refused to extend the terms of reference to inquire into that matter. A month ago I asked in the Senate whether that was correct. I have not yet received an answer for reasons which I think are fairly obvious. I am talking about the governmental record in relation to the ship painters and dockers organisation. It is quite true that following the publication of the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union the Labor Party became aware, as did the Government-in the case of the Labor Party certainly for the first time and I believe in the case of the Government for the first time-that ship painters and dockers were involved as agents for and accessories to large white collar criminals in the Australian community in relation to tax matters amongst other things. The first time that the Labor Party became aware of this matter was the publication of the Costigan report.

Of course, it is part of the burden of Senator Sir John Carrick's argument, when answering questions on a number of issues relating to ship painters and dockers, to suggest from time to time that the Labor Party has condoned the criminal activities of certain ship painters and dockers-for example for murder, robbery and things of this kind-which took place over a number of years.

I want to make our position quite clear on this matter. If the honourable senator wants to say that the Labor Party defends ship painters and dockers I will say that as far as I am concerned I do, in terms of the legitimate activities of ship painters and dockers which undoubtedly exist. Undoubtedly many ship painters and dockers who perform that craft or trade are not subject, in my view, to criticism in any way. However, there are other ship painters and dockers who engage in criminal activities. I think it is an important distinction to make. If one wants to reduce this argument to its absolute absurdity, the major crimes committed by ship painters and dockers have been committed in Victoria. They were all committed in the course of Liberal governments in that State and those governments were singularly unsuccessful in prosecuting for criminal offences members of the ship painters and dockers organisations. This is reducing the argument to an absurdity.

Since the Labor Government came to power in Victoria there have been no criminal activities by ship painters and dockers. That is an absurd argument but it is the level of debate which takes place in this chamber in relation to these sorts of matters. I suppose what brings this sort of response from Senator Sir John Carrick, when answering questions, is the 'my daddy is a policeman' argument and the 'we might be awful but you are just as bad' argument. This seems to reduce politics to its lowest common denominator. If one deals with that argument, this Government has been singularly unsuccessful in spite of repeated requests from the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), in getting rid of people in the Liberal Party described by the Prime Minister of this country as tax cheats.

The Labor Party has not been so unsuccessful. When it learnt of the Costigan Commission findings that ship painters and dockers were heavily involved in tax evasion and subsidiary activities to white collar crime the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) announced that a decision would be taken by the National Executive of the Labor Party to disaffiliate that organisation. It is absolutely true to say that the ship painters and dockers disaffiliated themselves before that decision was taken. However the National Executive of the Labor Party took a decision, noting that the ship painters and dockers had disaffiliated themselves and determining that they would not be re-affiliated with the Australian Labor Party until such time as the issues and allegations against the ship painters and dockers organisation had been dealt with and determined by the courts. That is an appropriate position for any political party to take.

I put those matters on the record because I think it is important to look at the records of respective governments in relation to these sorts of activities. I think it is important to distinguish between criminal activities and categorising a whole group of people as being reprehensible-if I can use a word that once became fashionable in this Parliament. The allegation that the criminal activities of the ship painters and dockers were defended by Labor in this place is totally untrue. If Senator Sir John Carrick alleges that it is not untrue I ask him to substantiate that any Labor leader or member has defended criminal activities of ship painters and dockers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-We are debating a statement made by leave by Senator Button relating to matters raised at Question Time today. I think, Mr President, that you would agree and that the Hansard will show that the outburst by the Labor Party, 'It is a lie!', occurred when I said primarily that the Labor Party did not disaffiliate the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union but that it disaffiliated itself. It will be found that that is when the outburst originally occurred on this matter, and it went on subsequently. The fact is--

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before we reach a crescendo of interjections may I just make the point that I was delighted that the Leader of the Opposition was heard in silence. I ask that the Leader of the Government in the Senate also be heard in silence on this matter.

—The fact is that what I said then is absolutely true; that is, that the Ship Painters and Dockers disaffiliated itself. Therefore, the outburst was quite unnecessary. The fact is that Senator Button, in his personal explanation, has sought to narrow the matter down to this: To narrow the Painters and Dockers down to white collar crime. He said that when the Labor Party discovered that the Painters and Dockers Union was engaged in white collar crime it set out to disaffiliate itself. The point I have made is that in general terms, over the years, the Painters and Dockers Union has been known to have a record of bloody murder and violence, and the Labor Party has taken no action in that regard. In fact, on Senator Button's own statement today-and Hansard will bear this out-he said that the Labor Party reacted to white collar crime, not to other things. He also said that he would defend the Painters and Dockers as a union. I would, of course, defend any authentic trade union or any authentic trade unionist who was acting lawfully. But I remind him of what the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union said. It said, in effect, that the Ship Painters and Dockers Union was not a trade union; that it was an organisation of criminals organised to recruit criminals for criminal purposes.

SPEECH.PARA: I respond only because I think the personal explanations have gone too far anyhow. In the first place I only respond on the subject matter of this situation. The fact is that the whole of my answer to the question was to the effect that Labor had been selective; that Labor would draw upon people whose records have proved to be clear, but in a selective way avoid entirely others, for example, an appointee of the Wran Government, avoid people who may have been associated with Labor. I put it to the Senate that that was a very appropriate line of argument to take.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Ryan proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The continuing failure of the Federal Government to grant freehold title to Aboriginal and Islander people to their reserve lands in Queensland.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise this matter today in very specific terms and the specific terms as stated in the matter of public importance are:

SPEECH.PARA: The continuing failure of the Federal Government to grant freehold title to Aboriginal and Islander people to their reserve lands in Queensland.

The point of the terms being so specific is this: There is no freehold title in Queensland. The State Government in Queensland has made it perfectly clear on numerous occasions that it has no intention of granting freehold title. In recent times, the Prime Minister of Australia (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has made it clear that he, too, has no intention of using the constitutional powers that this Parliament has to grant freehold title in Queensland. This is of ongoing and serious concern not only to all fair-minded Australians but also increasingly to fair-minded people throughout the world.

As honourable senators will be aware, the Commonwealth Games in Brisbane have just concluded. I should like to say, as Opposition members have said on other occasions, that we regard the Commonwealth Games as having been a success. We, along with all Australians, were delighted by the performance of our athletes. We were delighted by the way in which the Commonwealth community of athletes was able to participate in sporting events, by the standard of the events, and by the obvious pleasure and pride that the Games gave to all the participants and those who attended and, I might say, those who were able to view the Games through Australian Broadcasting Commission television, which did an excellent job also in bringing the Games to people throughout Australia. However, everybody who paid any attention at all will be aware that the Games was not the only thing happening in Brisbane in the last couple of weeks. The other issue was the matter of the Aboriginal land rights protests which, in contrast to the Games, is an issue which causes shame to Australians. Increasingly, this is a matter of which the world community is aware.

The Commonwealth Games may be over but the issue of land rights in Queensland is not over, nor will it be over until such time as freehold title to land is accorded to the Aboriginal and Islander people. The failure of both the Queensland Government and the Federal Government to achieve freehold land title for Aboriginals meant that the Games were, to some extent, overshadowed by this blot on our national character. The international media, quite rightly, took a great deal of interest in these matters and made extensive reports throughout the world on this gross defect in the situation in Queensland, a defect for which the Federal Government is also responsible.

We know what happened during the Games. Several hundred land rights protesters, Aboriginal people and their supporters, were arrested. Tens of thousands of dollars were spent on bail and fines for protesters. Although this is peripheral to the major point, it will cause much hardship amongst the Aboriginal community , already the most grossly impoverished section of the Australian community. The point I want to make is that those arrests should not have happened, not because the cause is not just or because our sympathies are not with the people who support that cause, but because that Act should never been enacted. I should like to take this opportunity to say also that the land rights protestors showed great restraint in their activities during the Commonwealth Games. Their demonstrations were peaceful and there was no attempt to disrupt the Games. I think that is a point that ought to go on the record and is a matter about which the organisers of the Games and all authorities who had control of the Games ought to express appreciation. There was no disruption of the Games. There was no attempt to disrupt the Games, and the demonstrations were peaceful. There was no violent protest by the demonstrators. Any minor violence which occurred did so in the process of the police carrying out their arrests, but the protests were never violent. This, I think, is something that ought to be noted, and on the part of the Australian Labor Party it is certainly appreciated that those who chose this forum to make their very just protests acted in a very responsible manner.

One might ask why a large number of arrests were made. Why did people viewing the Games and the news items associated with the Games witness large numbers of Aboriginal people and their supporters being arrested? It was not because of the behaviour of the protesters but because of the existence of an Act brought into being by the Queensland Government to overcome the fact that it had failed in its duty to grant freehold title to Aboriginal people. If the matter of land rights in Queensland had been settled, and the Federal Opposition made every attempt in this place and elsewhere to get that matter settled, then the Act would not have been necessary and the demonstrations would not have taken place.

The claim, as I have said many times, and I believe it is a claim that an increasing number of Australians support, is that the Aboriginal and Islander people are entitled to freehold title for less than 2 per cent of Queensland land. That less than 2 per cent is the land covered by existing reserves. The Queensland Government says that it wants the Aboriginal people to continue to have the use of that land. It is not trying to move them off the land and yet it will not give them secure title to that land. In the face of the repression by the Queensland Government and the continual racist statements by Ministers of that Government, the Aboriginal people turned, rightly, to the Federal Government. They sought action by the Federal Government to solve the problem of land in Queensland. What did the Federal Government do? In the House of Representatives it refused to vote on a Bill which would have solved the problem and then subsequently the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), to the horror of all people who have supported this cause, made a statement in support of the Queensland Government and its legislation.

As I said, there is no doubt that the interest of the international media was as much focused on what was happening with the land rights protests as it was on the Games. I draw the Senate's attention to the way in which Australia's performance with regard to its Aboriginal citizens in the State of Queensland has been reported in the world media. This is what Americans read in their 11 October issue of Newsweek:

Earlier this year, the Queensland Government charged that Aborigines had received military guerrilla training in Libya and were setting up secret guerrilla camps, assisted by militant New Zealand Maoris. Aborigine leaders denied the accusations and insisted that their demonstrations demanding land concessions would be peaceful. But the Government then passed special legislation suspending many civil liberties, including protection from unwarranted searches and seizures, for the duration of the sporting events. Police riot squads were issued with formidable new weapons, and an official ban was slapped on public discussion of security arrangements for the games. Queensland's avowedly reactionary Premier, Johannes Bjelke-Petersen, boasted to reporters: 'They can protest until they're black in the face, but they won't get land rights.'
The article by Carl Robinson and Spencer Reiss went on to say:
The message that many will take home from the games is clear. 'There is growing awareness that something is very wrong in Australia.'

For his attempt to enlighten Americans about the other side of the Friendly Games, Mr Robinson received a rap over the knuckles by the Department of Foreign Affairs at the instigation of the Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser.
