This was reported in the Age on 6 October. Clearly, in the Prime Minister's view, it would not do for the hypocrisy of the Federal Government on the Aboriginal issue to become well known. However, the Prime Minister has a very steep task ahead of him if he intends to silence the large number of other prominent media outlets throughout the world which have taken up this issue. For example, on 8 October the Guardian described the protests as follows:
. . . primarily designed to force the right wing Queensland Government, led by Joh Bjelke-Petersen, to follow other States by granting Aborigines freehold title to their reserves.
The article went on:

The spotlight has hit upon several murky corners of Queensland life including the authoritarian running of the reserves. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs Mr Ken Tomkins, interviewed by New Zealand radio said that the Aborigines would not know what land rights were. 'Aborigines eat birds and fish and drink a lot,' he said.

Reports of similar character are to be found in the Times, on British Broadcasting Commission television, in the Observer and in newspapers in Africa and North America. I ask honourable senators: Is this a situation that the Senate condones? Do we want the international media, brought here to witness sporting events, sending back reports of that nature-entirely accurate reports- to people throughout the world? Clearly it is a situation that the Fraser Government is prepared to condone at this stage.

Let us turn our attention to what the Aboriginal and Islander people want. They want inalienable freehold title to their reserve lands and the Fraser Government has failed to secure that for them. I know what the Minister for Education ( Senator Peter Baume) will say in response to this debate. He will say that the Aboriginals do not need freehold title; that the leasing arrangements that the Queensland Government has come up with are good enough and that the Fraser Government is prepared to guarantee these leasing arrangements.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did he say that?

—I know what Senator Baume will say because he has said the same thing with tedious repetition ever since this issue became one of national significance and has been raised regularly in this place. Senator Baume will tell us that he knows what is good for the Aboriginal people-that is, this dubious leasing arrangement-and that they are wrong in seeking freehold title. Our response to this is that the demand is for freehold title and that that is a proper and just demand. The Fraser Government has already been prepared to give freehold title in the Northern Territory and it ought to be prepared to achieve the same thing in Queensland. We are not interested in guarantees for legislation which is totally unacceptable to the Aboriginal and Islander people in Queensland. I hope that Senator Baume will have something more interesting and pertinent to say than that. The Queensland Government, backed now by the Federal Government since the Prime Minister had decided that what Premier Bjelke -Petersen is doing is good enough, is offering something it calls deeds of grant in trust which it says will give secure tenure and will provide land for the Aborigines on the same basis as other Queenslanders. However, no, reputable legal opinion supports the claims of the Queensland Government about its legislation or the claims of the Fraser Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us have a look at what Father Frank Brennan, a Jesuit priest and barrister commissioned by the Catholic Bishops to examine the Queensland legislation, has said about that legislation. He has pointed out that the Queensland Cabinet may cancel or vary the deed at any time; that Cabinet may declare the land to revert to the Crown for any reason that it appears to it to be desirable to do so; that the Minister for Lands and Forestry may cancel any lease if he is satisfied that any conditions are not being met; that Cabinet could resume land for public purposes including for tourist purposes, pastoral reserves, air strips and so on ; and that the grant carries no mining, forestry and quarry rights and Cabinet can give permission for miners to enter at any time.
The uncontroverted and long-published opinion of leading Queen's Counsel, Mr Bill Pincus, obtained by Archbishop Rush, Archbishop Grindrod and Reverend Father Brennan concluded:
If there was a genuine intention of giving security of tenure, it is manifest that that intention has by no means been achieved under the deed of grant in trust proposal.
So that is the totally unsatisfactory situation which Malcolm Fraser says he is prepared to support and which Senator Baume will now tell us is what the Aboriginal people really want and need.

In recent statements by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Wilson, the support for this totally unsatisfactory piece of legislation appears stronger than ever. The reservations about the Queensland land legislation which Senator Baume expressed on 1 April of this year seem to have disappeared in Mr Wilson's recent statement on land tenure for Queensland Aboriginals, the statement he made on Tuesday of this week. Mr Wilson states, and totally inaccurately according to all legal opinion:

The commitment by the Queensland Government to introduce deed of grant in trust means quite simply, that Aboriginals and Islanders in Queensland will have secure tenure on the reserve lands on which they now live.
An opinion like that coming from Mr Wilson makes it very clear to honourable senators in this place why Mr Wilson is no longer practising law. In a piece of semantic nonsense--

TALK.START.PARA: —He is practising; that is the point. He is not doing it; he is practising.
—He is practising and one of these days he might learn the difference between lease and freehold title.
—You teach him.
—I would be delighted to undertake that task. In a piece of semantic nonsense the Minister goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The reality is that security of tenure now exists, which is more important than the debate about what terms we choose to define that security.

The reality is that Aboriginal people do not own their land. Either Aboriginal people have security of tenure or they do not. But Mr Wilson's statement ends with what can be regarded only as a veiled threat. He says:
It-
That is security of tenure-

will not be achieved by taking the easy and irresponsible path of breaking laws and ignoring the facts. Indeed, that path might end up leading Aboriginals and Islanders away from the fulfilment of their just and fair aspirations.

So there is the not terribly veiled threat that they will not even get their deed of grant in trust legislation if they continue to exercise their democratic rights and protests in this matter. The Prime Minister was also reported as saying this week:
The Queensland Government has said it is sincere in making this land available to Aboriginals, and the practical effect of it is that it will be in perpetuity.
He also said:
A deed of grant in trust offered as much security as freehold.

This is clearly quite wrong and in the circumstances, which include the drastic criticism of the Queensland legislation by informed legal opinion, the Fraser Government's guarantee of this legislation is useless because it is guaranteeing something that nobody, except Mr Bjelke-Petersen, wants.

I think it is timely to ask why the Fraser Government is continuing to resist giving Aboriginals freehold title in Queensland particularly when it has been prepared to grant it in the Northern Territory. Is it because the Fraser Government no longer supports Aboriginal land rights at all? Is this change of policy confirmed by its current efforts to undermine the Northern Territory Land Rights Act?

The Queensland Government's racist attitude to the Aboriginal people was again demonstrated during the Commonwealth Games by the insulting and provocative remarks of its Minister for Aboriginal and Island Affairs, Mr Ken Tomkins. Honourable senators will recall that in an interview with Radio New Zealand Mr Tomkins stated that Aboriginal people were not advanced to a stage where we could give them freehold land. He also stated that because Aboriginal people lived on birds and goannas they did not need much money. Compounding this appalling situation, the Premier Mr Bjelke-Petersen, in a follow-up interview on Thursday's AM called land rights protesters militants, self-confessed communists and agitators and again made it clear that freehold land tenure for Aboriginal reserves was out of the question. This is the sort of regime that the Fraser Government is supporting. People such as Mr Tomkins who are making these derogatory, patronising and insulting remarks to Aboriginal and Islander people in Queensland are being supported by the Prime Minister of this country. The constant outbursts of Premier Bjelke-Petersen along the lines that people who support land rights are communists are now being supported by the Prime Minister . And they wonder why the protests continue.

Why does the Queensland Government resist so fiercely the move towards freehold title? Why is it retaining ownership of those lands and through its leasing arrangements the ability to resume those lands at any moment it chooses to do so ? I think the answers lie in the areas of mining and tourism. An article in the West Australian of 29 September by Lorenzo Boccabella put the position in these terms:
The whole of the Cape York Peninsula in North Queensland could be vital to Australia's future as a major world aluminium producer. It was among the world's largest bauxite reserves.
Besides the Shell-Pechiney and Comalco interests, Alcan also holds a large bauxite lease next to those held by the other two groups.

In this context, the last thing the Queensland Government wants is Northern Territory style land rights legislation where Aboriginals have both a say over mining activities and a healthy share of royalties.
Queensland Government economic interest in Aboriginal areas extends beyond mining.
On July 20 this year, the Premier announced that tenders would be called for the development of a tourist resort on Sweers Island in the Gulf of Carpentaria.
The Premier said: The area offers an ideal location for a first class resort with activities based on cruising and fishing.
Sweers Island is part of the land claims of the Queensland Aborigines.

In early 1977 without consultation or agreement from either the Aborigines or the Federal Government the island was excised from the boundary of the Mornington Island Aboriginal Reserve when that reserve was converted into a shire council along with Aurukun.

For Queensland Aboriginals who were forcibly moved away from their reserve at Weipa by the Queensland Government to make way for Comalco as recently as 1963, the further loss of their reserves is very real.
What situation are we faced with for the future? The Queensland Government is talking about wanting the Olympic Games held in Brisbane in 1992.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wishful thinking.

—It is wishful thinking because it should know that while the current race situation prevails in Queensland there is no chance of the Olympic Federation agreeing to that request. In any case, 1992 is a long way away. We know that there will be a Federal Labor government long before that time-indeed, quite soon. One of the first acts of that Federal Labor government will be to pass my private members Bill, which will be Labor legislation, to grant freehold title, not any other form of lease, over to the Aboriginal and Islander reserves in Queensland, which will then resolve the situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators could be excused for having a certain feeling of deja vu or ennui at what we have just heard. This shrill and pathetic offering will not do Senator Ryan any good when the Caucus re-elections come up in the future. So many debates have been initiated by Senator Ryan on this matter. On 16 September 1981 Senator Ryan raised a matter of public importance; on 24 September 1981 we debated her private member's Bill; on 12 November 1981 we debated her private member's Bill; on 18 March this year we debated her private member's Bill; on 24 March we debated her private member's Bill; on 4 May we debated another matter of public importance; and now we are debating this matter. We have again and again debated the same subject. The Government has made its position clear on every occasion the matter has been raised. However, I suppose I have to go through it all again and hope that this time at last Senator Ryan might get it right. I am sorry to do this, because time is passing.

SPEECH.PARA: Positive things are happening in Queensland. I just wish that Senator Ryan and the Opposition generally would get behind the efforts we have all been making to achieve real and lasting benefits for the Aboriginal and Islander people of Queensland. During the last week Senator Bonner, who is a member of this chamber , has played a notable and positive role in Queensland. He has played the role of a statesman, a mediator and a leader. He has advocated moderation. What he did in Brisbane last week was a credit to him, a credit to the Parliament which he represents and a credit to Aboriginal people. I believe what he did was in contrast to the action of those other people who work in Queensland not to heal but to inflame. The people who went up to Queensland, such as Senator Ryan, Mr Uren, Dr Murphy, Senator Tate, Senator Georges and Senator Gietzelt, made promises which were unrealistic and on which they cannot deliver. They incited people. When the arrests occurred later in the week none of them, but other people, was involved. Senator Ryan said today how terrible it was that they all had to pay out the bail money. They were there to do the inciting. They were not there at the sharp end when the time came. They lit the bushfires.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order.
—We have some sensitivities here, Mr Acting Deputy President .

—I want the word 'incite' withdrawn as it is an imputation against members of the Opposition and in particular me. I want that word withdrawn because I find it offensive. Senator Baume has selected one member of Parliament to laud; he deserves some commendation. What Senator Peter Baume is not aware of is that a number of other people did their utmost to see that there was no--
—Order! The honourable senator has made his point of order.
—Wait a moment--
—I withdraw the word 'incite'. The honourable senator is using my time.
—I am making a point of order.
—I ask Senator Georges to resume his seat. He has made his point of order. The word has been withdrawn. I call the Minister.
—Senator Ryan said that a large number of Aboriginal people were involved in the protest.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator Georges has the call. He is entitled to take his point of order without interruption from the Chair. When he has completed his submission it is competent for the Chair to rule upon that point of order. If Senator Baume wishes to withdraw the offending statement, that is fair enough. But I do not think it is proper for the Chair to interrupt an honourable senator when he is seeking to explain why he has taken a point of order.

—Honourable senators are not allowed to debate a point of order of this nature. If an honourable senator takes offence at a particular remark, I will order the remark to be withdrawn. In this case the remark was withdrawn. There is no necessity for any further debate on the matter . I call Senator Baume.

—Senator Ryan said that a large number of Aboriginal people were involved. She did not observe the fact that many other people who were non- Aboriginal-many were from out of Queensland-were also involved. Of course, those people did break the law. What is upsetting is that the Aboriginal people in Queensland have now been left to pick up the mess. They have been left with the reaction. I ask: How will this help Aboriginal people? I return to my argument. Our goal is to try to find real and lasting benefits for Aboriginal people in Queensland. To do this is neither easy nor simple. Slogans or nostrums for quickie solutions will not be the way through. The real question is what will benefit Queensland Aboriginal people. What is needed is careful negotiation with Queensland figures, Queensland Government figures, Queensland Aborigines and Queensland community leaders if we are to get the right outcome and if we are to achieve the kind of understanding which is essential to the resolution which we desire. That is why the Commonwealth has so often stressed the importance of real and meaningful consultations with Aboriginal people. Those consultations have begun and they will continue.
—The Minister is a racist and you know it.

—I raise a point of order. Senator Geitzelt said that the Premier of Queensland is a racist. I believe that is a reflection upon the Premier. It is contrary to the Standing Orders to reflect upon a member of any parliament.
—Members of Federal and State parliaments are protected from offensive remarks.

—I said that the Minister for Aboriginal and Islander Affairs was a racist. I did not accuse the Premier of Queensland of that. Such was the outrageousness of the statements made by the Queensland Minister that he was disowned by the Queensland Premier and rebuked for the statements he made.
—I ask Senator Geitzelt to withdraw the remark that the Queensland Minister is a racist.
—No, I will not, because he is.
—Do I understand that you are refusing to withdraw, Senator?

—I am only repeating the remarks that were made by the Queensland Government about the comments that Mr Tomkins made in a statement. The Queensland Government rebuked the Minister for Aboriginal and Islander Affairs for the statements that he made, which were highly provocative and emotive in terms of the atmosphere that existed in Queensland. They provoked the subsequent turn of events which did, as Senator Baume has suggested, create some unnecessary and unhappy reactions. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs needs to be condemned for the statements he made which were not conducive to creating the sorts of relations that were necessary during the Commonwealth Games in Queensland.

—The honourable senator has explained his position. Nevertheless, Standing Order No. 418 protects both members of this Parliament and members of State parliaments from offensive remarks. Calling a Minister a racist is an offensive remark. I direct Senator Gietzelt to withdraw it.
—I withdraw the statement, but--
—That is all, Senator. You have withdrawn the statement; do not make an explanation. I call Senator Baume.

—Why is this matter of public importance raised now? Senator Ryan's sense of timing has not always been very good but it seems to be even worse now. On the last few occasions when she brought forward this matter she did so to try to get some publicity at around the time of some major event. For example, she timed one of the debates to precede the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting and, more recently, the Commonwealth Games. It was said that international audiences would be shocked by the situation in Queensland. The fact is that in relation to both CHOGM and the Commonwealth Games international commentators have been quicker than Senator Ryan to note that the governments of the Commonwealth and the States have done a great deal for Aboriginal advancement. Mr Ordia of the Supreme Council for Sport in Africa said so. I refer Senator Ryan to the Canberra Times of 27 September this year. Mr Ordia said that he believed the Federal Government and white Australians had shown a genuine desire to correct Aboriginal problems. But Senator Ryan either overlooked or chose not to use that comment. Mr Morales, the President of the World Council of Indigenous People, urged the National Aboriginal Conference to get down to the serious business of negotiation. Are members of the Opposition the only ones to stand back hoping that the perfect solution to all Aboriginal affairs matters will drop out of the sky one morning if only we will agree to their simplistic proposition contained in the matter of public importance which is before the Senate today. I cannot help observing--
—I raise a point of order.
—It must really be hurting today.

—I am sorry for doing this because I do have a great deal of respect for the Minister. I believe his suggestions about Senator Ryan's motivation are contrary to Standing Order No. 418. He made imputations of improper motives and personal reflections on members. I believe the statement casting doubt upon Senator Ryan's integrity and motivation in respect of this debate ought to be drawn to your attention, Mr Acting Deputy President. I ask that the Minister withdraw those remarks.
—Does Senator Ryan feel aggrieved by those remarks?
—Yes, I do.
—Senator Baume, will you withdraw?
—I made no imputations. What I said was that she had timed the debates to get some publicity at around the time of a major event. I will accept--
—It will facilitate the proceedings of the Senate if the Minister would withdraw those remarks.
—I will withdraw anything that Senator Ryan finds offensive.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, Standing Order No. 418 also demands that an honourable senator withdraw what I find or another senator finds offensive. It does not necessarily concern the person who is referred to. If the Minister is in breach of Standing Order 418 he is in breach of the whole of the Senate, not the particular person referred to.

—When a remark is found to be offensive it is the custom of this chamber to attach some weight to whether the person so affected is offended by it. The decision as to whether a remark should be withdrawn lies in the hands of the Chair. Senator Ryan said that she found certain remarks by Senator Peter Baume offensive. Senator Baume has withdrawn his statement and I suggest that we continue the debate.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, in speaking to your understanding and ruling on this matter I say that I have worked with Senator Ryan on the committee on Aboriginal affairs and I object to Senator Baume saying that he withdraws his statement in respect of Senator Ryan only.
—Order! There can be no debate on the ruling that I have given. It was ruled that the statement should be withdrawn and it has been. Senator Gietzelt will resume his seat. I call Senator Peter Baume.

—What failure has there been on the part of the Commonwealth Government? There has been no failure at all to pursue the issue of Aboriginal land tenure. It has pursued the interests of the Aboriginal and Islander people. For some time now, the Commonwealth has pursued patiently the path of negotiations towards this end. I remind honourable senators of the four principles I laid down in August of last year as a negotiating basis. I will not go through them in detail. Honourable senators are aware of them. I remind them also of the statement I made on 1 April of this year when I was Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I plainly and openly committed the Commonwealth to guaranteeing security of tenure for Aboriginal and Islander reserves under the Queensland system of deeds of grant in trust. I did that in April. How can it be said that there has been a failure on the part of the Commonwealth Government to take action? That guarantee, solemnly made, was reaffirmed by my successor on 27 August, just a few weeks ago. The Commonwealth Government stands right behind that commitment. It is a public commitment, so who can talk about failure to take action, let alone continuing failure to do so? It is convenient to write motions in such terms but they do not bear comparison with reality.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ryan has couched her matter of public importance in terms relating to freehold. What is in a word? It seems that I have to remind Senator Ryan once again that the objective for Aboriginal people is not to obtain some form of legal title under British law. What is important is that they obtain secure tenure of their land so that they can continue to live on it as they wish. It is the outcome, not the process, that is important. No one has lost a hectare of land and no one is going to. We have given a guarantee. In fact, the deed of grant in trust represents a more secure form of title in meeting the particular needs of Aboriginal communities at this stage of their history than does freehold. The matter of public importance speaks of freehold title. Was it just a slip that the honourable senator omitted the word 'inalienable'? Was it just sloppiness, poor preparation? Does not the honourable senator understand the difference between freehold and inalienable freehold? I suppose she means that she wants the reserve to be held under a form of freehold, similar to that which applies to the ownership of her house or mine-a form of title which we can mortgage or sell off. That is freehold. Is that what she means? Perhaps she should think about going to the United States to see what the Indian people did with their freehold land, so much of which has been lost. It has been sold off to get-rich-quick land speculators. I do not believe that anyone wants to see that happen to Aboriginal people in Australia. Perhaps the honourable senator should be more careful in regard to the words that she puts into these matters. After all, she has had a fair bit of practice. She should also be aware that in the Northern Territory Aboriginal people do not enjoy freehold which can be mortgaged or sold. They have Aboriginal title, which is different from freehold and is inalienable. If that is what the honourable senator meant, why did she not frame her matter of public importance in those terms? Perhaps it is just sloppiness.

What of the deed of grant in trust? Such a deed, taken with a Commonwealth guarantee-the two must be taken together-represents secure title in Aboriginal hands. The Commonwealth will ensure that the title that is granted meets the needs of the people. Legal aid to ensure that would be available to the communities. Only last week the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Wilson) wrote to Senator Bonner along these lines. The letter can be seen by Senator Ryan. I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
4 October 1982
Dear Senator Bonner,

You have told me that there are some questions being raised amongst Aboriginal people in Brisbane at present about the integrity of the reserve boundaries under the proposed Deeds of Grant in Trust arrangement.

I am not aware of any proposal which has been made public to vary the boundaries of any of the inhabited reserves which are to be the subject of Deeds of Grant in Trust. Like you, I have heard some rumours. But I stress that they are not more than rumours. Nor could they be, because it is my understanding that the Queensland Government has not yet notified any Community Council of the details of the area proposed to be granted to it.
I believe it would be timely for the Queensland Government to make known its detailed proposals and I am writing to the Queensland Minister, Mr Tomkins, accordingly.

I think I should also remind you that the Commonwealth Government has made it clear, in the context of its unequivocal guarantee, that the integrity of the reserve boundaries is one of the principles that is required to be satisfied in any settlement of the land tenure question in Queensland. For this reason, I have said before that the Commonwealth is prepared to ensure that Community Councils have available to them access to legal advice on the details of any proposed Deed that may be offered to any of them. This offer remains on the table and is available to Community Councils when they are made aware of the intentions of the Queensland Government with regard to the particular areas for which each of them will be responsible.
You may feel it is useful to let Aboriginal communities know of what I have said in this letter.
Ian Wilson M.P.
Senator Neville Bonner,
Commonwealth Government Centre,
295 Ann Street,
Brisbane Qld 4000

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I invite honourable senators to contrast the situation with deeds of grant in trust with that of freehold land in Queensland. In regard to security, which is important, in Queensland freehold land can be acquired under Schedule 2 of the Queensland Acquisition of Lands Act . It can be taken away by mere executive act for any reason declared to be a public purpose. That is what can happen to freehold land in Queensland. The deed of grant in trust that we have negotiated cannot be taken away just by executive action. It is revocable only with the authority of the Parliament. There is a Commonwealth guarantee putting that in place. Anyone who examines the two situations will have to agree that freehold title in Queensland is not secure in the terms which Senator Ryan acknowledges are necessary for Aboriginal people. The deed of grant in trust, with the Commonwealth guarantee, is the more secure.

SPEECH.PARA: Is Senator Ryan speaking about acquiring the reserves? I suppose that she is seeking the taking over by the Commonwealth of all the reserve land in Queensland. Has she calculated how many hundreds of millions of dollars would be needed, under the Australian Constitution, for the acquisition of that land? Has she really thought through how the Commonwealth could or would service these small isolated areas once Queensland's responsibility for them ceased, who would run the schools, who would build the roads, who would undertake public health and safety functions-all these things and a lot more? That is one of the inconvenient details that is omitted. I ask Senator Ryan to nominate which Aboriginal programs might have to be cut back to find those hundreds of millions ? Which other Commonwealth programs would have to be cut back. Where would the money come from? Surely I need not remind Senator Ryan again that when her party was in government it had available to it full constitutional power to go down the road that she is advocating travelling now. It examined the question of acquiring reserve lands and smartly backed away from it. She might wish to look at Hansard of 4 May 1982 at page 1776 if she wishes to refer to what was done or not done by the Labor Party when it was in office.

Progress is being made. In the last 10 years a great deal has been achieved for Aboriginal and Islander people all over Australia, not least in Queensland. More needs to be done. We have never made a secret of that. I wish Senator Ryan would take a fair look at the progress that has been made and work with us and with Aboriginal people towards still greater achievement. There is no substance in the matter of public importance and has not been from the beginning. The Government will not accept or support that contention. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has authorised the issuance of a selection of statements relating to the Queensland matter. I believe that Senator Ryan would be greatly assisted if she were to undertake a close study of them. I have arranged for them to be circulated to honourable senators and I table one of them for the elucidation and edification of the Senate. I now move:
That the business of the day be called on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I claim to have been gravely misrepresented by the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) during the debate and seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—The honourable senator may do so.

—I will not undertake the defence of others. I undertake only my own defence in this matter. The Minister indicated that members of parliament, including myself, had incited. I know that the Minister withdrew that statement as a result of my protest, but he gravely misrepresented my position and that of members of the Labor Party in this regard. It was well known that protests were going to take place during the Games. The Labor Party had a position on this- that the Games ought not to be interrupted and there ought to be no boycott. But we recognised the legitimate right of the Aboriginal people to protest during that time just as other people were protesting in support of particular points of view. We also recognised the right to support the protesters on this occasion .

SPEECH.PARA: Some members of parliament did not parade before the cameras what they were doing about those demonstrations. I am not in any way denigrating Senator Bonner 's role. He is an elder, a leading member of the Aboriginal race, and his role during that period is to be commended. But it ought not to be used in such a way as to denigrate others. The preparations for the rally on 26 September involved quite a deal of negotiation with the authorities in Queensland. That was done by the Labor Party members through me. In Queensland that involved an approach to the Commissioner of Police. I indicated that such a protest would take place and that I had been asked, on behalf of the black people, the tribal council, the black protest committee in Brisbane, to approach the Police Commissioner. I did that. I approached the Police Commissioner who subsequently introduced me to the superintendent of traffic. We made the necessary arrangements for a peaceful demonstration to take place on 26 September.

That was one role. That was not done openly because it is fairly clear that it was a black protest. The Aboriginal cause was properly supported by the Aboriginals and anyone who supported that, particularly white people, would need to take a background role. I am telling the Minister this because he has obviously been only partly informed. I will also tell the Minister that on the Friday that I returned from this Parliament I was told that certain arrangements for accommodation had fallen through; that the arrangements to provide accommodation and facilities for the black people arriving in Brisbane had been withdrawn. I was also told that the $20,000 which the Government and the Minister were supposed to provide had not been provided, and that the program for the black protest committee had fallen apart for that reason.

In fact, it was because of that neglect that subsequent events developed. What did members of parliament do in that situation? An approach was made to the police superintendent indicating that no accommodation was available and that tents would be erected in Musgrave Park. I approached the police superintendent and indicated that if his patrols saw such tents erected in Musgrave Park they should realise why those tents were erected. Subsequently, I rang the Deputy Lord Mayor of Brisbane and indicated to him the possibility that tents would go up in Musgrave Park; that he could not be asked for permission because regulations would prevent it but that he ought to be aware.

I mention all these things to make the Minister realise that there was no incitement on the part of members of parliament on either side. What we did, in our own way, was to prevent confrontation and to prevent incitement. When the Minister praises Senator Bonner-rightly so-he should realise also that members of this side of the House had a role to play to prevent confrontation and violence. When people were unnecessarily arrested on the first occasion, bail had to be found. Members of parliament were involved in collecting that bail in some way or form. I am aggrieved by what the Minister had to say and by the method in which he said it. He got up in this debate as though it were a debate- -

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, Senator Georges is making a personal explanation, saying that he was misrepresented. I think he has explained the misrepresentation. I wonder whether at this stage he is not proceeding beyond it.

—I am listening to Senator Georges's remarks with some care. He was aggrieved by the remarks made. I think that so far all his remarks have been in order. I will ask Senator Georges to wind up as soon as possible. He has made his point fairly clearly.

—I doubt that I have made it clearly in my mind. That is the real problem that you face, Mr Acting Deputy President. When you give a senator the call, that senator has the floor. That senator has a right under the Standing Orders. The Minister objects and says that I am now going beyond the explanation and debating it. I am not.
—You have the call, Senator Georges. I have said that you have not so far gone beyond it. I think the personal explanation should be of limited duration.

—I have indicated that the methods used by the Minister in the debate were very aggressive. Because they were so aggressive, especially against the shadow Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, they were also unjust. They were particularly unjust to those people who endeavoured to do as much as they could. That does not take away from the role of Senator Bonner. He had a particularly difficult role. Whereas the rest of us could stay in the background and do those things that may have been necessary, he had to make an appearance. I mention this to illustrate the contrast. The Minister made his misrepresentation by commending Senator Bonner, as he deserved, but then going on to say that other people, such as myself, misused the situation to incite and to develop confrontation. Nothing is further from the truth. Throughout the whole of that week no member of the Opposition did anything to incite confrontation. But we did understand the need of the Aboriginal people to discuss, to debate and to question. Finally having made a decision-despite Senator Bonner's plea-to break the law on this occasion, they did it only after considerable debate, after considerable thought and with a certain amount of regret. There was not one deliberate attempt at violence on the part of any Aborigine who took part in those demonstrations. They had a right to so do. They did it effectively. they did it to put across their message internationally. In spite of what Senator Peter Baume says, there is still much left to be achieved in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable senator claim to have been misrepresented by Senator Baume?

—Yes. During Senator Baume's defensive speech, he attempted to suggest-even though he subsequently made some concessions-that he believes that members of the Australian Labor Party who were invited to Queensland by the Aboriginal movement to participate in a legal march somehow or other acted in a provocative or confrontationist way. In that sense I believe he completely misunderstands the motivations of members of the Labor Party, including the shadow Minister for Aboriginal Affairs who led our contingent to the legal march , in our participation in that march. The Minister seemed to suggest that there was some element of flamboyance involved in that, and that we were not there subsequently when matters became more heated and got out of hand, and that this placed us in an inferior position in respect to the very difficult position that Senator Bonner had to face.

SPEECH.PARA: The facts are that there were at least a dozen members of the Australian Labor Party who were members of parliament who responded to the invitation and only one Government member. We went there in a sense of solidarity and of giving some moral support to the Aboriginal movement. I should have thought that all of us in this place would understand that the Aboriginal movement, for almost 200 years, has been downtrodden and placed in an inferior position in respect to Aboriginal rights to be accepted as citizens and in respect to the campaign for land rights. It is a pity that Senator Peter Baume would take the view that we went there with some ulterior motive and not for the purpose of assisting the Aboriginal movement which, as I understand it, has a unanimous position in respect of land rights. If the Minister accepts that Senator Bonner's motivation was one of assistance to that movement for land rights, he should similarly accept that in respect of the members of the Labor Party who were there.

We were there to advise and assist and to give moral backing to the Aboriginal movement for land rights. That movement will continue until every State government-Labor, Liberal or National Party-accepts its responsibilities in respect to land rights and grants equality of opportunity in respect to land rights and to the laws and procedures of our country. Therefore, it is a mistake on the part of the Government to suggest that members of the Opposition, quite a number of whom are on the front bench of our party, did not go there with the highest of ideals and with the idea of giving support and solidarity to the Aboriginal people. Other senators, such as Senator Georges and Senator Ryan, played a considerable part in assisting Senator Bonner's efforts to get the point across to the world Press, to the people of Queensland and to the people of Australia that the issue of land rights was justifiable. I believe that in all circumstances members of parliament who went there had those objectives in mind.

DEBATE.TITLE: PARLIAMENTARY ASSEMBLY OF THE COUNCIL OF EUROPE

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report of Australian Delegation

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe, 13 September to 8 October 1981.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report of Australian Delegation

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the official report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to Africa, July to August 1982.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The trip undertaken by the parliamentary delegation to Africa covered, on the African mainland, Nigeria, Ethiopia, Somalia, Kenya, Zimbabwe and Zambia. Many subjects came out of the study tour which it would be worth emphasising. Already, however, I have briefly dealt with the question of Namibia when speaking to the recent report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence on that subject. That Committee is now examining the subject of the Horn of Africa, and I shall deal with the particular problems of Ethiopia and Somalia in due course when that report is put down. I could speak on the importance of the current disunity within the Organisation of African Unity and its significance to Africa. I could also speak on the subject of whether the one-party States of Kenya and Zambia and the emerging one-party State of Zimbabwe can be consistent with democracy, as is their claim. I have, however, decided to address myself to the major problem of economic failure which the delegation witnessed and the potential political consequences of the worsening economic position, and to touch upon the contribution that Australia can make to economic stability in Africa. In doing so, I shall look at the four Commonwealth mainland countries that the delegation visited-Nigeria, Kenya, Zimbabwe and Zambia.

SPEECH.PARA: Nigeria, with a population of over 80 million, returned to civilian government in October 1979 to become the world's fourth largest democracy and ninth most populous country. Its international status is enhanced by the prominent role that it plays in the United Nations, the non-aligned movement and the Commonwealth. Its oil revenue gives it even greater recognition and membership of the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Add to this its leadership role in the OAU and it becomes clear that Nigeria is important both inside and outside Africa. But it is a country with major economic difficulties.

Nigeria, which once used to be a net exporter of foodstuffs to neighbouring African countries and a world rated producer and exporter of cocoa, ground nuts, cotton, rubber, palm oil, hides and skins, among other things, is now a major importer of the same. Agriculture, together with livestock, forestry and fishing , contributed about 61 per cent of the gross domestic product in 1962. By 1975- 76 this contribution had declined to under 23 per cent. In 1960 agricultural products constituted 80 per cent of the total value of exports; by 1970, 44 per cent; and by 1979 less than 7 per cent. In part this result reflects the poor performance of the agricultural sector. In part it also marks the spectacular growth of crude petroleum exports.

The dramatic change in the face of the economy from agriculture to oil led to accelerated distortion and dislocation. The oil boom threw the country's military leaders and their economic advisers into confusion. Active plans to diversify the economy, improve agriculture and establish agro-based industries were abandoned for prestigious and often unnecessary projects at grossly inflated prices. Nigeria opened its borders to the importation of all manner of goods, and the enhanced gains from oil sales were squandered. The construction boom drew workers from agriculture, corruption led to unplanned ordering of products such as cement, and port congestion followed. All added enormously to the cost of Nigeria's imports.

Then came the crushing blow of the oil glut which drastically reduced the nation's earnings at a time when the prices of other primary commodities were falling. At the same time, the prices of imported finished goods continued to rise. By 1978 inflation, which Nigeria had imported, was about 30 per cent, and in 1979 it was believed to be about 40 per cent. The consequence is not only major economic difficulty but also the inevitable pressure that it places upon the Government's stability. The delegation witnessed a strong commitment to democracy, the desire of Nigerians to make it work, and the recognition that the military experiment had so patently failed. But 13 of its 22 years of independence have been under military rule, and the potential for a return must remain if the civilian government is unable to meet the aspirations of its people.

Nigeria receives low aid priority from Australia. It looks to Australian expertise and experience in a number of areas, particularly finance, farming, transport and education. What appears to be particularly disappointing, however, is the failure of our trade relations. In 1980-81 Australian exports to Nigeria were just under $4m and imports were just over $1m. This can be compared with the fact that in 1978 Nigeria exported to France goods to the value of over 600 million naira, to Germany 600 million naira also, to Italy 200 million naira, to the Netherlands 900 million naira, to the United Kingdom over 400 million naira and to the United States of America over two and a half billion naira. This enabled imports from such countries as France in the sum of 600 million naira, Germany 1,150 million naira, Italy 550 million naira, Japan 870 million naira, the Netherlands 340 million naira, the United Kingdom 1,800 million naira and the United States of America 860 million naira.

Negotiations towards a bilateral trade agreement between Australia and Nigeria were shelved in 1979, and in the same year we withdrew our Australian trade representative from Lagos. Nigeria is now being served from Kenya. Even accepting the historical ties between Nigeria, the United Kingdom and other European suppliers, and the fact that they may be better placed geographically and that we have no direct shipping links with West Africa, it is my view that, from the point of view of Nigeria's high population and potentially strong economy-if plans to make it again self-sufficient in food by 1985 are successful -and if oil income can be stabilised, there must be a tremendous trading future for Australia in Nigeria. It would entrench our already strong political relations and in a most practical way contribute to the economic stability that will be necessary if democracy is to survive.

Kenya created an image of prosperity and stability since its independence in 1963 but is now also facing most difficult economic circumstances. In contrast with Nigeria it must import all its oil which in 1980 cost 40 per cent of its foreign exchange earnings-all the money that it earned from its principal exports of coffee and tea. In 1980 there were serious shortages of some foodstuffs, particularly maize, the staple food, wheat and milk. Large imports, some as food aid from the United States of America and other sources, were necessary. In fact 1981 was the third consecutive year in which Kenya had to import food. Apart from being hit from the substantial increases in the cost of oil, it is conversely affected by the 1978 crash in coffee prices. Additionally, the economy has been detrimentally affected by the failure of tourism to continue to expand at earlier rates, partly because of the growing international recession and rising air costs and partly because of a growing image of East African instability. The closure of the Kenyan-Tanzanian border in 1977 has not helped.

Britain had developed Kenya as the economic hub of East Africa. With the breakup of the East African community in 1977 its exports were dramatically affected. Problems are compounded by Kenya's population growth of 4 per cent, the highest in the world, by natural increase. A substantial annual gross national product increase is necessary to maintain even per capita income. The Kenyan economy is heavily dependent upon foreign trade. The major outlet continues to be Europe. However it has also been substantially assisted by large amounts of development aid. Almost half of the Government's development expenditure between 1974 and 1978 was expected in the form of aid. Sources of aid have diversified considerably in recent years. The share provided by the United Kingdom has fallen whilst that of the multilateral agencies and some European countries, notably, Germany, Sweden and the Netherlands, has increased.

The economic stresses have clearly played a part in the attempted coup which occurred just after the delegation officially left Kenya. It gives further evidence of the stress that will be placed even upon such show pieces as Kenya unless the economic crisis can be answered. In times of crisis the gaps that have been growing between the haves and the have nots appear to widen and racial intolerance increases. Many of the Indian shopkeepers bore the brunt of the looting that accompanied the recent attempted coup.

Clearly most Australians would also want to support democracy in Kenya and the question again arises as to what part, if any, Australia can play. In contrast to Nigeria, Kenya has had a high priority in Australia's development assistance effort in Africa. The Committee visited the Magarini settlement program which aims to settle 40,000 people on their own land and to improve agricultural techniques for farming in low rainfall areas. Clearly the scheme is making a small but worthwhile contribution to the food shortfall as well as the social welfare of the people involved. Whilst it is succeeding under close supervision, one must have reservations as to whether the success will continue when the supervisors return home. Involvement of the Kenyan Government authorities and regional authorities appears to be a sound policy. Our aid to Kenya in 1982 is approximately $5m.

Trade between Kenya and Australia is small but slowly growing. In 1981 we exported to Kenya goods to the value of $18.2m and imported goods to the value of $4.5m. Thus there is a significant imbalance. Kenya's exporters are eligible for preferential treatment under Australia's system of tariff preference for developing countries but as yet there has not been any great dividend shown. The regular shipping link between Australia and Kenya should contribute to strengthening trade relations.

Zimbabwe contrasts with Nigeria and Kenya as the most recent independent African State since April 1980 compared with the earlier oldest independent States I mentioned. The economic problems it faces have not therefore developed in the same way but rather out of years of sanctions and transport difficulties. A war costing a million dollars a day-37 per cent of the Budget-frightened off investors, is causing a continuing exodus of Europeans and the engagement of European manpower in military commitments. Thus the economic difficulties occasioned by the general world recession were exacerbated in the case of what was Rhodesia.

Conversely, sanctions have forced upon Rhodesia the need for greater self- sufficiency and with this has come the development of infrastructure and a more advanced industrial sector. Thus although the net economic performance at the coming of independence may not have been so impressive, the potential existed for growth that would in part depend on the ability of Prime Minister Mugabe's government to hold its white population, to attract foreign investment and secure World Bank and other loans. At the same time, to maintain internal stability Mugabe had to improve the living standards of the black population or in other words show that they would be materially better off as a result of their many years of struggle. It might be argued that in the shorter term the challenge provided a conflict of priorities.

Its first year of government was a great economic success which was assisted by excellent maize and tobacco crops, but even more significantly by #1,000m of foreign aid promised over three years at the Zimcord conference held in March 1981. However there has since been a marked slow down in economic growth. The euphoria has been replaced with a cautious pessimism. The season has not been good and the Government's somewhat clouded intentions on public ownership have deterred investment. Although there is some dispute over figures there appears to be a growing exodus of skilled whites. The need of Mugabe to satisfy the immediate aspirations of his people with land and income, education and health has also meant an emphasis away from economic development.

The position in Zimbabwe would therefore appear to be delicately balanced. In recent times there has been evidence of growing instability and again one can surmise that the re-emergence of Zimbabwe African Peoples' Union militance and increased banditry is linked to economic stress. Mugabe's answer principally appears to be to call for more aid but whether the Western world will continue to be so generous is questionable.

There can be no doubt that Australia, seen as a good friend of Zimbabwe, will be called upon to play its part in overcoming what appears to be a growing economic crisis. At independence we announced a grant of $5m for assistance over two years. In the last two years that sum has increased to a commitment of over $20m. Some of our aid has been expended in assisting with the cost of Australian teachers. From the observations of the delegation, that has been a tremendously successful program. Zimbabwe would like to see an extension of the scheme into other skills and if this could be facilitated it would clearly be a worthwhile contribution.

From the point of view of trade we have given Zimbabwe developing nation preference and have sent trade missions there. Whilst officially we state that trade will grow one cannot be immediately optimistic. The commencement of flights by Qantas Airways Ltd will add a new dimension but the success in relation to Australian tourists staying in Zimbabwe will largely depend upon internal stability. Prime Minister Mugabe was at pains to stress to us that internal stability will be maintained.

Zambia is another African country which achieved early independence in 1964. In the same way as Nigeria's economy is now dominated by oil, the Zambian economy is to an even greater extent reliant on one product-copper-with earnings running at about 97 per cent of total export earnings. Like Nigeria when prices were higher and Zambia was profiting, earnings were not always wisely spent. With a severe downturn in copper prices from 1976 the economy had to find itself in difficulty. In fact, the economic position in Zambia is now very serious with a non-convertible over-valued currency, price controls, commodity shortages, adverse balance of payments and payment arrears.

Zambia has fertile land and a benevolent climate and should be able to feed itself. There is now a concerted effort towards that objective. Unlike Kenya, the industrial marketing and services sectors are heavily dominated by quasi state companies and boards. With some exceptions they appear to be poorly managed, running at a loss and a net economic drain. The Government has indicated that there remains a role for private enterprise and has taken steps to encourage foreign investment. But to date these steps have not shown much success. In addition to economic problems resulting from the downturn in copper prices, Zambia has played a leading role in the struggle for liberation in southern Africa and has suffered as a direct result. To some extent it remains the home of the liberation movements. Clearly its contribution in the Rhodesian war detrimentally affected its economic performance.

Zambia sees the emphasis in recovery on aid rather than trade. Australia's assistance has not been great. In bilateral aid, the major spending is a development import grant scheme valued at $2m over three years commencing in 1981-82. Zambia is interested in drawing on Australia's expertise in rain-fed wheat cultivation. Bilateral trade is modest and largely in Australia's favour. Again, the economic stress leads to political vulnerability, even in the case of a leader so entrenched as President Kaunda. The President in fact acknowledged to us that coups and counter-coups in Africa are a way of life and the current economic stress will only add to the potential. Australia has warm relations with Zambia and again one must ask whether there is anything Australia can do to assist in stabilising Zambia's economic situation.

Although Nigeria is in west Africa, Kenya in east Africa and Zimbabwe and Zambia in southern Africa, all are exhibiting the same sign of severe economic stress. All have the potential and have in fact earlier been net exporters of food. All are now running the risk of political destabilisation from failure to meet economic aspirations. Each of the four countries has a plan and a strategy to increase food production. Each also has a program for returning the former agricultural community to the land. This has had the advantage of lessening one form of political stress; but on the other hand, the multitude of small holdings does not necessarily lead to the type of agricultural efficiency to which we are accustomed in Australia. To some extent, the delegation found that frustrating but recognised that African aspirations were not only for a better economic position but also in many cases for a small land holding. The delegation had to adjust to the concept that in such cases as the Magarini land settlement in Kenya, advancement was learning to use oxen for the first time as a step up from purely hand labour. In Nigeria, the highly regarded International Institute of Tropical Agriculture, which the delegation visited, had a program to develop implements simply to make hand labour less demanding. Therefore, implements were being developed not to advance from hand seeding but to enable the farmer to seed without having to bend over to the same extent.

The direction of economic recovery has to be acknowledged to be dependent upon the political philosophy of government. In Nigeria therefore, the need is trade and Nigeria would see its responsibility as trading out of its difficulties. Kenya has as its cornerstone of economic policy, the paper of Tom Mboya in 1964 on African socialism which described the encouragement of both state and private enterprise. However, capitalist markets forces tend to predominate. It will, however, attempt to overcome its economic difficulties through a state-private enterprise program not dissimilar to that of Australia. Zimbabwe appears to be having teething problems in direction. As the Prime Minister of Zimbabwe acknowledged to us, the objective is ultimate socialisation. But on the other hand, its policy is to encourage foreign investment. Investment guidelines have not, however, been set out and foreign investment has simply not come. The delegation evidenced a certain frustration on the part of the Zimbabwe Promotion Council in that regard. In Zambia, as I indicated, consistent with the political philosophy of its Government, the economy is very much state oriented. Both Zimbabwe and Zambia therefore appear to be looking to aid rather than to trade to relieve pressure in the immediate sense. Both find their economic reliance on South Africa as particularly frustrating and are looking to overcome that frustration. The development of the Southern African Co-ordination Conference is designed to that objective, and Australia is providing support.

Thus there is also a certain frustration for Australia. It has very warm relations with Kenya, Zimbabwe and Zambia and good relations with Nigeria. Within Australia's economic resources, however, its aid to Africa cannot be great. There may be grounds for greater assistance to Zambia and greater assistance temporarily to Kenya. Within the concept of the North-South dialogue a real and long-lasting advantage exists in increased trading capacity of the Third World. Aid, however, is not in any event the total answer. In trade, as I indicated, there is greater scope in Nigeria and, I believe, Kenya. The European trading nations are showing it to be so. Each of these African countries must determine its own direction and there must be an acknowledgment that small gains are worthwhile because in conjunction with economic change there is also substantial social evolution. Australia's response must be flexible, adaptable and sympathetic.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-As this was the second parliamentary delegation to visit Africa in three years, it would appear that parliamentary delegations to Africa will be more frequent in future then they have been in the past. I mention that because prior to the 1979 delegation it had been 12 years since a paraliamentary delegation had visited Africa. In future I would like to see delegations concentrating more on a particular region of Africa and spending more time in the countries visited than in trying to cover the whole continent in one visit. For example, I believe that a delegation should visit west Africa and include some of the former French African countries such as Senegal, the Ivory Coast or Gabon as well as countries such as Nigeria and Ghana which have Australian diplomatic representation. In east Africa a delegation could visit countries in the Horn of Africa as well as Kenya. It would have to visit Kenya if it were visiting the Horn of Africa because nearly all the air links throughout the region go through Nairobi. I think there are other itineraries in east Africa which could include countries where Australia has diplomatic representation, such as Kenya, Zambia, Zimbabwe and Tanzania as well as strategically important countries such as Mozambique and Mauritius. I would like to congratulate the Government for extending diplomatic recognition to Mozambique. That has been done only recently and it is something which I believe ought to have been done some time ago.

SPEECH.PARA: On this delegation I believe that we attempted to visit too many countries in too short a time. But because of the fact that in all the countries, with the exception of Nigeria and Mauritius, we were able to talk to the heads of state, this made even the briefest of the visits worthwhile. For example, even though the delegation was in Zambia for only 1 1/2 days the meetings with President Kaunda and the Zambian Minister for Foreign Affairs were extremely important and certainly made that visit a success. Unfortunately, due to a special meeting of the Federal Parliamentary Labor Party, the three Labor members of the delegation did not visit Nigeria or Somalia. Further, because of the coup attempt in Kenya on 31 July, I was not able to rejoin the delegation in Kenya as I had been making a private visit to Burundi and therefore missed the visit to Mauritius. I intend, therefore, to make some brief remarks about those countries that I was able to visit with the delegation.

In Kenya, the delegation visited the Magarini Land Settlement Scheme referred to by Senator Hill which is Australia's first major integrated rural project in Africa. The cost of the Scheme is estimated to be $21.6m shared by the two governments on an equal contribution basis. The delegation was impressed by the progress that has been made and we were pleased to see that current difficulties are being speedily resolved by the joint Australian-Kenyan review commission. The delegation was welcomed by President Moi who informed us that although at that stage Kenya had not made a decision to send a team to the Commonwealth Games, he was sure that a Kenyan team would participate, as it did. He also referred to the imbalance of trade between Australia and Kenya and hoped that this would be corrected in the future. He praised Australia's stand on Namibia and its opposition to apartheid.

Since independence in 1963 Kenya has been regarded as an example for other African countries as far as political stability and economic progress are concerned. Therefore, the attempted coup on 31 July by a group of Kenyan Air Force officers was received throughout Africa with dismay. It was not surprising , in my opinion, if one considers the problems faced by Kenya today. The economic problems facing the country are frightening. For example, as Senator Hill stated, last year Kenya spent between 35 per cent and 40 per cent of its foreign earnings on petroleum or petroleum products. The rise in oil prices has led also to a decline in tourism, which has compounded Kenya's economic problems . The estimated annual population growth of the country is nearly 4 per cent, one of the highest growth rates in the world, and this is coupled with expectations of the people there, which are probably amongst the highest in any country in Africa. There is no doubt that the attempted coup was a severe setback that will have wide-ranging consequences for a considerable time. Whilst the election of European and Asian members to the Parliament was a hopeful sign, the crackdown on political opposition to the Government, especially the treatment of people such as Odinga, and the pressure being put on the free Press are not hopeful signs for the future.

The High Commissioner and his staff at the Australian mission in Nairobi did everything possible to make the delegation's visit a success, and right throughout Africa we could not help being impressed by the professionalism of the respective Australian heads of mission and their staff.

The delegation visited Ethiopia. Perhaps the most important recommendation that comes out of the Committee's report concerning Ethiopia is that Australia should consider establishing a diplomatic post in that country. We realise that that would be a small post, but we have a three-person post operating in Zambia and we think it would be possible for a three or four-person post to operate at Addis Ababa. There are a number of reasons for this, the main one being that Addis Ababa is the headquarters of the Organisation of African Unity. The second most important reason is that there is great super-power rivalry in the Horn of Africa, and this is likely to continue, at least for the foreseeable future. There is also the whole question of food aid to refugees, and the claims of abuse of food aid in that country could be better looked after if Australia had a diplomatic mission there.

Although the delegation was in Ethiopia for only a very short time, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees made available his DC3 aircraft so that we were able to visit a number of centres in that country. First we visited Ginir, where Australia, as part of an aid program, has built silos. It was a quite impressive project, with extremely good agricultural potential. However, the delegation was concerned that the infrastructure seemed to be lacking and also that the machinery that is necessary for the project was in a state of disrepair. The delegation also visited a refugee camp at Jigiga, which is in the Ogaden region of Ethiopia. The refugees there are mainly ethnic Somalis. They all seem to be in reasonably good health and, as far as our delegation was concerned, there certainly did not seem to be any evidence of anyone starving in that region.

In a meeting with Chairman Menghistu, the delegation was able to discuss a number of issues, including the future of Eritrea. The Chairman asked us to extend our visit so that we could visit Eritrea and this ties in with the remarks I made earlier. I think on many occasions delegations try to fit in visits to too many countries and do not spend enough time in any particular one. It certainly would have been good for all of us and good for the Australian Parliament if we had been able to visit Eritrea. We also discussed the conflict that was taking place with Somalia and the future of the OAU. The Chairman indicated that he wished a delegation to visit Australia in the near future and described Australia's relations with Ethiopia as excellent. Whilst Ethiopia is described as a Marxist state and has been under strong pressure from the Soviet Union to set up a mass party on the Soviet model, it has so far refused to do so . My impression is that whilst the military officers who run the country describe themselves as Marxist, there is no evidence to suggest that they are trying to impose an East European type of communism on the people but instead are following their own brand of African socialism. I believe that Australia has a role to play in Ethiopia, and having a post there would certainly help us.

In Zimbabwe, unfortunately, the delegation's visit coincided with the kidnapping of a number of tourists, including Australians. In fact, two Australians are still missing, and this is a matter of great concern to all of us. However, I believe a completely wrong picture of Zimbabwe is being presented in the Australian media. Some areas of the country have still not been pacified. This is not surprising, given the fact that a civil war took place prior to independence and also given the fact that a tremendous amount of arms are still in the country as a result of that civil war. Visitors to Zimbabwe are informed of the areas where there are still difficulties and are told to avoid them. Unfortunately, the group of tourists to which I referred had crossed the border by truck and was in an area where many robberies and disturbances had recently taken place. Stories in Australia of this sort of thing happening in Harare, the capital of Zimbabwe, are nonsense and again are evidence of the bad reporting on Zimbabwe in the Australian media.

Ever since independence, Press reports have appeared in Australia that the country is on the edge of chaos or on the verge of collapse. Most of the articles, including the article in the Sydney Morning Herald last Saturday, are not attributed to any particular journalist. Others are attributed to people such as Peter Younghusband who, we were informed, gets his information on the telephone and writes the articles in Cape Town. Articles have also appeared in Australia saying that a brigade from the North Korean Army was occupying a key position in the armed forces. The truth is that the North Koreans were there as part of a military training scheme, just as Australia has military advisers in the country. The largest group of military advisers has always been, and still is, British. Most of the North Koreans have now left. The reason they were invited, as it was put to us, was because Zimbabwe is a non-aligned country. I particularly want to stress the role of the Australian media because, as mentioned by Senator Hill, Qantas Airways Ltd will commence its flights into Zimbabwe on 7 November. My impression is that tourism in Zimbabwe has a great potential and is increasing rapidly at the present time. I was pleased to have my impressions confirmed by Senator Missen, who has just recently returned from that country.

While I was in Zimbabwe, I took the opportunity to discuss the sort of Press publicity that I have referred to today with officials from the Australian High Commission, with Australian military advisers, with Australian school teachers and also, and I think very importantly, with white members of parliament who had split from Ian Smith's party. I am pleased to be able to say that they did not hold the gloomy predictions for the future of Zimbabwe that we have been fed in Australia. That is not to say that the country does not have some real problems economically. There has been a slump in world mineral prices and mining accounts for 5.2 per cent of the gross national product and employs 60,000 people. Agricultural exports are being hampered by the fact that the country is land- locked and that South Africa is actively supporting dissidents within Zimbabwe and also in Mozambique, and this subversion is making it extremely difficult for exports to reach the sea ports. The expectations of the people are very high indeed and the Government for political purposes has to provide schools, roads and bridges to rural communities, even though the cost to the community is extremely high. Again, we saw evidence of the school system being severely strained as thousands of black students receive education for the first time. Of course, this is a service that the Government of Prime Minister Mugabe had to provide.

Joshua Nkomo and his Soviet backers have obviously not accepted the results of the election and quite serious charges were levelled against his organisation by both the President and the Prime Minister when they met the delegation. They especially claimed that military equipment from the Soviet Union had been channelled to Nkomo's forces since independence, which is a very grave charge indeed. As was also stated by Senator Hill, the 160 Australian school teachers in Zimbabwe have an excellent reputation, a reputation which has spread to other countries in the region. I certainly hope that the Government will extend their term of contract. They are great ambassadors for Australia. I hope also that Zimbabwe will be able to establish a high commission or at least an information office in Australia as soon as possible.

The delegation was in Zambia for only a day and a half. However, as I said earlier, the visit was worth while because we were able to speak at length with President Kaunda and also with the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs. The delegation was very appreciative of the time given it by President Kaunda, especially as he was hosting a visit from President Nyerere of Tanzania during the time that we were there. As referred to earlier, Zambia played a leading role in independence struggles in Angola, in Zimbabwe and in Monzambique, and is also playing a key role in Namibia at the moment. It has paid a very high price indeed for its support of these independence struggles. We were able to talk with President Kaunda about the recent talks that he had with the South African Prime Minister, Mr Botha. President Kaunda said to the delegation that before the Labor Government came to power in Australia, Australia was seen as an ally of South Africa. The situation at present is that because of the role played by the Labor Government and also because of the very important role played by the present Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), Australia is now seen as an ally against South Africa and an ally against apartheid. He also spoke to us at length about the Commonwealth Games and said that in his opinion Australia should not be penalised by a boycott of the Games. In fact, such a boycott did not occur.

As Senator Hill said, the country is faced also with grave economic problems which are especially due to the decline in commodity prices and the cost of fuel . The delegation was informed that it is costing Zambia $US900 a tonne to produce copper and it is able to sell it for only approximately $US700 a tonne, with the result that the copper mining industry, which is perhaps the country's key industry, is stockpiling and not selling copper. Australia has a three- person post in Lusaka. The delegation considered that even though that is one of our smallest posts it is a success. However there was some feeling that perhaps the size of the post should be increased from three persons to four persons.

I made a private visit to Burundi. Burundi is a classic example of a landlocked , resource-poor nation that only now is beginning its development. It is one of Africa's smallest countries and until recently it had one of the bloodiest political histories of any country in Africa. However, recently, under the regime of President Bagaza, the country has undergone a remarkable transformation. Because of the time restrictions I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard an article from Newsweek of 1 March 1982 entitled 'Burundi's New Stability'. It spells out in detail the things to which I would have referred.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Burundi's New Stability

The tiny African state of Burundi's has never had much to boast about. Its economy is among the world's poorest while its population density rates amongst the highest. Burundi has seized international attention only twice in its 400- year history. In the 1940s it served as a backdrop for the Hollywood classic '' King Solomon's Mines.'' And in the early 1970s it staged one of the bloodiest tribal wars in modern African history in which 150,000 people were killed. But Burundi can now claim to be one of Africa's most stable nations. For a country once expected to follow neighboring Uganda down the road to perpetual bloodshed, the achievement is nothing short of extraordinary.

Burundi's turnaround has been largely the work of one man: Lt. Col. Jean- Baptiste Bagaza. When Bagaza seized power in 1976 in a bloodless coup, his striking good looks and tender age, 30, did little to inspire confidence. His advisers were also regarded as mediocre-hardly surprising for a nation that could not boast a single university graduate when it achieved independence from Belgium in 1962. But Bagaza learned quickly. He cornered diplomats at state dinners to discuss the virtues of fertilizer. Bagaza roamed the countryside in a Range Rover, chatting with the farmers to learn about agricultural problems. Within five years, says a Western diplomat in the capital city of Bujumbura, '' Bagaza developed into one of the most exciting leaders in Africa.''

The young President's strategy has included cautious efforts to repair relations between the perennially feuding Tutsi and Hutu tribes. While the bloodletting has stopped, the enmity remains. The Hutu tribe accounts for 84 percent of Burundi's 4 million people, but the Tutsi tribe still holds most of the land and the political power. Bagaza-a Tutsi-has tried to redistribute the country's meagre economic and political offerings. He has given jobs, Cabinet posts and schooling to Hutu tribesmen. His pace has been somewhat leisurely-but with good reason. ''If he moves too quickly,'' says a European diplomat, ''he will alarm the Tutsi elite and probably start another coup.''
