Bagaza's cautious efforts seem to be paying off: many Hutu who slipped out of Burundi during the atrocities of the 1970s are now returning home.

For all the good news, however, home remains a dismal place. Only 3 percent of Burundi's forests remain, and the soil is severely depleted-critical problems for a nation that is dependent on agriculture. Burundi's sole source of foreign currency is its coffee crop, an export highly vulnerable to volatile overseas market fluctuations. ''When the price of coffee falls on the world market,'' says Energy Minister Isidore Nyaboya, ''we simply halt capital projects.'' Even when the coffee market is healthy, Burundi's sizable economic problems are deeply entrenched. The landlocked country must move all imports and exports through surrounding states-an expensive and chancy business-to gain access to the sea. Increased trade will be imperative in the decades ahead, especially if the population doubles as expected. If an economic downturn should coincide with the anticipated population explosion, renewed ethnic strife could be one result.

Prudence: Bagaza believes the key to tribal peace is economic development. His discreet management of Burundi's slim holdings has enabled Burundi to quintuple its foreign aid. The United States is currently building a road from Bujumbura to the countryside to help farmers get their goods to market. The Chinese are building hydroelectric plants, the North Koreans are constructing a conference centre and the French are expanding Burundi's air-flight facilities. Says one Western aid official: ''We like doing business here because the government uses aid money prudently and well.''

The splashiest project is a multimillion dollar mosque in Bujumbura financed by Libya. Burundi has only a handful of native Muslims, but Muammar Kaddafi demanded that the mosque be built if Burundi wanted continued military aid from Libya. Eager to hold on to Libyan jeeps and radio-communications equipment, Bagaza agreed. He also insists that Burundi's Libyan connection is legitimate and he shrugs off Western complaints. ''Criticism of our relations is propaganda by Libya's enemies,'' insists Bagaza. ''That country has its revolution and we have ours.'' For now, Bagaza's primary concern is to keep Burundi's economy moving at such a rapid clip that the Hutu and Tutsi tribes won't have time to brood over their differences. If the strategy continues to prove successful, the long-overlooked African state may finally have something to boast about.

TALK.START.PARA: —I visited Burundi to look at a United States aid project, the preservation of the Bururi rain forest. It is costing more than $US1m over a four-year period. It is a very impressive project, part of a huge United States aid project to the country on a scale that could never be undertaken in Africa by a country like Australia. I was extremely well briefed while I was there by Mr Nyaboya, the Minister for Public Works, Energy and Mines, who I hope will be visiting Australia as a guest of the Government in the near future. I would also like to place on record my appreciation of the assistance I received from the Governor and officials of the Bururi province when I visited the project. The Government in Burundi has heard of the success of the Australian schoolteachers in Zimbabwe and has made a formal request for two Australian schoolteachers. I found this to be quite remarkable, given the lines of communication between these countries. It was some indication of the very good role played by these Australian schoolteachers.

SPEECH.PARA: The future of the country is economically tied to one issue, and that is whether there is oil beneath the African lakes. I was fortunate enough to be able to talk to some people from Western oil companies while I was in the country. They believe that Lake Tanganyika has a tremendous amount of oil beneath it. If that is correct, the future of central and east Africa certainly will be very different indeed.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL IMPACT OF URANIUM MINING ON THE ABORIGINES OF THE NORTHERN TERRITORY

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The report to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Wilson) on the social impact of uranium mining on the Aborigines of the Northern Territory, submitted by the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies, is another report in the six- monthly report cycle that the Senate has had the opportunity to discuss. I believe it is a particularly interesting report which raises a number of important issues. The issues that take up a fair amount of the report concern particularly the Nabarlek and Ranger operations. At present those operations are relatively small. The two approved projects, Jabiru and Jabiluka, are considerably larger, as is Koongarra, which is still under negotiation because it is located on a rather contentious site in the middle of the Kakadu National Park.

I wish to raise a specific question in relation to the Jabiluka operation. It concerns the workers at the site. At Nabarlek workers are flown in and then flown out. In that way the number of permanent residents can be kept to a bare minimum. As I understand it there has not yet been any firm decision in relation to Jabiluka. However, I do not think from the size of the operation that it is unreasonable to suggest that we would be looking at a permanent population in the vicinity of 7,000 or possibly 10,000 workers. The social impact on the Aboriginal people and their lifestyle can only be imagined. If we were to fly in 7,000 workers on a permanent basis when there are approximately 900 permanent Aboriginal residents close to the site, I believe we would have cause for concern. However, if it is decided to follow the Narbarlek idea and have a fly- in/fly-out operation then presumbly the number of permanent residents could be kept down to somewhere in the vicinity of 2,000 people. I believe that would be a preferable situation and I hope it is the intention of the developers of the Jabiluka project. Indeed, I hope it is the intention of the Northern Territory Government and the Commonwealth Government to apply whatever pressure they can to have the same type of arrangement at Jabiluka as has existed at Nabarlek.

The other issue I wish to raise relates to uranium mines as they operate in Australia in comparison with uranium mines in other parts of the world. I refer particularly to the problem we have at the Northern Territory mines of monsoonal rains. We have found already-there has been relatively extensive reporting of this-problems at both the Nabarlek and Ranger operations in terms of seepage from the tailings dams, particularly seepage into the water table with subsequent damage to the environment and possible long term effects spread over a much wider area through pollution of the water table. The particular problem that has been raised in regard to the monsoonal areas suggest that the continuation of the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies reports would be particularly useful not only up until 1983, which is when those studies are scheduled to end, but also well beyond that time to monitor the social and health consequences that will flow from those mines. I believe that the Government has a moral obligation in this regard since it did make an undertaking in relation to the report of the Fox Ranger Uranium Environmental Enquiry in August 1977 to permit uranium mining only if harmful effects on Aboriginals could be avoided. I believe that monitoring could very well assist.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS TARIFF BILL 1982CUSTOMS TARIFF (ANTI-DUMPING) AMENDMENT BILL 1982CUSTOMS TARIFF (MISCELLANEOUS AMENDMENTS) BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 September, on motion by Senator Messner:
That the Bills be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to discuss the present state of the Australian film industry. The film industry has been one of the dramatic cultural successes in Australia over the last decade. It has been received with acclaim round the world with remarks about our recent films such as 'maturity', 'intelligence', 'clarity', 'unique characteristics' or, as one English critic said about one of our films, 'exciting', 'subtle', 'beautifully made', ' beautifully photographed', 'superbly acted', 'extremely moving', and 'I would regard such a film as just about perfect'. The prominent English actor James Mason confessed last year that he was tremendously jealous of the Australian film industry. International recognition in other forms or awards and nominations for Oscars are beginning to come. Of course, not only feature films have been in the sensational new wave of films. Bruce Petty won an American Oscar in 1976 for the best animated film and documentaries such as The Last Tasmanian and Front Line have been winning widespread acclaim.

SPEECH.PARA: But the problem for the industry is that it seems to be in a sort of boom and bust cycle. The film tax concessions introduced in 1980 produced a great burst of investment in films but that has now dried up. Last year 33 feature films were made. This year it looks as though only six to eight will be made. This is a dramatic turnaround. I think we must examine what is going wrong and why the film tax concessions are not working as they were originally expected to do. I had some misgivings when these tax concessions were introduced. I said at that time that the only justification the Government can have for such large subsidies for the film industry is that they will raise the level of Australian film culture and the output of higher quality films. I pointed out that the problem is how one controls the quality; how does one stop large subsidies being used to make what can kindly be called rubbish films? Everyone knows that each year some films are produced which never should have been produced. The marketplace is not an appropriate vehicle for controlling such a heavily subsidised industry.

At the time the tax legislation was introduced I toyed with the idea of requiring that before any investment became tax deductible at least 10 per cent of the money put up should come from one or other of the film commissions-the Australian Film Commission or one of the State film commissions-because, after all, they are supposed to be aiming at quality. The trouble is that their track record, to put it at its kindest, is what one could term as ambiguous. I think we will now have to start looking at this because we must have some control over quality if we are to have substantial public investment in the form of tax support for the film industry. That is not the greatest problem but it is one that we really have to look at now.

The Treasurer (Mr Howard) said, when this legislation was introduced in 1981, that he would look at it again in six or 12 months to see that it was not going in the wrong direction. I think now is the time we should look at whether these tax concessions are working in the way we expected and, if not, why they are not working. The reason I say this is that the concessions are in fact very generous . I think most honourable senators are aware of what is given to film makers under Division 10BA of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Magnificent films such as Heat Wave, Puberty Blues, Star Struck and The Man from Snowy River have been made through tax concessions under Division 10BA of the Income Tax Assessment Act. That division provides that investors may have a tax deduction of 150 per cent on their investment. If they are on the highest marginal rate and they invest, say, $100,000 in a film that means they get a $100,000 investment for an actual expenditure of $10,000. If a return is made on a film, and by no means all films make returns, investors are exempt from income tax for the first 50 per cent of their investment.

These might appear to be, and they were seen to be at the time very generous concessions. Why then has investment in the film industry dried up so sharply? A number of reasons were apparent at the time and were put to the Treasurer, who did not feel able to meet these objections because he was then, as he is now, very concerned about the possibility of tax evasion and unscrupulous tax avoidance. In order to limit that he felt obliged to impose conditions which have caused problems for the film industry and problems for investment in films. The first of those is what the industry tends to call the '12-month rule'. The film makers are forced to mount, film, edit and get public release of a film within the same financial year. That imposes very great problems because within a financial year they are forced to complete a process that would normally take 16 to 20 months or more. It is not even that they have the full 12 months, because very few of the type of investors who go in for film making have any clear idea of what their investment potential or financial situation is going to be before about Christmas. They will not consider such investments until about that time. If they borrow the money they want to have it out for as short a time as possible. As a result, this reduces the film making season from 12 months to about 6 months which is really an impossible period in which to make good films. The industry is being forced into making tax avoidance quickies. Not all films can be placed in this category. However, there are too many of them and they do nothing for the level of film culture in Australia and are not a justified expenditure of public funds.

There is a further very serious problem. The new companies Act forces producers of films, like any other company, to issue a complex prospectus before they can attract film investment money. This really is an insuperable difficulty. It not only costs a great deal of money to issue such prospectuses but also takes time. The six-month film making time is further reduced by the requirements of preparing and issuing a prospectus. I think we must seriously look at whether it is appropriate and necessary for film producers to be forced to issue a prospectus as is any other company by the companies Act.

One other factor which has had a very serious effect on the film industry is the way in which the bunching of production has caused an overloading of available facilities and, as a result of the ordinary laws of supply and demand, a sharp increase in costs. Competition for the use of the available facilities shoots up the costs not only because of the competition but also because the season for film making is almost as brief as the ski season in a drought year. Investors have to get their returns over a very short season. Up go the costs again. One of the great qualities of Australian films used to be the way in which one produced first rate films at reasonable costs. These costs are now escalating.

We must look at how we can reorganise Division 10BA of the Income Tax Assessment Act to see that we provide for three things. The first would be high quality Australian films which would raise the level of film culture in the year ; the second would be to provide for efficient ways to stop a rip-off of the tax system through the film industry; and the third would be to avoid, through spreading production, the rapid escalation of costs.

One suggestion has been put forward which I think does deserve serious examination by the Government. At present the investment cannot be written off, the tax concession cannot be claimed, until the film has been exhibited-until its copyright has been obtained. That effectively means that it must all be done within a six month period. What is now suggested is that the investors should be allowed to write off their investment and claim it against their tax as soon as they have invested. Obviously this potentially opens the way for tax rip-offs by never producing the film. To overcome that problem it has been suggested that the film must be made and exhibited within two years. If it is not exhibited within two years, the tax concession is revoked and a penalty is imposed. Investors will not like penalties, but I think that they will like this system a lot more than the present system where we are making films that are tax saving quickies. I commend that approach to the Government. I believe the Government must look at it very carefully.

The other problem concerns the way in which section 51 (1) of the Income Tax Assessment Act is being used to obtain tax concessions which are of no benefit to the Australian film industry or to Australia. This is the tax deductibility allowed for in the ordinary business dealing. What happens is that a person invests in an Australian company's books-there are two companies involved in this-and then borrows money from overseas, say, $3 for every dollar invested. That person then puts the whole lot through the Australian company's books and claims an Australian tax deduction. An investor can get a 375 per cent tax write -off on his investment. There is no requirement, as there is in the Division 10BA tax deduction, that the film should be of significantly Australian content. There need be nothing Australian in these films. Films such as Arthur, which has nothing Australian in it at all, have been made under this arrangement. Other countries have faced up to this. Canada had this problem and has outlawed this type of investment in film industries. I think that we have to move very fast to stop this type of rip-off of the Australian taxpayer which has no benefit at all -or very few-from the point of view of the Australian film making industry.

There have been suggestions by one of the promoters of these schemes, United American and Australian Film Productions Pty Ltd, that it will build a studio complex in Canberra costing several million dollars. I believe that might well be erected alongside the silicon chip manufacturing complex in Canberra. I do not think that either has any likelihood of being built. We are being naive and gullible to be taken in by this sort of talk. The company will not build this studio complex. If it did build it, Canberra would not be the place to construct it. It would have to be in either Sydney or Melbourne if it intends to make any significant contribution to the film making industry. That is an area which we must look at very carefully. We should, as Canada has done, close this tax loophole now.

I do not suggest, as some film makers do, that if we close this loophole more money will come into the film industry. By blocking off the loophole, that does not mean that more money will go to the industry. People will invest in the film industry if the conditions are changed to make us produce better films. If we make better films there will be a better chance of a return for the investor because in times such as these investors are sensitive. If films do not make money the present Division 10BA is not an attractive investment. A film has to make money in order for it to be an attractive investment. The way to make money is to make more high quality films. This is not being encouraged under the present tax legislation. The proposed scheme is very generous and very well intentioned. Minor alterations must be made to ensure, firstly, that we have a thriving and highly artistic film industry, and, secondly, the Australian public gets full return for the concessions it made to this industry through the tax system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity of speaking at the first reading stage of the Customs Tariff Bill to refer to a matter which has already been the subject of some discussion this morning; that is, the situation of Zimbabwe and Australia's relationship with it. I have not yet had the chance to read the report, presented by Mr President on behalf of the parliamentary delegation that went to Zimbabwe. I have heard what I might call 'potted versions' from my colleagues of what has been said and what has also been said by Senator Hill and Senator Sibraa. I entirely agree with those remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps I can update that information, having spent some eight days in Zimbabwe since the delegation was there. I formed very firm conclusions on matters on which I had already tentatively formed views when I was in Harare earlier this year.

I believe it is relevant today that one should add one's impressions on this because we are constantly seeing in Australia a denigration by the media of the state of affairs in Zimbabwe. These reports are completely out of context; they attempt to raise problems and to highlight the difficulties which are inherent there. We all know that the missing six tourists have not been found. I saw in a report in the Herald of last night that they have been sighted again in Botswana . While I was in Harare the secretary to the Prime Minister, Mr Mugabe, told me it was believed they were probably in Botswana and not in Zimbabwe. That was the explanation for the lack of sighting for some period. It does seem to fit together. One hopes that the tourists are still alive and in due course will be returned to their families. This is one of the incidents which the Press in Australia has highlighted, but it does not highlight other significant and encouraging signs of progress which Zimbabwe is making under its very efficient and able Prime Minister, Robert Mugabe, and other Ministers, many of whom I have had the opportunity to meet.

It is important to put these matters into context. It is also important in this area of media distortion to remind ourselves of an editorial which appeared in today's Australian newspaper under the heading 'Self-evident humbug'. It did not mean to be so but the editorial is a piece of self-evident humbug in itself and is, therefore, well named. The editorial stated that Australians are having conflicting demands in a desire for lucre and a quest for moral purity. It criticises the fact that our trade with South Africa has increased and that we are now providing a Qantas Airways Ltd service to Zimbabwe. The editorial impliedly objects to the fact that Qantas does not fly to South Africa at the present time. I will not at present deal with the South African aspect of the matter; I intend to say a lot more in this Parliament in regard to our trade with South Africa and the extent to which there might be codes of conduct that would regulate that. I will have more to say in other speeches in this chamber about that matter. So far as the remarks which were made in this editorial about Zimbabwe are concerned, I regard the decision for Qantas flights to Zimbabwe to commence on 7 November as a matter of extreme importance and of great value for Australia and Zimbabwe. The Australian editorial can only state:
And Qantas flies to other countries whose regimes, in their own way, are at least as repulsive as that of South Africa.

They do not say this is Zimbabwe; presumably this is what is meant. In my opinion an excellent attempt is being made in Zimbabwe to run government properly. There is some talk of a one party state-which I hope will not come about-in Zimbabwe, but it has been a somewhat popular idea among African countries. To compare the viciousness of the regime in South Africa as this editorial does, and its failure to recognise the dangers it is in with the really great efforts which the Mugabe Government is making to put Zimbabwe on its proper feet economically is, I think, a quite monstrous piece of humbug.

What is objectionable is the attempt of South Africa to destabilise the government of Zimbabwe, the fact that South African troops have gone across the borders into that country. Some have been killed there, apparently in an attempt to destroy the railway service, which is one of the lifelines of Zimbabwe. Most of Zimbabwe's supplies to the world must at the moment go through South Africa. Indeed, South Africa stands condemned for the lack of foresight that it has shown in its dealings with Zimbabwe. Instead it ought to be encouraging a very strong development, both economically and otherwise, of that community.

I do not wish to deal today with the economic help that Australia has given, concerning which I spoke following my previous trip, or with the other actions taken by Australia, such as the sending of school teachers. I hope that we will be sending more school teachers because they are received with a great deal of satisfaction in Zimbabwe and are doing a great job. I want to speak particularly about the proposed Qantas service to Zimbabwe and what I believe is its major purpose. It is true that, in the first instance, it will cater mostly for people going on to South Africa, but I believe that the position may well soon turn around; that soon there will come an appreciation of the tremendous tourist possibilities for Australians in going to Zimbabwe and spending, on their way to Europe, a week or a fortnight there. In connection with the trip that my wife and I had, the question of danger was raised by some of my colleagues before we left. They urged that we not go. To my mind, we faced less danger during that trip than could be expected in Rome or London. In my opinion, one would be in less difficulty there than in many other places; there are many more dangerous places in the world.

One does not go at the moment to areas that are destabilised around Bulawayo. One does not travel that road as a tourist. On the other hand, one can travel very effectively around the country to the main tourist places by air. The tourist facilities are very effectively handled.

Zimbabwe offers tremendous tourist possibilities. They were known before the civil war and they are again becoming appreciated. Having gone down to Great Zimbabwe, to the magnificent and interesting ruins of a former civilisation, and to the game reserves both in that area and at Wankie, I can testify to the hospitality of the Zimbabwean people and the very high standard of hotel accommodation and other facilities in these areas. Victoria Falls, given the great deal of accommodation that is available there, presents such an experience that I believe within a very short period thousands of Australians will be taking the opportunity to fly direct to Zimbabwe and then go on to Europe and other places. They should put aside the fears that some newspapers have tended to exploit and take an early opportunity of visiting Zimbabwe.

The first flight from Australia will occur soon. I hope that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) or a leading Minister will be on it. The people and leaders of Zimbabwe are anxious that the Prime Minister should take up the long-standing invitation to visit their country. He is held in very high respect by Zimbabwean leaders, who appreciate the work he did in solving problems associated with Zimbabwean independence. As far as Zimbabwe is concerned, Australia has other things going for it also. We are very fortunate in having in Zimbabwe our High Commissioner, Jeremy Hearder and his wife Raye, both of whom speak excellent Shona. I understand that he is the only foreign representative Minister or High Commissioner who can do so. He can broadcast in that language. It is obvious when one sees the contact that he has with leaders, that his ability and interest are appreciated greatly by the Zimbabwean people.

I had the opportunity of attending the party that was given to Mr Mugabe when the freedom of the City of Harare was conferred upon him and of hearing the delightful speech he made on that occasion. Very real warmth was expressed by the Zimbabwean people both for him and for other guests present. One could sense the very evident pride they felt for their leaders in that they were doing so well. When one meets Ministers and other leaders in Zimbabwe one realises that they possess a considerable depth of talent and ability. I believe that they will overcome their problems, which include the 'Marxist rhetoric' in which some of them are caught up. I do not believe that marxism is really being applied in government, but it tends to frighten some businessmen and has perhaps frightened some of the white ex-Rhodesians who have left the country. One finds that some of those former citizens now are almost anxious that Zimbabwe should fail, that they should be shown to have been justified in making what was, I believe, the regrettable decision to leave that country and not help it during its establishment of independence. I believe that there is a need for more trained people and that people will be coming to Zimbabwe. I have already met migrants from Britain who have arrived since independence and I believe that the trend will become more marked as time goes on.

I wanted particularly to say something in an effort, firstly, to overcome the campaign of denigration the Australian media has waged-to quite an extent-in regard to Zimbabwe, and to point out that that country has a tremendous tourist potential. That is one way in which Australian citizens travelling abroad can help greatly. Certainly, as a result of six tourists having been captured, there has been some cancellation of bookings, some fear and trepidation, but I believe that Australians, who are doughty warriors when it comes to travelling, will find great opportunities to enjoy a marvellous experience in Zimbabwe. I believe that that fits well the aims the Australian Government has pursued for some time .

I have returned with other suggestions about which I will not go into detail but which I will be discussing with the Prime Minister when he returns. They relate to relatively small and uncostly ways in which we can further assist Zimbabwe and help our relationship with that country. It is the duty of all of us who have an interest in seeing that Zimbabwe is successful economically, also in a tourist sense and as a healthy democracy in Africa. We must realise that the people who are working there with dedication and skill to make a success of independence really need our help. They are entitled to expect our assistance and I hope that Australians will make every effort to assist, and to see, this glorious country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish this afternoon to deal with a matter concerning the education of students in Australia but would first commend Senator Missen upon the contribution he has just made and ask, if he would not mind, to be associated with the sentiments he has expressed. As honourable senators will recall, I was one of those who were privileged to go to Zimbabwe to observe that the elections there were freely and fairly conducted. We formed the same sort of friendships that obviously Senator Missen has formed.

SPEECH.PARA: The topic with which I would like to deal briefly this afternoon is the education in Australia of what we might call foreign students. I hesitate to use the word 'foreign' although that is actually the legal situation. I want to talk about students from our northern neighbour countries; people from Malaysia, Singapore and so on.

I will give just a little background to the comments that I am going to make. We know that the Asian universities find a great deal of difficulty in coping with the numbers of students who present themselves to be enrolled. We know also that some tertiary institutions discriminate against some nationalities. We have been advised that what we might call non-indigenous students have to obtain higher marks to qualify for entrance. For example, we know that in Malaysia people of Chinese background have to get 30 per cent more either to gain entrance to a tertiary institution or, for that matter, to qualify for the civil service as it is called there.

Another factor which has an effect is that Australia is reluctant-in fact more than reluctant; it will not enrol students from overseas if a course is available in the country of origin of the person applying. Here no discrimination is made in terms of whether any places are available in the course, but simply that the course is available in their country of origin. Another factor which has an effect is that we have excess capacity in our universities and other tertiary institutions in Australia. The final factor, which is relevant here, is that some ethnic groups, particularly the Chinese, undertake responsibility for the education of selected relatives and do so regardless of where this education is undertaken.

I should like to take a case that was brought to my notice in Darwin to illustrate what I am saying. A young woman from Singapore, 21 years of age, is the niece of a Darwin resident. The Darwin resident was Chinese and is now an Australian national, married to an Australian. The woman concerned from Singapore did not meet the requirements of the university in Singapore but she does meet the requirements of the Darwin Community College. I have a letter which was given to me in which the Assistant Registrar states:
I am pleased to advise you that you qualify for admission to our Bachelor of Business (Accounting) course.

If you are serious in your intention to study at Darwin in 1982, you should now approach the Australian Embassy in Singapore with a view to obtaining a student visa. If you are successful in your application for a visa, you should forward to me documentary evidence of your visa details, at which point I will be able to formally offer you admission to the programme.

Let me say that this implies no criticism of the Darwin Community College in the fact that they will enrol this girl. There is no suggestion that the standards are lower; rather there are not the same numbers to cope with in the Northern Territory as there are in Singapore. In this case the aunt is prepared to accommodate the girl, to pay all the expenses associated with her education, and to provide the family atmosphere-for want of another phrase-for the girl to live in. In other words, it would satisfy the girl's parents that there will be-I hesitate to use the word 'supervision'-some oversight of her activities in Australia. She wants to provide this in Darwin but will do it in the United States if necessary. So we have a situation in which the aunt is prepared to pay all the costs involved to provide accommodation for the girl or to pay for accommodation. The girl will do the course in Darwin if she is allowed to do so but is prepared to do it in the United States, where she also qualifies for entry to a tertiary institution. The Australian High Commission wrote to the aunt in these terms:
I refer to your letter dated 30 August 1982 regarding the entry to Australia in 1983 of . . . for study purposes.
I will not quote the name. The letter continues:
Due to the large number of applications selection standard for 1983 entry were tightened. Miss . . . did not meet the minimum requirement, consequently her application was unsuccessful.

I cannot understand the refusal in this case. The Darwin Community College will accept the girl. I cannot understand what the Australian High Commission means when it says that she did not meet the minimum requirements. What requirements are we talking about? The only requirements should be that she is able to come to Australia at no cost to the Australian Government and that she does not pose a health hazard. Certainly that was no problem because a health certificate was available. The aunt will cover all costs involved and the girl will return to Singapore after she has completed her three-year course.

Let us look at some of the advantages of educating the girl in Australia. Firstly, the money will stay in Australia. Those of us who come from the north- although I am sure that places like Melbourne and Sydney have the same situation -see thousands, if not millions, of dollars moving out of Australia to overseas countries either to educate or to support selected relatives. This is the case in Darwin, particularly with the Chinese community, where people of Timorese or Chinese ethnic background support their relatives who remain in the country of residence-in Macau and in other places. Mr Acting Deputy President, you will know that this is the case from your committee inquiries. We do not want to see that money moving out of Australia.

The second advantage that I see is that a potential bond will be established if the girl comes here. I do not want to go into the goals of the Colombo Plan here but I will mention them later. The potential bond that the girl could make as one who has committed herself to Australia would be established once more between Australia and Singapore. It has been made quite clear that the Community College has a place for her. That place would be filled and there would be interaction between this Chinese student and the other students in that course. As I indicated earlier, the girl would have a good home and some supervision. Another factor would be that an Australian national, who has asked for something which seems to be fairly reasonable, would go away satisfied. To me, this is very important.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you will let me have the details later, I will see whether I can follow up its particularity. I am very interested.

—I will give you the details later. Thank you very much for that offer. What could be the possible objections to this? Firstly, some people might say that it could cost the Australian taxpayer some money. I do not see how. I cannot see how it would cost the Australian taxpayer anything. But if it does, let us think in terms of charging students. I do not want to go into a philosophical discussion of whether people who come to our shores should be charged. But this could be discussed and, if this is an objection, then let us look at the possibility of the aunt paying for the cost of the education. My view-I have put it in the chamber on a number of occasions-is that we ought to sell our educational services. We ought to create institutions, particularly where I come from, where we can offer educational services to the people of the north.

SPEECH.PARA: A possible second objection would be that it would keep an Australian student out, would deny an Australian student a place at the Community College. Let me assure the Senate that this is not so. It is quite clear from the letter that a place is available, that the person meets the requirements and that the College would be quite happy to have her there.

A third possible objection is that the girl, at the conclusion of her education , would not return home. I have an assurance from the sponsor that certainly the girl would return home to do the job for which she would have been trained. Of course, as we all know, a written assurance that the student will return is required before a student visa is issued. It is pointless for the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to say that there have been cases where people have not returned home. That is insufficient evidence to deny one person the opportunity of coming here. We cannot apply this sort of blanket situation and say: 'Well, somebody broke the rules so we must not allow anybody in'. It is very difficult to police these things but proper policing can be arranged.

I am suggesting more flexibility and more recognition of the credibility of the applicant and of the sponsor. I do not have to go into details of the character of the aunt in Darwin who wants to sponsor this girl, but I could do so and I would certainly have no hesitation in doing so. I think that we ought to give some more thought to the selling of educational services as one more way of bringing money into the community and making use of the multiplier effect of which the Government speaks. It tends to speak of it only when it is talking about the mining industry. It is certainly not of the same quantum but it would bring money into the community.

The Northern Territory wants a university. I would support a university if it were set up to cover some specialised area not presently covered by a university in Australia. I cannot make a suggestion-no doubt Dr Jim Eedle would give us a lead-on whether it be tropical agriculture, tropical medicine or something in the tropical area that is not being covered at present. I am hopeful that we will look towards selling education to our Asian neighbours with the idea, through our university, of cementing bonds with those countries. I would support it if we were to provide training where none is available at present to meet the needs of the community.

As a final point, I would be happy to support the university if the money coming in from overseas helped to pay the bills for what the university will cost us both in the Northern Territory and here on the Federal scene. I believe that sufficient safeguards exist. I should like to see a response to this case. I am very grateful that the Minister at the table, Senator Sir John Carrick, has asked for the details. I shall provide them to him today. I should like to see some reaction from the Government to soaking up our excess capacity in the universities, bringing money into the community, and developing the goals of the Columbo Plan, which scheme was, in many aspects, highly successful when it operated in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity of presenting to the Senate a series of questions, which are fairly lengthy and which, according to the forms, traditions and Standing Orders of the Senate, cannot be asked at Question Time and cannot be put on the Notice Paper in the form of a question. If the Senate is to be a House of review and if it is to look critically at legislation in an era in which Bills are becoming more complex and more technical, we must be given the opportunity of placing some practical examples before this House and seeing how legislation will apply. For that reason I shall later seek the incorporation in Hansard of the balance sheets of four distinctively separate and unrelated companies, each of whose balance sheets must be looked at in complete isolation, in relation to a matter which is before Parliament and which is due to come into this chamber in the next week or so.

SPEECH.PARA: Some may say that the opportunity is available in the Committee stage or after the second reading speech. However, because of the complexity and the fact that sometimes these matters go through this House in a matter of hours, or in an afternoon, there would be insufficient time for the Government's advisers to provide an accurate and detailed answer. I mentioned that the opportunities are not available at Question Time or through notice because of the detailed nature of the matters at hand. I shall call these companies Nos 1, 2, 3 and 4. At this stage I point out that I do not want to debate the merits or demerits of the matters but simply to provide the Government with an opportunity to examine the matters and come up with answers prior to the time at which we shall debate this matter at the second reading or Committee stage.

Companies 1 and 2 have provided for all income taxes currently accrued up to the date of sales. These taxes were passed on to the purchaser, thus giving the vendor shareholders no benefit in terms of primary taxes payable only. These have been regarded in the past as usual business transactions. However, companies 3 and 4 took into account no accrued income tax liabilities, and obviously the vendor shareholders in these companies received a benefit equal to the unprovided primary income tax payable. Such share sales therefore, in my view, would be naturally suspect as abnormal transactions.

Therefore, in relation to this series of companies, the balance sheets of which I am about to incorporate into Hansard, I ask whether the Minister, at the appropriate time-not now-could outline the nature and extent of the liabilities for tax and penalties of the company, the vendor shareholders, and the promoters . I seek leave to incorporate the balance sheets in Hansard rather than reading out the detailed figures, because I believe that this will give the Senate and the outside community an opportunity, without having to pay an outside service such as Commerce Clearing House Australia Limited, of understanding what we are intending in a practical way by putting legislation through this House. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise two matters: Firstly, the limited or loaded terms of reference for Mr Von Doussa's inquiry into Mr Horgan's affairs, as detailed in the Press release by the Acting Attorney- General (Mr N. A. Brown) of 11 October; secondly, the earlier suggestion that Mr Costigan be asked to conduct the inquiry, a matter about which the Government has, at the very least, substantially fudged the truth. The Acting Attorney- General's statement of 11 October does not stipulate the investigator's powers to secure documents, if any. It does not state whether the investigator will have access to bank records, or whether the investigator will have access to tax records-although the worth of those tax records must, in the circumstances, be open so to some doubt. It does not state whether evidence will be taken on oath, or, indeed, taken at all. The statement says:

SPEECH.PARA: The terms of reference for Mr Von Doussa's inquiry are to inquire into transactions involving the sale of companies in which Mr Horgan was involved with a view to determining whether any action of Mr Horgan's in respect of those transactions was illegal, dishonest or a conflict of private interest and public duty.

I stress that there are only three grounds on which Mr Horgan could conceivably be found guilty. First, are the actions illegal? Queen's Counsel are already on the record disagreeing about whether wet Slutzkins were illegal, at least up until December 1980. 'Dishonest' in this context presumably means the theft of money, since the whole investigation is about money matters. It would be very difficult, if not impossible, to get convictions on those grounds unless conviction could already be obtained on the previous ground of illegality. The third ground is conflict of private interest and public duty. To convict on that third ground would require showing that Mr Horgan allowed private interests to influence his actions and judgments on one or all of the seven government bodies on which he holds positions in a way which was or could have been prejudicial to the interests of those public bodies.

Mr Horgan has never been accused of doing that. He has been accused of contriving his affairs in a way which reduced the tax revenue which would otherwise have been paid to the Commonwealth. The inquiry's terms of reference ignore that central issue. They do not require an answer to this question: How much tax was evaded or avoided by Mr Horgan's company sales? The terms of reference are contrived to avoid that question. The terms of reference are loaded. Mr Horgan has been accused of being a director of at least seven companies sold to the Maher organisation, all of which finished up with sham directors, some of them being registered painters and dockers. That fact of the painters and dockers is significant in relation to Mr Costigan, and I shall return to it later. Mr Horgan was shown to be a director of two companies sold to the Wynyard organisation under similar circumstances. Irrefutable evidence has been tabled and incorporated in this Parliament to prove all of those allegations. The McCabe-Lafranchi report has shown that at least one of those companies, Treamog Ltd, had a current year profit of nearly $4m on which company tax was never paid. That at least was a wet Slutzkin. I stress that that was identified not by the Labor Party in this Parliament but by the McCabe-Lafranchi investigation.

Apologists for this Government and its cronies describe the exposure and documentation of these matters as smearing. They add that it has all been done under parliamentary privilege. That is untrue. I put out 12 statements in June and July when the Parliament was not sitting in reference to Treamog Ltd. On 24 September the Sydney Morning Herald had the headline on its front page 'How Horgan company avoided $7m in 5 Years' and it went on to supply the details and the arrangements which were made to achieve that fortunate result for Mr Horgan. That was not privileged. If the Von Doussa inquiry is to have any credibility it must be extended to cover the revenue effects of Mr Horgan's dealings with Maher and others. Explicitly it must determine whether Mr Horgan will be affected by the recoupment legislation currently before the Parliament. But just as the Reid inquiry excluded examination of dry Slutzkins, this bogus loaded inquiry also evades the crucial questions.

I turn now to Mr Costigan. On 22 September the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) said that he believed Mr Costigan-I use the Prime Minister's words-' should undertake this particular investigation'. On 23 September in the unprecedented move of a joint statement from the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and Mr Horgan, issued by the Treasurer and for which he must take responsibility, it was stated: Initially it was suggested that Royal Commissioner Costigan may undertake the inquiry but it has now been determined that he is not available. The Treasurer said that it has now been determined that Mr Costigan is not available. That statement, if not blatantly untrue, was highly misleading. It was shown to be misleading by the Treasurer's reply in the House of Representatives today to a question from Mr Duffy about which more will be said later. That it was untrue was first suggested by the National Times issued on 26 September. It stated that Mr Costigan had definitely agreed to conduct the inquiry.

On 12 October I asked Senator Sir John Carrick whether the Prime Minister had asked Mr Costigan to conduct the inquiry and, if so, what was Mr Costigan's reply. In his usual way he obfuscated and prevaricated. He implied that Mr Costigan had refused but said that he would get details from the Prime Minister and tell the Senate. He did not give details that day. The next day, by which time the Prime Minister had left the country, he was reminded of his promise. His evasive response was that he said that he would get the information but he did not say when. I suggest that he deliberately avoided asking the Prime Minister because he either knew, or was afraid of, the answer, assuming that it would be truthful. Today, following a question to the Treasurer, which the Treasurer could not under the circumstances entirely dodge, the answer of the Treasurer was summarised, I believe not particularly accurately, by Senator Sir John Carrick in the Senate at the end of Question Time.

I turn to the Treasurer's answer. The question was very similar to the one which I had put previously, namely: 'Why was Mr Costigan not conducting the inquiry as had earlier been suggested?' The Treasurer said:

Sometimes one's recollections can be faulty. To my recollection, the discussion occurred between either the Minister for Administrative Services or Sir Peter Lawler or another senior officer of his department and the Royal Commissioner.

What an imprecise answer! The Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman), the head of the Department or some other officer discussed a question which had first been asked in the Parliament two days before and which was a matter of crucial importance to this Government's credibility. I draw attention to the imprecision of the answer. The Treasurer continued:

The situation very simply was that Mr Commissioner Costigan was not available to do the type of inquiry the Government wanted because he was willing to do it only in his capacity as the Royal Commissioner inquiring into the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union's activities.

From the statement made on the 23 September when it was determined that Mr Costigan was not available we have the contradiction that Mr Costigan was available but that he was not available under the terms which were acceptable to this Government. The Treasurer continued:

The Government quite properly in my view took the attitude that having an inquiry by a commissioner acting in that capacity in respect of the circumstances surrounding the allegations against Mr Horgan that have been made in this place was quite inappropriate.

The allegations against Mr Horgan which were made in this place have been supported by documents showing details of nine companies of which Mr Horgan was a director and which were sold to Maher and other dealer promoters. All of those nine companies finished on the bottom of the harbour. At least two of them had a registered painter and docker as a director. All of them finished with directors who are now colloquially known as painter and docker directors. The other names in those documents which we have tabled in Parliament and incorporated in Hansard are repeated almost ad infinitum in the Costigan report. It was within Mr Costigan's existing terms of reference to investigate the Horgan case because of the very close association with painter and docker names and activities. It was entirely logical that he should do so. Today the Treasurer has admitted that Mr Costigan was willing to conduct the inquiry, exposing in the process a lengthy trail of disinformation laid by him and other Ministers.

The truth is that Mr Costigan was stopped by this Government from doing the investigation. Costigan was vetoed because the Government feared he would do a thorough job. The Government feared that Costigan would answer the crucial questions, whether or not they were explicitly asked in the terms of reference, about how much revenue was lost by Mr Horgan's contrived actions and whether Mr Horgan would be affected by the recoupment legislation provided he was given access to all the relevant documents. Instead the Government chose to load the terms of reference with the deliberate intention of producing a not guilty verdict. As long as the terms of reference were interpreted in the legalistic nitpicking manner for which the legal profession in general has recently become notorious, the Government may not have been able to select the lawyer to conduct the inquiry. But with loaded terms of reference and even a random selection from the law society there is an excellent chance that the essential questions which ought to be addressed would not be addressed.

The Prime Minister nominated Mr Costigan off the top of his head in a careless moment. The rest of the Cabinet vetoed Mr Costigan. The Treasurer tried to cover up the facts with a highly misleading, if not outright untrue, statement on 23 September. Other Ministers, including most recently Senator Sir John Carrick, have joined in the attempt to cover up and deceive the public about the true nature of the suggestion that Mr Costigan should inquire into this matter. The Government yet again in this instance has dug in behind tax evaders and tax evasion and it nearly got away with it.

—We understand that. I do not think that I need to start an argument about the matter. I want to use my time to draw the attention of the chamber and the public generally to misspending in North Queensland of what is, in fact, taxpayers' money.

SPEECH.PARA: Many honourable senators would be aware that the area in which I live, Townsville, is a very marginal seat in the Federal division of Herbert. Prior to the last Federal election, this Government spent very large sums of money in establishing an international airport at Townsville. Even that was a political move right from the start because an across-the-board committee had been established to plan for the future together with a good working committee largely based on expertise from the James Cook University. At the appropriate political time that committee was wiped out of existence, mostly with the aid of the National Party. That party was largely responsible for it. Then a new National Party committee was set up to run the airport planning. That particular committee was able to achieve some considerable notoriety when, from out of the blue, an announcement was made that the international airport would be placed at Townsville. At the moment that international airport is one of the jokes of north Queensland, if not of Australia, because of the lack of money to develop it properly. When the small jumbos come in there they back and fill for about 15 minutes before they can even turn around. I hope that in this economic and political climate we will not spend a lot more money on something and then only half do it. Even the construction of that airport is contrary to the recommendations of the Bureau of Transport Economics. I am not knocking the airport by any means because there is a place for it and it could be properly utilised. But we need money to develop it properly.

When the razor gang was stalking this country it made many recommendations which have cost this Government and the taxpayers of Australia many millions of dollars. I want to point to one facility which we had worked for years to establish in Townsville and which was eliminated progressively over the last 12 months, ever since the razor gang made its recommendations. I refer to the North Queensland Branch of the Australian Archives. We had no repository of an orderly nature-I am excluding places such as James Cook University and other institutions that preserve papers, books and many other things of historical value-for such records. The establishment of a branch of the Archives was something that we had looked forward to for years. We had hoped that not only would it be allowed to continue but also it would develop and expand.

For the record, I will very briefly give the history and then point out where this Government has been responsible for the misspending of about $70,000 and the virtual closing down of the Australian Archives, North Queensland Branch. The Archives opened in what was virtually a broom cupboard in the old Commonwealth buildings on 25 February 1974, during the days of the Labor Government. Incidentally, we have long planned the construction of a new Australian Government Centre which has been deferred in every successive Budget over the life of the last two parliaments. We had hoped that it would be included in the 1982-83 Budget. The only way we are going to get it now is if the Government, in a moment of panic, decides that it needs to put something else of a Commonwealth nature in the federal division of Herbert in a vain hope to try to save that seat for the incumbent Liberal Party member. If that is done , I will make some suggestions in relation to the provision of more space to re- establish properly the Australian Archives.

In 1975, the then relevant Minister, Doug McClelland, inspected the Archives and promised that immediate action would be taken to upgrade the tiny establishment we then had. Unfortunately, on 11 November 1975, the Government disappeared and the incoming government decided to abolish the Archives for all practical purposes. However, after some pressure the operation was resumed and on 25 February 1977 the go-ahead was obtained to establish a proper branch office of the Australian Archives. At approximately the same time, on 4 July 1977, the office opened in the new building in Sturt Street and a storeroom and a repository at Casey Street, Aitkenvale, were established. Furniture ordered came in in bits and pieces. It started to arrive in early 1978. In mid-1979, staffing took place. One Clerical Assistant, Grade 4, and two Clerical Assistants, Grade 2, were appointed, and a labourer/ driver was also engaged. That has basically been about the size of the staff, excluding the officer in charge, over the period the office operated and, I think, operated very effectively. But when the razor gang arrived, without any examination of what was going to happen, the representatives just said: 'Well, we're closing you down. Thanks, see you later'. And away they went. No proper inspection was carried out and nor did the representatives examine the relevant needs of the local branch of the Australian Archives or anything else. They just said: 'You are closing down, and that's it'. The shopfront establishment in Sturt Street was subsequently dismantled.

I will give honourable senators an idea of the cost of the Sturt Street premises. It is an excellent concrete building and was mostly properly fitted out, depending on the amount of money available. The monthly rental was about $1 ,000. The cost of electricity to run the building, including air conditioning, was about $45 a month. The cost of the patrol service for safety and security was about $145 a month. Because the building was in good order virtually no money at all needed to be spent on maintenance. But the matter went further than that because of the amount of money that was necessary to shift to the other premises. I refer now to the Casey Street premises. First of all, they needed modification and about $70,000 to move to the outer suburb, to a place where nobody could find it, in a back street. It meant a total upgrading including new partitioning, adjustments to the mezannine floor and a modification of the sprinkler fitting system, to take the extra storage and so on. The sum total of that-incidentally, I have already cited the figures for the cost of the Sturt Street building-was around $70,000; that is, to do the adjustment and virtually to wipe out a branch of the Archives in the far north, the only one that has ever been there. But one should also look at the total annual cost of keeping that shopfront in Sturt Street. The money expended on the shift alone, to move the headquarters to the outer suburb, would have kept the Sturt Street office for certainly another four years.

When the Australian Government Centre is completed the current plan is to provide for a very small space for the Australian Archives, North Queensland Branch, in the new building. I hope that if this Government decides to do something, whether there is an election in the next few weeks or early next year or whether the Prime Minister has enough courage to allow the Parliament to run its full term, included in that policy will be a decision to set aside some money before the election to start the construction of the Australian Government Centre and that there will be discussions with the people associated with archives, particularly at the national level, to see that there is properly planned spacing. In the shift from one place to another, this meant an elimination of certain members of the staff who, of course, went on to the unemployed list.
The objectives of establishing archives can be briefly spelt out in these few sentences.
Provide a service to Commonwealth Departments by efficient records management.
Provision of low cost storage for records not required for daily or regular use by Departments.
Preservation of important historical documents, which are likely to be held by Commonwealth Government agencies and available only from North Queensland sources.

These objectives, of course, did not operate when I started depositing my papers . I suppose in the long term it is a tragedy that all of my personal papers will be lodged in Canberra with the National Library, which has a very efficient filing and recall system. There are staff pressures or staff ceilings applied to Archives, and one would be lucky to get anything out of the Brisbane office under three or four weeks because of the inability to service properly people who need the recall of documents. It is not the fault of Archives at either the national level or the State level; there are just not sufficient people available to do the work. An Archives office would keep the records and historical documents of North Queensland for use there by Commonwealth Government agencies and then later on, in the open period, by researchers. It would service all Commonwealth departments from St Lawrence north and west to the border with respect to records, storage and disposal.

Surveys in the late 1960s provided statistical data and established the need for the opening of the Archives office in the north. Since its notional opening in 1972 and effective operational status in 1979 there has been a considerable increase in the number of requests for material, and in complexity and output from the offices it was proposed to service. It has a very wide territory. Many historical documents, of course, will never be preserved unless there is a central agency such as the Archives office to provide the care and attention that documents of that nature need and for posterity to be able to do research on them.

I hope that the Government will take the steps necessary to see that provision for this work is made in the future. It is too late now. The gate has been closed and the horse has gone. I hope that planning will commence immediately to see that there is some restoration of a facility that was becoming very valuable to northerners and which would become even more valuable in the future. The point I complain about most is the short- sightedness of Government action in misspending the best part of $70,000 probably to save, in the short term, $8,000 , $10,000, $15,000 or $20,000. It has effectively crippled the service by putting it into limbo. One wonders whether Sir Phillip Lynch is not using this as one of his means for getting out of the Parliament because of the many scandals associated with the recommendations that came from the razor gang.

The other big problem that we have in the far north is the decision to incorporate the College of Advanced Education at Townsville with James Cook University. The CAE did not want the amalgamation, and JCU did not want the CAE amalgamated with it. In the short term that was a very costly thing. In the long term it is doubtful whether it will have the same effectiveness as the CAE operating alone and the university operating in its own right as well. I make an appeal to the Government to look at these things in the future and not to take a window dressing attitude in a so-called effort to save taxpayers' dollars. What the Government has done in the areas that I have mentioned has wasted many thousands of dollars of taxpayers' money for a smart operation that in the long term will be disastrous.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, may I just have a moment? What is the situation?
—You are confused.
—I am not confused with what is happening but I object to the way that some of the things are happening around here today.
—You have got two minutes. Get on with it.

—I am not wasting my time. I object to a situation in which one honourable senator goes away and has his lunch and then comes back into the chamber and expects to speak, having lost his position on the speaking list.
