DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory I present two reports on proposals for variations of the plan of lay-out of the City of Canberra and its environs-76th Series-Item 2, 77th Series, and 78th Series-dated October 1982, together with extracts from the minutes of proceedings of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the reports be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The report on the 77th series of variations covers 11 variations to the city plan and recommends the approval of works valued at over $3.5m. The Committee, in considering these proposed variations, noted the third report of the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly Standing Committee on Development and Planning and took evidence from several private citizens during the public hearing held on 27 September 1982. The Committee has decided to withhold the approval of one variation and has approved the remaining ten. It has also decided to approve one item deferred from the 76th series.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee is withholding approval on a proposal to degazette part of an existing paved area in Garema Place, Civic. The proposal involves the demolition of the existing toilet block and the development of the site as a restaurant or cafe. The Committee requires further information from the National Capital Development Commission and the Department of the Capital Territory on arrangements to ensure pedestrian access and visual continuity between City Walk and Garema Place, and what is intended for the future development of Garema Place to ensure that its present character, as an important place for public activities and assembly, is maintained. The Committee has also approved item 2 of the 76th series, the deletion and realignment of a length of cycleway between Haydon Drive and College Street, Bruce. The Committee received a letter from the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) dated 16 September 1982, providing the additional information sought on the necessity of the variation. A copy of the letter is included in the report. The 78th series proposes the addition to the city plan of several roads to provide access to the new Parliament House.

The Committee is concerned that the number of modifications and proposals contained in this series has been presented as one variation. It believes that these modifications should have been presented as separate and distinct items in the series, particularly since the total estimated cost for the series is $20.9m . The Committee in its report has itemised the modifications contained in the series.

Most of the modifications proposed in the series have not attracted criticism but the Committee has received conflicting evidence concerning the proposed Commonwealth and Kings Avenue ramps. As a consequence, the Committee has reservations about the proposed ramps and, in light of the NCDC's evidence that work on the proposed ramps would not commence until the 1984-85 financial year, does not at this time approve these parts of the variation that include these ramps. The Committee also defers approval of the associated proposed works at the Kings Avenue-State Circle intersection and the Canberra Avenue-State Circle intersection. It approves the remaining works. This includes the variation to the intersection at Melbourne Avenue and Capital Circle. The objectors' evidence in relation to that matter was that they were concerned about the increased traffic that would come into Melbourne Avenue. The NCDC gave an undertaking with respect to the Stonehaven Crescent end that it would look at the increase in traffic there to see whether any further variations to that end would be required. The concern of the objectors that the variation would enable traffic to flow from the Woden Valley area through Melbourne Avenue around the perimeter of Parliament House and down the Commonwealth Avenue ramp was one of the reasons for not approving the Commonwealth Avenue ramp. If that is not built, then the traffic flow through Melbourne Avenue would be considerably different than if the ramp were to be built there. To that extent the Committee took notice of what the objectors had to say about the Melbourne Avenue entrance. There will undoubtedly be some increase of traffic at that end but not more, we believe, than the Melbourne Avenue road at present can carry.

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON GOVERNMENT CLOTHING AND ORDNANCE FACTORIES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martyr Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Select Committee on Government Clothing and Ordnance Factories on the future of the Australian Government Clothing Factory at Coburg, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martyr Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

This is the second report from the Select Committee. The first report, on the future of the Bendigo Ordnance Factory, was tabled in the Senate on 9 March. To set some minds at rest immediately, the Committee has not recommended closure in this case. The Committee's task in this inquiry was to determine the future of the Australian Government Clothing Factory at Coburg, given the decision of the Government, which followed the Review of Commonwealth Functions, that the factory be offered for sale or lease as a going concern. In short, the Committee recommends that the Government's decision to sell the factory as a going concern was basically correct. It agreed that there were three options open to the Government for the future of the factory-sale or lease as a going concern, retention by the Government or closure. The Committee was united at least in the decision that the factory should not be closed. Very little evidence was given to the Committee on the consequences of leasing the factory. The Committee agreed that it would be unusual for a whole business to be leased as a going concern.

In detail, the Committee recommends first that the effort to sell the factory as a going concern, suspended for the term of the inquiry, be now pursued with maximum vigour and a particular effort be made to show the work force the benefits of the sale. Secondly, as an incentive to prospective purchasers and in establishing fair terms of sale, the factory should retain all its defence contracts and be given favourable consideration for others in the future. Thirdly, if the Australian Government Clothing Factory is to be retained by the Government, it should be given more autonomy to operate as a commercial enterprise. As a consequence of this, the factory would account for its notional costs and factory management would be given more incentive to pursue profitable purchasing and pricing policies.

We feel that the embroidery section attached to the factory-I ask you, Mr Acting Deputy President, as a former senior ranking naval officer, to be patient with me when I talk about the embroidery section-ought to be examined to see whether its services are really necessary for the uniforms of the fighting forces and, if so, whether the cost of the embroidery on uniforms ought to be allocated to the wearer rather than the Government. This presumes the availability of cheaper alternatives to embroidery as standard issue. The Committee discovered almost by accident during the inquiry that at that stage there was not a full duplicate set of patterns. In the case of fire or some other damage to the factory, production would have been disrupted. We recommend that duplicate sets of all patterns be retained for safe keeping at a location outside the factory in case of fire. We were not asked to inquire about anything like that but that is one of the things that came out. I suppose it is one of the benefits of having an inquiry into government concerns.

The evidence presented to the Committee revealed that the factory is very efficiently managed. It is capable of manufacturing over 2,000 kinds of garment. It is a small clothing industry within itself and it has supplied the Department of Defence with clothing requirements of a very high standard, often at short notice, for over 70 years. The Department of Defence told the Committee that the factory had served it well over that period and its work was a continuing requirement for the Defence Force. The Committee has been mindful of this in its considerations and concludes that there is no case for closing the factory, as there certainly was in regard to the Bendigo Ordnance Factory. Some of the references on pages 17 to 21 of the report show a comparison quite clearly. During the course of the inquiry the Committee did make some comparisons. They were certainly favourable as far as the Government Clothing Factory at Coburg was concerned.

All that having been said, the Committee, though, found no real reason for recommending that the factory remain under Government control. The Committee is disturbed by the annual loss incurred by the factory and the consequential cost to the Government of retaining it. That cost is in the order of $1.1m to $1.6m annually. Page 16 of the report shows that the notional costs are a combination of audit fees, administrative support, depreciation, interest on capital, superannuation, repairs and maintenance, insurance and other expenses which would normally be met by a commercial establishment but which are not met in a Government establishment. It is these notional costs which, for instance, totalled $1.3m in 1980, $1.1m in 1981 and $1.6m in 1982. These notional costs were the cause of disturbance among some Committee members. We felt, nonetheless , that there was certainly no case for closing the factory as there was in the case of the Bendigo Ordnance Factory. The Committee believes the Government does not have a social responsibility to maintain a commercially non-viable factory.

Given that the size of defence orders is constant, perhaps increasing, the factory could be sold as a going concern and possibly attract a buyer who would make it viable, bringing his own expertise and capacity. The Committee appreciates the dilemma of the Departments of Defence and Defence Support in that they must attempt always to obtain the greatest possible value for the taxpayers' defence dollar whilst ensuring that defence skills and capabilities already acquired in Australia at high cost are not lost or dissipated. Sale as a going concern would achieve this objective.

TALK.START.PARA: —Next thing you will be recommending that we hand over the Defence Force to private enterprise.

—If Senator McLaren wanted to auction the Defence Force I do not think he would get a bid. The Committee is confident that private enterprise is capable of undertaking the work required by the Services and fulfilling their needs satisfactorily, although certainly the cost to the Government may increase . It would be offset to some extent by taxation paid by a private operator. Delivery might also be affected to some extent but this would be the subject to negotiation between manufacturer and client.

SPEECH.PARA: Overall, though, the Committee is satisfied that commercial viability could be achieved and that action to invite selected firms to submit proposals relating to the sale of the AGCF, which was deferred during the period of the inquiry, should now continue. If the AGCF is to be retained by the Government then it should be operated along more commercial lines. At present the factory's aim is to break even, despite evidence which indicated that there might be opportunities to price some garments on a more competitive basis. Accounting for its notional costs and having more flexibility in pricing and purchasing policies would enable the factory to achieve this. I think it was the unanimous conclusion of the Committee that the present management of the factory is quite capable of achieving those limited objectives. The safe-keeping of patterns in the event of fire concerns the Committee and although the patterns are being recorded on a computer for safe-keeping in the future the Committee considers that there should be a safe place for storage in the meantime.

The sale of the AGCF as a going concern would not result in significant social and economic impact in either the Coburg area or the industry generally. It is probable that AGCF employees would be given offers of employment by a prospective purchaser, and the Committee has said in its report that the Government, in negotiations with the buyer, should consider the matter of retention of staff with a view to the continuation of the existing terms and conditions of service. In these circumstances, the social consequences of the sale need not be as pessimistic as those outlined in some submissions to the Committee.

At this stage I should say that once again I deeply appreciated the co- operation of members of the Committee. Certainly we had disagreement but it was always civilised and understanding. I think that all members of the Committee appreciated the help by the staff which in many cases went beyond the requirements of duty. All Committee members appreciated the co-operation that was shown particularly by Mr Silk, the AGCF Manager, and his staff and also the staff of other Government departments. We thank all of those who made submissions and appeared before the Committee. Finally, I commend this report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Senate will be aware, the Senate Select Committee on the Government Clothing and Ordnance Factories, of which I was a member, was appointed over a year ago to investigate the proposed sale or closure of two government factories as recommended by the razor gang. The recommendation of the Committee in respect of the closure of the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo was in fact not adopted by the Government. Senator Button and I strongly disagreed with the Committee's recommendation on the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo. It is pleasing to note that the new Minister, Mr Ian Viner, has gone even further than the original recommendation made in the majority report and the factory at Bendigo is now becoming a government owned enterprise showpiece.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee was by no means a model committee. Members of the Committee disagreed very strongly on various matters, mainly on ideological grounds. As Senator Martyr has pointed out, our discussions were always amicable. However, difficulties arise with the findings of the Committee in respect of the Ordnance Factory and the Government Clothing Factory because strikingly different conclusions are arrived at. However, it would be a mistake to believe that the work of the Committee has been a waste of time and effort. It seems clear that a lot of information has been gathered by the Committee and that the Government has taken notice of it. Indeed, the committee looking at the Government Aircraft Factories on behalf of the Defence Review Committee unearthed a lot of informationm on the way the Government is running its defence factories. I believe that the establishment of the Department of Defence Support has so far proved remarkably, and even some of the cynics might say surprisingly, successful.

I believe that one or two brief comments should be made about the dissenting report by Senator Button and me on the Australian Government Clothing Factory, Coburg. We have recommended that the factory remain government owned and government operated. I believe the important point in arriving at this conclusion, and I am sure a point to which the Senate will have to give some careful consideration, is that the factory was set up by a previous conservative administration very largely as a result of an exhaustive debate. The Menzies Government set up the commission headed by Sir John Allison, assisted by Mr Leslie Brewster, to look at the question of whether a government clothing factory should be established for clothing members of the services. It recommended not only that there should be a government factory but also that money should be spent on extending its operation and building new premises. Therefore, the present factory is very much the child of the Allison and Brewster report.

It is interesting to note that these two gentlemen were leaders in industry. They headed up very large private enterprise companies. Leslie Brewster was a director of one of the largest garment manufactureres in the country and has been for many years the Treasurer of the Victorian Chamber of Manufactures. It was not the sort of commission that one would expect to be unduly sympathetic to the establishment of government owned enterprises. Yet it found, for some very cogent reasons, that it was absolutely essential for the Government to have a clothing factory. It said that such a factory was necessary for the quick delivery of items in variety. It said that the factory could be a laboratory for garment design and development. It said that the vagaries of private industry make it very difficult for a government to get uniforms during times of emergency. It said that such a factory was necessary if government was to have the means of keeping industry honest in the procurement of uniforms from private enterprise.

Recently Australia agreed to contribute to the Multinational Force and Observers in the Sinai. Had it not been for the Government Clothing Factory the uniforms required by the peacekeeping contingent could not have been produced in time for it to meet its commitments. The rapid development of the Army Reserve is another example of the way in which the factory at Coburg has been able to meet such emergencies. It is important to realise that the factory is not set up to make uniforms for Australian forces in the event of war. It is there to meet emergencies and as a nucleus for the development in the event of war. Long production runs, of course, would be let to private industry. However, in between wars and emergencies it is important to have a factory which can develop new uniforms, act as a store for patterns and be the nucleus from which rapid expansion of uniform making can emanate.

Some things have been said in the majority report which I would say are quite sensible. I think we have reached a greater degree of agreement on the question of the Government Clothing Factory than was reached on the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo. It is agreed that there is need for a factory although the majority report says that such a factory could well be operated by private industry. It is on this point that we believe the majority report is in serious error. Senator Martyr made some quite extensive comments about the fact that this factory would be able to produce uniforms more cheaply if it were operated by private enterprise. I disagree with that. It was suggested that certain notional costs are not taken into account in the costing of uniforms. I believe those notional costs are fictitious and to say that they have not been taken into account is purely a paper exercise. The facts are that the pricing of uniforms from the Clothing Factory is competitive with private industry. It is also very important to realise that the association which represents the overwhelming majority of the garment manufacturers in this country said that it believed the Government Clothing Factory should remain, that it performed a very valuable function and that, by and large, private enterprise was not interested in the short runs that were essentially the function of the Government Clothing Factory . We have here a very clear statement by the industry that the factory is performing a useful function and that its function could not be easily undertaken by any other means.

It was also very significant to learn during the evidence that some years ago Sweden tried to close downs its government-owned clothing factory for ideological reasons and that the Swedish Government very quickly found that it could not operate without a government-owned factory which was capable of producing uniforms for its Services. Whilst many honourable senators may think that the debate on this issue is somewhat unimportant and academic, it does raise a very basic issue. Unless we can clothe our forces efficiently and quickly we are not in a position to say that we have a properly equipped Defence Force in this country.

There is one other aspect of the majority report to which I draw the attention of the Senate. It was suggested that the embroidery section was not profitable and, therefore, should be abolished. I think that this would give material for a Gilbert and Sullivan type of comic opera. With a little bit of imagination we could write an opera entitled 'The Naked Admiral'. Imagine the Australian Government saying to the Admiral of the Fleet: 'Here is an aircraft carrier which cost about $1 billion, but we have not got the money to supply the insignia on your uniform. We suggest that you go somewhere else and see whether you can get the insignia. It will cost you something; you pay for it yourself. The Government of this country has not got the money'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Go to Moss Brothers.

—Yes, or wherever. This is where the whole concept of cost effectiveness has been drawn to a ridiculous degree. Government senators said that the Government Clothing Factory was uneconomic and, therefore, should be closed down. They are not really concerned about where we can get the insignias which are a necessary part of the armed forces. The whole idea conjures up all kinds of interesting examples. During the revolution in Russia it was decided that there would be a classless, rankless, army; no one would give orders and no one would obey. This was a delightful concept but it did not stand the test of time. In 1943 Stalin found that he had to reintroduce ranks. He finished up giving them the same titles as the old Tsarist Army. We must have ranks in our Services and, unfortunately, rank has to be very clearly observable. If Senator Martyr were the Admiral of the Fleet-heaven help us-I think he would too be pleased that the Government had the money to pay for the trappings on his uniform.

SPEECH.PARA: I make one final point in relation to the inconsistency of the majority report. I will endeavour to be brief. Those responsible for the majority report are the champions of the private enterprise system. But they said that the Government should give favourable consideration, in the event of the factory being sold, to defence contracts being guaranteed. They cannot have it both ways. They either believe in private enterprise, and hence that that can operate without government assistance, or they do not. They are saying, 'Sell the factory but keep the government assistance'. I move an amendment to the majority report in the following terms:
At end of motion, add:
'but is of the opinion that the proposed sale of the Australian Government Clothing Factory at Coburg is primarily for ideological and not practical reasons and:
(a) would cause the price of uniforms for the Defence Forces to increase;
(b) would cause certain sections of the factory to be relocated to other Government factories, with consequent unnecessary social and financial costs;
(c) would create a risk of Australia becoming dependent on overseas clothing technology; and
(d) has not been justified on the basis of any new factors which have arisen since the previous conservative administration set up the factory after exhaustive debate.'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am broadly in agreement with the views expressed by Senator Siddons. In fact, I must be in total agreement because we both signed the same dissenting report in relation to the future of the Australian Government Clothing Factory. I want to make some very brief remarks about that.
—It is a socialist proposal-like all of the Democrats.

—Senator Lewis interjects with his customary lucidity and sense of history; it is a socialist proposal established by Bob Menzies. If the Liberal Party, as the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has reminded us recently, Senator Lewis, were consistent now with the principles established by Sir Robert Menzies it would not be in the awful shape that it is. The fact of the matter is that the proposed sale of the Government Clothing Factory at Coburg emanated from the decisions of the so-called razor gang in April 1981. It is sad to say that while most members of the Liberal Party have ceased to talk any more about the razor gang and have abandoned most of its decisions, only those two well named honourable senators-Senator Crichton-Browne and Senator Martyr-battle on in defence of the principles which guided the Liberal Party 18 months ago and which have been abandoned by everybody else. This is, in a sense, their final monument. I am glad that the report of the Senate Select Committee on Government Clothing and Ordnance Factories has been published because it means the Committee can now be disbanded and that those honourable senators who served on it can get down to some work on serious political issues. Senator Siddons has spoken about the majority report in some detail. I just want to make one or two points.
—You are an expert on embroidery. What do you think about it?

—I intended to work up to that. At the height of my speech I was going to talk about embroidery, Senator. I thank the honourable senator for his interjection. The recommendations of the majority report of the Committee have the same sort of sad sense of deja vu about them as the report of the inquiry into the Bendigo Ordnance Factory. It was suggested that the factory should be sold as a going concern. As a sop for that suggestion it was said that the question of persuading the employees of the factory of the benefits should be pursued with maximum vigour. I do not know who will do that. I do not know whether Senator Crichton-Browne and Senator Martyr are offering their services to go the the Coburg factory and explain to the workers that they should really understand that their future would be well secure in their hands. Whatever those honourable senators think about that proposition, the people at the clothing factory do not believe it. They do not believe that, just the same as the people at the Bendigo Ordnance Factory did not believe that when the same honourable senators tried to persuade them that the factory should be sold.

SPEECH.PARA: The strange thing about the majority report is that nobody who gave evidence to the Committee believed the clothing factory should be sold. No argument was advanced and there was no evidence before the Committee to say that the clothing factory ought to be sold. The Department of Defence was not keen on the clothing factory being sold. The Australian Confederation of Apparel Manufacturers, the employer body, was not keen on the clothing factory being sold. It did not think it was wise. The employees and the management were not keen. On the basis of all that evidence Senator Crichton-Browne and Senator Martyr deduced that it should be sold. It was an extraordinary exercise in quasi-judicial determination, based on the issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Wills would not be too keen about it either, would he?

—No, he is not too keen. There was an extraordinary lack of material to suggest that it was a wise, prudent and socially desirable course to sell the factory. The Committee, in the course of its deliberations, went to the factory, inspected the premises, saw the work being done and spoke to management , staff and employees. I believe that it is true to say that all members of the Committee were impressed with the standard of the work being done, with the systems organisation, and with particular aspects as revealed in the course of the evidence. I refer, for instance, to the fact that, when the Defence Department came to the factory and said 'We are going to send a contingent to the Sinai in three weeks; will you provide us with uniforms?', it did so and has done likewise on a number of occasions in similar circumstances, providing a range of uniforms for service personnel, often on very short notice. As Senator Siddons said, the Committee was very impressed with the embroidery section of the factory, where highly skilled machinery work is done. The view was expressed there-it is one that I have no difficulty in believing-that it would be difficult to get that work done anywhere else in Australia. In fact, the embroidery section does work for overseas military forces, producing ceremonial banners and objects of that kind.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Crichton-Browne and Senator Martyr, in their majority report, paid one tribute to the factory. They said that the duplicates of all of the factory patterns ought to be retained outside the structure in case of fire. That was a nice way of saying that there was something really worth retaining about it, but that was about all that was said of that nature in the course of the majority report. I do not believe that either Senator Siddons or myself retreats from the view that probably better financial arrangements could be made. I refer to the way in which the factory accounts are prepared and the costing of various items takes place. However, that is not a reason for selling the factory. It is a reason for saying that the Government should look at ways of making that part of the operation more efficient. I believe that everyone who was aware of the evidence would agree as to that fact.

The minority of the Committee was impressed by the way in which the factory operates, by its work force, by its good industrial relations record, by the particular skills displayed in certain sections, by the concern of the employees about the maintenance of what has been a steady employment situation for most of them over many years, and by the general wider community concern that the factory should be retained. No one is lining up to buy it. No organisation seriously puts itself forward as contending for the work that is done by the factory.

In conclusion, I say that the factory has been the subject of a number of inquiries, each of which has come to the conclusion that the factory should be retained as a public service, a service to the State, if you will, in terms of the work done. The Allison and Brewster report referred to the great variety of items manufactured and its relatively short production runs, which affect costs. That passage is quoted in the minority report. For the reasons I have given I was a signatory to the minority report. I hope that the Government will take precisely the same attitude to this matter as it did to the Bendigo Ordnance Factory report and reject the decision of the majority of the Committee.

In conclusion, I pay tribute to those other senators who served on the Committee because, although I disagreed with two of them, I at least managed to express my disagreement in most civil ways, as I always do, and they did the same to me. I pay tribute particularly to Senator Siddons who, I think it is fair to say, if I am not telling secrets out of school, was substantially the author of the minority report. I have pleasure in seconding the amendment moved by Senator Siddons.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall be very brief because Senator Martyr, in a very articulate and precise manner, laid before the Senate, as an addendum to the report, those matters that we canvassed, which quite properly should be touched upon. I should say at the outset that it gave me more satisfaction to deal with this part of the inquiry than that which related to the Bendigo Ordnance Factory. To say the least, it was nothing short of depressing to see the manner in which that factory was operating and its lack of capacity and potential for the future.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe it is reasonable to say that the Government Clothing Factory is very well managed. Mr Silk, from what I observed in a rather superficial way perhaps, is doing an admirable job, labouring under the circumstances of its being a government factory from the outset. The factory seems to be well laid out and there seems to be good morale among the work force, although one could not help but note that when the Government announced its intention to sell the factory, allegedly one of the staff attempted to burn it down. I do not know whether that is a reflection of the employees' dear love for Mr Silk or the Government, or their abhorrence and fear concerning the efficiencies of private enterprise. On the whole, it appears to be a happy work force and to be functioning well. The fact is that it is a Government clothing factory and does operate at a loss, including notional costs-which are as real as any other-of some $1.6m a year.

One is drawn to the conclusion by the evidence-the same evidence as that upon which we reflected in the first part of our inquiry-that the Government, by its very nature, does not seek to derive a profit from these types of activities or, in many cases, to break even in a proper way taking into consideration notional costs. In fact, when I asked Mr Silk, the manager, whether he was seeking to operate on a non-profit or non-loss basis, while covering all outgoings from charges made to customers, his response was yes. He went on to say that he got into trouble whether he made a loss or a profit; that he was supposed to end up square in spite of the circumstances.

Regrettably, I suspect that that reflects the attitudes of government departments these days. They just do not have a profit mentality, even when profit is possible. Perhaps one should not be too critical of modern civil servants, who are steeped in the ways of governments. There used to be a time, at least under conservative governments, when it was felt that government was intended to provide those services and facilities that it could best provide and private enterprise ought to provide those that could more efficiently and effectively be provided by it. It is regrettable that successive governments have ensured that provision of these services and so we find this mentality-that costs and profits are of no real consequence.

Mr Aitchison, the executive director of the Australian Confederation of Apparel Manufacturers, as mentioned earlier, did suggest that private enterprise did not particularly want this factory to be sold out of government hands. I have to say that I have some reservations as to his motives. One could not help but note that, with the high level of protection afforded the clothing manufacturing industry, the more factories that are open and the more diversification of ownership that occurs, the less likelihood there is that protection will remain at present levels. Moreover, I believe it was Mr Silk who testified that one difficulty the factory had was that it trained competently and capably skilled machinists, only to find that they were tempted into private enterprise factories. A number of the staff who commenced their employment with that factory were unable to speak fluent English and there were special training courses to teach them to speak English. The factory was providing a skilled workforce only to have it removed from it and placed, as a result perhaps of better offers or different offers, in private enterprise. I refer honourable senators to page 231 of the evidence where the point was made by Mr Aitchison when he said:
It is interesting to note that the industry itself has some sympathy for the factory because it does provide a reservoir, I suppose, of training.

One of the reasons that were given for the retention of the factory in government hands was that the defence forces could very quickly obtain their clothing and equipment at short notice. The example was given to us of the Sinai peacekeeping force's requiring its uniforms in a very short time. I think that that was a unique circumstance and that by and large departments should know their uniform requirements well in advance. On reflection, it seems to me that perhaps we have inefficient management, poor judgments and slow decisions being made by the defence forces and that they are seeking to compound their incompetence by asking for a government factory to ensure that th manifestation of their incompetence is not reflected in the end result of their clothing demands. It has also been suggested that the factory plays a unique role. Of course, that is not the case. It plays a vital role in our defence needs, but it is certainly not unique. Indeed, Mr Ballantine, the President of the Combined Union Shop Stewards Committee of the Australian Government Clothing Factory at Coburg, said:

I think perhaps we should not get carried away with the making of garments. It is my belief that private industry can make any garment at all. There is not a garment that can be made at the Government Clothing Factory that cannot be made by private industry.

In fact 35 per cent of the type of work that is carried out by the clothing factory is done in private enterprise. I believe it is reasonable to say that any similar factory in the hands of a private operator could duplicate the activities being conducted in that factory. Of course, in the light of the size of the factory and its workforce, for an effective sale there would have to be some guarantee from government departments as to its work load. Mr Hugh Ryan, the Deputy Secretary of the Department of Industry and Commerce, has said that the Government could guarantee a minimum of 500,000 hours per year. I find it interesting to note, at this time of high unemployment and an apparent downturn in the economy, that this particular industry is having difficulty in attracting skilled workers and that the industry is allegedly running at full capacity. In the final analysis, the bottom line argument in this debate is whether the activities of this factory are better managed and better conducted by private enterprise or in the hands of government. That tends to be subjective view dependent on one's philosophical approach to life. Senator Martyr and I believe that we have examined the evidence in an objective way. On the basis of that, we have drawn the distinct conclusion that this factory can be well managed and well run by private enterprise as compared with the way that it is run in the hands of the civil service.

The Committee has functioned very well in this case. We have all been of the same mind, at least in terms of the facts. It was in the distilling of the facts as they were assembled, and it was in reaching conclusions, that we had to take a different view. I noted the comment made earlier that the factory was set up in the first place by a conservative government. I do not feel bound by the precedents of poor judgments by previous governments, either of our persuasion or that of the Opposition. To illustrate the point I am making, that factory makes uniforms for the Victorian Police Force and it makes them at below cost. As I understand it, the first uniform is provided to police in Victoria by the Government. Subsequent uniforms are required to be purchased by the individual policemen. So in fact that factory is subsidising not only the Victorian Government but also individual policemen in Victoria.

It seems that there is no sensible approach by Government to place the factory on an efficient, economic and viable footing. In the event that the factory is not sold, I hope that the Government chooses to give more flexibility to management, to give management a freer hand to make value judgments and to allow management to seek to run the factory at least at break-even point, taking into account the notional costs. At present that is certainly not the case and that is one of the reasons why we conclude that the factory ought to be sold.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be added (Senator Siddons's amendment) be added.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE FOR THE SCRUTINY OF BILLS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the fourteenth report of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, concerning the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill 1982, the Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill 1982 and the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1982.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Committee, I lay on the table Scrutiny of Bills Digest No. 12, dated 14 October 1982.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Paper and Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On behalf of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) I table a policy discussion paper on extrinsic aids to statutory interpretation. The paper examines the extent to which, in interpreting Acts of Parliament, regard can properly and usefully be had to reports, explanatory memoranda and other materials that do not themselves form part of the Act. For this purpose the paper examines the extent to which the courts already use such extrinsic materials. It goes on to consider whether the range of such extrinsic materials needs to be broadened, and how that could be brought about in a way that would be satisfactory and acceptable from the point of view of the courts and of the audience to which the Act is directed. Finally, the paper sets forth for consideration and discussion a possible procedure and program for the use of specially prepared explanatory memoranda limited, initially at least, to selected Acts considered by their sponsors to be appropriate for this purpose.

SPEECH.PARA: The discussion paper arises out of an initiative announced by the Attorney- General in 1981 at the time he introduced the Bill to insert section 15AA in the Acts Interpretation Act. The Attorney-General stated that an examination would be undertaken of the topic, with a view to developing proposals that would be brought into the Parliament for further consideration. There has also been considerable interest in the exercise by groups outside Parliament and indeed overseas as well, and it is hoped and expected that the paper will produce a vigorous and fruitful debate. My only regret is that Senator Durack is not personally able to open that debate, as the exercise is very much his own personal initiative. No official examination of this kind has taken place since Federation in 1901, although as the paper indicates there have been some distinguished precursors.

The paper is also timely in view of the quite remarkable way in which the problems of statutory interpretation have engaged the attention of both our highest courts and the wider Australian community in recent times. One thing that clearly emerges from the paper is that the courts already can refer to extrinsic materials in certain cases under the existing rules of interpretation. Legislation is not made in a vacuum and each Act must be read in its context. Courts may, and on occasion do, look at reports and other materials leading to the legislation in question. Recently, individual judges of the High Court of Australia have gone to the extent of looking at Hansard to identify the problem the Act addresses or even to ascertain directly what was the parliamentary intent. These judicial developments are of great significance. However, other judges take a more restricted view, and this in itself raises a problem. There are other problems. Often these materials will not be readily accessible to the ordinary users of statutes. They are not necessarily self-explanatory and often require a difficult exercise of evaluation. Finally, as the paper notes, overall there has been much greater reluctance to use parliamentary materials than to use other materials, such as reports, that in fact are more remote from the law- making process than is Hansard.

In these circumstances, the paper proposes for consideration the use in selected cases of a specially prepared explanatory memorandum or statement that would be submitted to Parliament along with the legislation in question. The memorandum, when approved, would be made as accessible to the users of the legislation as the legislation itself. One of the most interesting points that emerges from the paper is that the idea of such a special explanatory statement has received wide interest or support over a considerable period. The paper cites Professor C. K. Allen, in his time one of the most distinguished commentators on the English legal system which we have inherited in Australia. Reference is also made to the detailed study of this proposal by the 1969 report of the English and Scottish Law Commissions, presided over, I should add, by Lord Scarman, one of the most distinguished of the English law lords. Sir Stanley Burbury spoke in favour of the idea on his retirement from the Tasmanian Supreme Court, and associated the idea with proposals along these lines made by the eminent American jurist Dean Roscoe Pound. I therefore commend the paper and look forward to the constructive debate that I believe its analysis of the topic and the proposals it makes deserves.

Statutory interpretation is a matter that directly concerns all those whose activities are affected by Acts of Parliament. In modern society, that means everyone. However, members of this Parliament have a particular concern in ensuring as far as possible that Acts passed by them give effect to their understanding and expectations of what Acts mean. In our time, there have been a number of developments. One is the increasing use of objects clauses to set forth the object or purpose of Acts. Another was the enactment last year of section 15AA of the Acts Interpretation Act directing courts to prefer that interpretation which promotes the object or purpose of an Act to one that does not. The paper points the way to a further possible development, and at the same time draws attention to judicial developments of considerable significance.

The intention is that time should be allowed for the paper to be studied and debated, inside and outside the Parliament, before any decision is taken on whether its specific proposals should be proceeded with. Clearly the kind of special explanatory memoranda it envisages would require the devising of appropriate procedures for each House, and both Houses jointly, for dealing with the approval and possible amendment of such memoranda. The nature of these procedures is, of course, a matter for the Houses to consider and decide. The paper notes that one of the vital factors in the success of the proposal would be the spirit in which the courts accept such aids to interpretation. It could equally be said that success would also depend on the spirit in which this Parliament receives the proposals and implements them.

On the machinery aspects, consideration and amendment of a memorandum in conjunction with the consideration of the Bill to which it relates may turn out to be incompatible with the existing practices of the two Houses. However, a motion of approval of a memorandum, quite separate from the consideration of the Bill, could be an acceptable alternative. This could be achieved by the motion being agreed to in the House in which the Bill originated and transmitted to the other House for its concurrence; or the motion being moved separately in both Houses and agreed to.

It is proposed that a symposium will be held early in the New Year involving parliamentarians, eminent judges and other lawyers, as well as other interested groups. The purpose will be to further the discussion and also to help bring an early resolution of the issues so that decisions can be made as soon as possible on the proposals in the paper. I would like to commend officers of the Attorney- General's Department, in particular Mr Brazil, a Deputy Secretary of the Department, and Mr Kolts, First Parliamentary Counsel, for the valuable work done by them in the preparation of this paper. I commend the paper to the consideration of Parliament. I move:
That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a fascinating subject, especially for lawyers, and I am minded-indeed, prepared-to wax lyrical upon it for my full half hour. However, bearing in mind other more immediately exciting topics bearing down upon us, I will limit my contribution to just a few seconds-maybe about 120 seconds. I think what should be said-it is really quite important-is that anyone who thinks that statutory interpretation issues of the kind dealt with here are too exotic for anyone but lawyers to take an interest in need only contemplate the havoc caused by the Barwick High Court of Australia in its literal interpretation of tax laws throughout the 1970s which has contributed along, of course, with the neglect of the present Government, to our discontents on the taxation front.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition welcomes very much the appearance of this Green Paper, so-called , although green ink does not seem to have gone anywhere near it in its production and even if it is, in the finest traditions of the Attorney-General's Department, now over a year late in its appearance. It was said back in September 1981 that the Paper would be brought forward before the Parliament rises. Senator Durack did not say which Parliament. The idea of policy discussion papers to generate in the community debate of a constructive kind on complex issues is a very sensible one and one which deserves a lot more repetition, although I do not suppose that we could expect that from this Government.

Finally, the proposal for formal explanatory memoranda to be de-endorsed by Parliament at the same time as the parent legislation is neither very new nor very radical but it would, I believe, represent a significant contribution toward more acceptable interpretation by judges. Partly as a backlash to the excesses of the Barwick High Court, courts right around Australia, I believe, are now more alert to the purpose and intent of legislation than they have been in the past and more sensitive to the social and economic effects of their interpretation. But that process needs all the reinforcement it can get. I repeat that we welcome the appearance of this policy paper, congratulate those responsible, particularly Mr Brazil and Mr Kolts for its preparation, and look forward to an early opportunity to debate it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that it will come as something of a surprise to the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) to know that the Australian Democrats wholeheartedly support the proposals that are outlined in this little document entitled 'Extrinsic Aids to Statutory Interpretation'. As a lay person and not as a lawyer who is likely to get highly enthusiastic over this matter, I cannot quite understand why taking into account what Parliament wanted in the first place should be considered extrinsic to the legislation. As an English teacher I would have thought that it was intrinsic to it but I do not want to spend a great deal of time debating the title of this paper. It is a relief to see that following the Government's limited success with section 15AA of the Acts Interpretation Act, the Government is continuing in what appears to be a proposal to inject further fresh air and common sense into the interpretation of legislation in this country. I for one certainly hope to be able to take part in the proposed symposium that was referred to at the end of the Minister's statement.

SPEECH.PARA: I wonder whether the enthusiasm amongst lawyers that Senator Evans referred to will be very positive enthusiasm or whether it will not be more involved with beating of breasts and tearing out of hair since lawyers and some others in this country make considerable livelihood through the adversary system that exists in the law courts of this country. Through a series of mental gymnastics and semantic pedantry lawyers argue the finer points of law arising out of unclear wording and intention in Acts and unwitting and/or unintentional loopholes and anomalies. I suspect that they will not like at all anything which is likely to clarify this and take away the intellectual stimulation that they seem to find from arguing the point. On those grounds alone it means that this proposal is worth supporting.

The Australian Democrats have, of course, had occasion to be upset-the matter is quite close to our hearts-with the insistence on some of the judiciary in taking absolutely literal interpretations as has happened to us within the last 18 months in a High Court of Australia challenge regarding the advertising campaign that was mounted against us in Western Australia during the last Federal election. The definition of 'casting a vote' was defined very narrowly- more or less in terms of dropping the damn thing in a ballot box-and no consideration was paid to what was done prior to that to determine fairly or otherwise how a voter was likely to make up his mind. In September this year the Age referred to Sir Garfield Barwick's penchant for narrowly sticking to pedantic semantics in relation to the Westraders case.

TALK.START.PARA: —Get on with it, kiddo.
—I am sorry but the honourable senator is just getting back some of his own. He should sit there and listen. I do not mind whether or not he listens but he should just sit there.
—How much of my own are you giving me back this afternoon?
—Not nearly as much as the honourable senator deserves.
—We are only up to the second sentence.

—That is right. We are only up to the second sentence. It is correct, as the point is made in the document, that legislation is becoming increasingly complex. But it is also affecting more and more ordinary people in the community, people who are not lawyers, people who expect to have common sense and the intentions of the Parliament of this country taken into account when the court is asked to make a decision. It is ludicrous for the Parliament of this country, which is allegedly made up of ordinary people and not just lawyers-although I admit that there is a surfeit of them here at the moment-to pass legislation which it thinks it understands, which it believes has a specific purpose, intention and meaning only to find that those very people it is intended to apply to can avoid it, in the case of punitive legislation, or not make full use of it, in the case of legislation which is intended to assist them. An example of the first situation, of course, is the tax law. Any member of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills can refer to any number of examples relating to the second case.

SPEECH.PARA: Judicial interpretation is clearly important to protect the liberties and rights of the people and nobody is going to argue with that. But it should not act, however unwittingly or coincidentally, to subvert the intention of the Parliament which passed the Act. Section 15AA, as I have already said, has gone some way towards correcting that. The use of specific and special memoranda as a second step to ensuring that the spirit of the law and the intentions of lawmakers-that is, members of parliament-are taken into account, is welcomed by me and by my party. I too, commend the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) and his Department for their efforts in this regard.
Debate (on motion by Senator Chaney) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the resumption of the debate be made an Order of the Day for the next day of sitting.
By way of explanation, I think it would be a pity if this matter were not available for more detailed debate at a later time. That is why I wished to adjourn the debate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Proposed Tabling of Papers: Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On 22 September 1982 the Government tabled 85 documents relating to straw companies and the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act 1980 arising from the debate in the Senate on 9 September 1982. One category of documents tabled included advice from the Commissioner of Taxation, correspondence between Ministers, departmental minutes and other material which even on the most generous interpretation of what might have been tabled in the fullest freedom of information legislation would not normally have been available. There has been this very wide disclosure because the Government appreciates the public interest involved.

SPEECH.PARA: The documents tabled included also three opinions by counsel. As to other legal opinions, a police investigation report and departmental legal advice that were sought, the Solicitor-General advised that their release would be harmful to the administration of justice. He stated that harm, in his view, would be caused both to those who may be prosecuted and to those who may be proceeded against civilly, or to the cause of the prosecutor or civil complainant. In many instances both sides would be injured. He stated also that injury could not, in his view, be avoided by excising names.

The Senate nevertheless by its resolution of 23 September 1982 resolved that the documents withheld should be tabled, and indeed at the last moment added a further document to the list, consisting of the report of a Taxation investigation officer in a bottom-of-the-harbour scheme. The tabling of the papers referred to in the resolution was specifically stated to be 'subject to' the editing of the papers by the Royal Commissioner, Mr Costigan, in consultation with the Crown Solicitor, to ensure that no material is published which would prejudice the conduct of legal proceedings against those involved in tax evasion and avoidance schemes. The resolution raises a number of important issues and it calls for a considered Government response, even if, for reasons to which I shall now refer, the terms of the resolution have been rendered inoperative.
Editing of Documents by Royal Commissioner Costigan

When the Senate resumed earlier this week, the President of the Senate tabled a letter dated 8 October from the Royal Commissioner, Mr Costigan, in which he has confirmed the view that I had already indicated to the Senate when the Senate resolution was being debated on 23 September last. I shall refer to that view in the words Mr Costigan has used in his letter.

When I was originally advised of the suggestion which ultimately found expression in the Senate resolution I indicated that in my view it was both inappropriate to my present Commission and indeed beyond my terms of reference to undertake such a role.
In view of the resolution of the Senate I have given further consideration to this matter. Such consideration has not changed my opinion.
I must therefore with great respect to the Senate resolution decline the invitation implicit in it.
I also seek leave to have the whole of Mr Costigan's letter incorporated in Hansard as an appendix to this statement.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Mr Costigan's reply speaks for itself and needs no gloss from me except to note the obvious, which is that as the Senate's resolution is expressed to be 'subject to' the editing of the document in question by Mr Costigan, and as Mr Costigan has declined that invitation, the terms of the resolution have become inoperative. I have already mentioned that I indicated to the Senate, before it passed the resolution, that this was a view Mr Costigan had already expressed when approached by the Attorney-General ( Senator Durack) on 10 September 1982.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Costigan's letter refers to his terms of reference. The role envisaged by the resolution would not be an appropriate one to graft on to the present terms of reference of the Royal Commission. A totally new kind of inquiry would be involved. It would give the Royal Commission a totally new character and burden it with functions that could interfere with its performance of the role for which it was appointed. It appears on the face of it quite inappropriate to ask a royal commission to inquire into, and report to the Governor-General on, the matters referred to in the resolution.
Constitutional Issues

The resolution, however, raises wider issues of a constitutional character which any Government mindful of its responsibilities under the Constitution would be bound to raise, whatever its complexion and whatever the particular issues involved might be.

Section 61 of the Constitution commits the enforcement of the laws of the Commonwealth to the Executive Government. It is part of that constitutionally assigned responsibility to conduct prosecutions as appropropriate and to recover outstanding tax. It is a further part of that same responsibility to decide what government documents of a legal or investigative character can properly be released in the public interest so as not to prejudice the conduct of legal proceedings that may be brought against alleged offenders against the laws of the Commonwealth. The Government is under the further obligation not to prejudice the fair trial of any alleged defendant by the release of information that might reasonably be considered to be prejudicial to his fair trial.

That responsibility may be qualified by legislation passed by both Houses of Parliament and assented to by the Crown, but that does not affect the basic position. That legislation then becomes one of the laws the Executive Government should enforce and maintain. Subject, however, to such legislation, the manner, the method and the means of executing and maintaining Commonwealth laws are matters for the Executive Government to decide, subject of course to the conventions of responsibile government. So much was said very plainly by Mr Justice Isaacs in New South Wales v The Commonwealth (1915) 20 Commonwealth Law Reports, at page 89.

Yet on one reading the basis upon which the Senate resolution has been constructed and passed is that the decision on these matters can be assigned, against the wishes of the constitutionally appointed repository of the function, to some third person. The resolution referred to Mr Costigan. Another suggestion made in the debate was the Ombudsman, Professor J. Richardson. The Government's extensive inquiries on the matter have not been able to unearth any precedent for such a resolution in these particular terms or to like effect, either in the Australian Parliament, or in the House of Commons.

Quite apart from precedents, a very serious constitutional issue arises as to whether a resolution of this kind is within the powers of either House of the Parliament. It raises the kind of issue that was referred to by the High Court in the Boilermakers Case (1956) 94 CLR, at page 277, where the following comments of Professor Harrison Moore were adopted:

In the case of the Commonwealth Parliament it is impossible to avoid the conclusion that the separation of powers was intended to establish legal limitations on the powers of the organs of government, and that the Courts are required to address themselves to the problem of defining the functions of those organs.
We are dealing here not with a claim of Senate privilege versus Executive privilege but a question of the separation of powers.

In the light of these considerations, it is interesting to note that the motion by Senator Evans at present before the Senate-it is yet to be dealt with and I will mention it at the end of my speech; Senator Evans had notice of a motion yesterday and it is that motion to which I refer-only 'requests' the Government that the editorial role envisaged by the tabling resolution of 23 September be performed by a third person outside government. That formula is, I believe, the more constitutionally appropriate way for the Senate to address matters of this kind.

However, in another respect the latest motion labours under similar difficulties. It seeks to involve the Federal Judiciary in the exercise of Executive responsibility, and in fact compounds the problems to which I have referred by proposing that the Chief Judge of the Federal Court nominate a Federal Judge to perform a non-judicial function of a plainly executive character. Perhaps some analogy with the role of Judges in dealing with claims of Crown privilege in litigation between parties is being relied on. If so, I would point out that the interests in that situation are very different from those involved in the case of a difference of views between the Executive and a House of Parliament. Also, the suggestion does not solve the problem of the separation of powers. As I have said, it only compounds it.
Role of Solicitor-General and Commissioner of Taxation

As I observed in the debate in the Senate on 23 September there is agreement in the Senate, in the broad, that it would be accepted by all honourable senators from all parts of the chamber that nothing should be tabled that would prejudice proceedings that may be brought against persons guilty of tax evasion or avoidance. I should add to the circulated statement that there would also be common ground between us that nothing should be tabled which would prejudice the proper defence of proceedings brought either civilly or criminally.

The issues are the narrower ones of whose opinion should be accepted for this purpose and also, what tests should be applied. Senator Evans acknowledged in debate on 23 September 1982 that he is on record about the ability of the Solicitor-General, Sir Maurice Byers, and his freedom from political bias. I do not want to take the time of the Senate in repeating at length what I have already said in the earlier debate on this topic on 23 September 1982. However, I should mention again that, quite apart from the professional independence and integrity of a person of his eminence and standing, the Solicitor-General is an independent statutory officer appointed under the Law Officers Act 1964.

The Government does not propose to table documents that, on the advice received from the Solicitor-General, would be harmful to the administration of justice. In view of the very special and sensitive character, however, of the document referred to in item 12 of the Senate resolution of 23 September, I interpolate that that is the investigator's report to the Commissioner of Taxation-the Government has considered it appropriate to refer the question of its tabling to the Commissioner of Taxation. The document referred to consists of the report of a taxation investigation officer into a bottom-of-the-harbour scheme. The Government believes that it should accept the views of the Commissioner of Taxation on that document, which briefly are that even with sanitising and editing, the tabling of the document in any meaningful form would offend against section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. I seek leave to incorporate the Commissioner's statement as an appendix to this statement.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just to add to the sense of the statement I am making to the Senate now, I must quote one further sentence from the statement of the Commissioner of Taxation. He states:

SPEECH.PARA: It is a document which, by its very nature, reveals the whole substance of the case that might be made against certain people and in my view-
That is, the Commissioner's view-
its tabling would be even more damaging to future prospects of prosecution action than the tabling of legal opinions.

So there is a twofold objection to the tabling of that document-the possible infringement of section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act and the prejudice to the prosecution which might be brought with respect to a particular bottom-of- the-harbour scheme.
Test to be Applied

The Senate resolution of 23 September was specifically amended just before its adoption to refer to the exclusion only of materials that would, not might, prejudice the conduct of legal proceedings against those involved in tax evasion and avoidance schemes. While the Solicitor-General has advised that some of the documents in question could with sanitising and editing be tabled under the test in the resolution, he has further advised that other documents could not be tabled even under that test. Also, I have confirmed personally with the Solicitor-General that he is still of the opinion that in the case of all the documents he previously examined their tabling would be harmful to the administration of justice in the sense I referred to at the opening of this statement. It is the Government and not the Senate that bears the responsibility for the enforcement and maintenance of the laws of the Commonwealth and for ensuring that appropriate steps are taken for the bringing of proceedings, civil and criminal, that are presently contemplated in relation to tax evasion. It is idle to think that this is a responsibility that the Executive Government can properly abdicate to this House or some third person. The Government's decision remains that it should take account of the advice expressed by the Solicitor- General and referred to on the tabling of documents on 23 September last.

I trust and expect that the reasons for this position will be understood and appreciated. It would be easy enough in one sense to table all the documents. As was indicated on 22 September, the legal opinions are not all one way. However, as the Treasurer (Mr Howard) stated at the outset, the only appropriate course the Government can take is to accept and act on the views of the Solicitor- General. As to document 12, it believes it must act on the view expressed by the Commissioner of Taxation. The wider issues I have raised have not been referred to in any spirit of confrontation. It would be remiss of any Government not to raise them having regard to the responsibilities of the Executive Government for the enforcement and maintenance of the laws of the Commonwealth.

If I may return briefly to a passage on page 4 of the statement, I repeat that it is part of that constitutionally assigned responsibility to conduct prosecutions as appropriate and to recover outstanding tax. It is a further part of that same responsibility to decide what government documents of a legal or investigative character can properly be released in the public interest so as not to prejudice the conduct of legal proceedings that may be brought against alleged offenders against the laws of the Commonwealth. The Government is under the further obligation not to prejudice the fair trial of any alleged defendant by the release of information that might reasonably be considered to be prejudicial to his fair trial. I commend those reasons for the consideration of the Senate.

It has been agreed between the Government and the Opposition that there be a cognate debate on this statement and general business notice of motion No. 63 in the name of Senator Evans. Once this statement and the motion that the Senate take note of the statement are dealt with, I shall be moving to rearrange the order of business to enable Senator Evans to move his motion. In other words, it is proposed that we should have a cognate debate which effectively debates both the statement I have put down and the motion to take note of it and the motion which will be brought up, subject to the concurrence of the Senate, for vote later today, that is, the motion to be moved by Senator Evans to amend the original motion to which I have responded in this statement.
The documents read as follows-
ROYAL COMMISSION ON THE ACTIVITIES OF THE FEDERATED SHIP PAINTERS AND DOCKERS UNION
Commissioner: Mr. F. X. Costigan Q.C. G.P.O. Box 262C, Melbourne, 3001 Secretary : Mr. G. Hutton Telephone: 529 2244

CANBERRA, ACT, 2600
My dear Attorney,
I acknowledge receipt of your letter of 6 October enclosing a letter from the Clerk of the Senate to the Leader of the Government in the Senate.
The Clerk's letter sets out the terms of a resolution agreed to by the Senate on 23 September.

When I was originally advised of the suggestion which ultimately found expression in the Senate resolution I indicated that in my view it was both inappropriate to my present Commission and indeed beyond my terms of reference to undertake such a role.
In view of the resolution of the Senate I have given further consideration to this matter. Such consideration has not changed my opinion.
I must therefore with great respect to the Senate resolution decline the invitation implicit in it. I do so, however, with an appreciation of the compliment paid to me by the Senate.
I would ask you to pass this letter to the Leader of the Government in the Senate with a request that he in turn pass it on to the Clerk of the Senate.
