STATEMENT BY COMMISSIONER OF TAXATION IN RELATION TO DOCUMENT 12

The amended motion carried by the Senate on 23 September 1982 calls for the tabling of a document-Document No. 12-which was not covered by the original motion. This document is an 18 page report by a senior investigation officer to the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation in Perth.
I have carefully read this document and am of the opinion that it cannot be tabled.

The document is an internal working document prepared within the Australian Taxation Office dealing with a particular company's affairs. It contains a full narrative of the case, details of evidentiary material and of admissions made on which a prosecution might be based and it canvasses the legal arguments available to support a prosecution. It contains several pages of verbatim evidence obtained during an interview of a person by a police inspector. It is a document which, by its very nature, reveals the whole substance of the case that might be made against certain people and in my view its tabling would be even more damaging to future prospects of prosecution action than the tabling of legal opinions.

Section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act provides that an officer shall not, except in the performance of any duty as an officer, communicate to any person any information acquired as an officer. It is my view that I am prohibited by this provision from releasing the document in its complete form for the purpose apparently envisaged by the motion. In addition, it is a fact that a great many people are aware of the identity of the particular case dealt with. In these circumstances any deletions from, or alterations to, the document to conceal identities of people would not solve the problem and it is unavoidable that any information at all provided in a so-called ''sanitized'' version would offend against section 16.

There is also the further point that if the document suffered such deletions and alterations as would be necessary to meet the requirements of section 16 the result would be that what was left would be insufficient to convey much, if any, sense to a reader.
I repeat that I am of the opinion that the document cannot be tabled and I hope that the Parliament can accept my submission on this point.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney), taking the high constitutional ground that it does, reminds me of nothing so much as one of those fog machines that were traditionally used on movie sets, cranking out on cue great thick clouds of artificial smoke, designed to obscure key elements in the scene and add a general air of mystery to it at the same time. There is nothing in that statement which should deter the Senate from continuing on the course on which it has embarked, nor will we on this side of the chamber be deterred.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me at the outset remind the Senate of the particular documents which are the subject of the resolution of 23 September. I remind the Senate also why we are seeking them and why it is in the Government's political interest not to provide them. The 14 groups of documents fall into two main classes. On the one hand, there are legal opinions obtained from Queen's Counsel and others which, with one or two exceptions, appear likely, on the evidence of the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, to amount to strongly and persuasively argued reasons for believing that legal proceedings could have been taken under the existing law against the participants in bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. The second class of documents is a miscellany of letters and memoranda written mainly by officers of the Attorney-General's Department which, on the evidence of the Costigan report again, are likely to amount to a quite inadequate explanation of why proceedings could not have been taken.

It seems, then, likely that the tabling of the documents will profoundly embarrass the Government in several interrelated ways. It will reveal, as I said on 23 September, that the Government had strategy open to it under the existing law, that it could have actually prosecuted under the existing law but it did not; that it could have run civil proceedings under the existing law to recover the taxes in question but it did not; that it did have well and cogently argued opinions and memoranda arguing that such proceedings could proceed and that it did not have well and cogently argued opinions and memoranda arguing the contrary, just a series of bleating ex post rationalisations from senior officials to justify their inaction. The credibility of the Government very much hangs upon the quality of those legal opinions and the contents of those documents. Its lack of credibility will stand nakedly revealed if those documents are in fact put down.

What weapons, what armour has the Government then mobilised to protect itself against this possible embarrassment? It seems to me that in the course of the ministerial statement we have five separate propositions advanced, and I want to spend my time going through them in turn. The first proposition is that the Costigan response has rendered the resolution of the Senate inoperative. The second proposition is that no document can be tabled in this case without prejudice to the administration of justice. The third proposition is that Parliament should accept the decision of the Solicitor-General without demur on these matters. The fourth proposition, and here we get on to the high ground, is that it is wrong of Parliament to seek to exercise, itself or through some third person delegate, functions which properly belong to the Executive. The final proposition is that it is wrong of Parliament to purport to delegate the functions in question, in particular to a sitting judge.

Let us go through each of those in turn. The first proposition is that the Costigan response has rendered the Senate resolution inoperative. This is said in Senator Chaney's statement with all the sense of triumph of Little Jack Horner sitting in his corner pulling out his thumb with a plum on top of it. Of course that point was conceded by the Opposition, as the text of the notice of motion that I gave yesterday makes perfectly clear. It is necessary for the terms of the Senate resolution to be amended or supplemented if it is to have practical effect. What we are seeking to do in the motion of which I gave notice yesterday, and will formally move-I hope to have the question put on it at the conclusion of this debate-is just that.

The second proposition is that no document, it is said, can be tabled without prejudice to the administration of justice. The concept of the administration of justice is used by the Minister here, as it was in the original Government response, in a kind of shifting, sliding way to accommodate almost anything the Government wants it to. The administration of justice has become almost synonomous in the Government's usage of it in this statement with the concept of 'truth, justice and the Australian way'. What we mean by the administration of justice, and the sense in which we are employing that term, and the Senate employed that term in passing the resolution of 23 September, is the prejudice or otherwise to legal proceedings. It is in that narrower sense, which we believe is the only appropriate sense in the context of which this debate should proceed, that we press the point. We regard the only relevant criterion-it is a wide-ranging one-as being that specified in the terms of the motion; namely, would the tabling of the documents in unedited form prejudice the conduct of legal proceedings against those involved in tax avoidance and evasion schemes. Of course I add in parenthesis that there are a number of ways in which proceedings can be prejudiced and blatant unfairness to an accused person may well be a ground for aborting a trial. A number of aspects of the Government's concern are accommodated within that narrower language that I insist, and the Senate has so far insisted, should be the language used as the criterion.

The Senate majority never had any desire to interfere with the administration of justice in this sense. That is why we have been concerned to have the filter mechanism that is proposed in that resolution. That is why we want to have someone, independently of politics and independently of the executive filtering the documents, making this decision, in order to avoid any possibility of there being such prejudice.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be an awfully mangled document by the time it has been edited, sanitised and filtered.

—There will still be enough to embarrass the Government, Senator Haines, so I do not think there is too much to worry about in that respect. That is why the resistance is being mounted. There will be sufficient substance left, I am sure, to make the point that we are all interested in seeing made, and to ensure that the truth is revealed. We have also been prepared to conceed that of course it is possible that on examination some of the documents will fail this test of prejudice to proceedings but it is also perfectly likely that a good many of them will pass it in one form or another. So much is acknowledged in the ministerial statement at page 8 where the following passage appears:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Solicitor-General has advised that some of the documents in question could with sanitizing and editing be tabled under the test in the resolution . . .

I repeat that the Solicitor-General advised that some of these documents could, with sanitising and editing, be tabled under the test in the resolution. So it has been acknowledged even on the Government side that the test is not an unreasonable one by reference to the criterion in question. Why on earth is the Government holding back? I suggest the reasons speak for themselves.

The third proposition is that the Parliament should accept without demur the opinion of the Solicitor-General in respect of the application of this test of prejudice to proceedings. This is a question which we argued at length the last time this matter was debated and no more than Senator Chaney do I propose to repeat what I said in this place on 23 September. It is no disrespect to the ability, character or position of Sir Maurice Byers to say, as we have said and I say again, that he is simply too close to the Executive in this matter. He must be regarded as being an officer of the Executive for all practical purposes and, indeed, his role as an officer of the Executive becomes important as a part of the Government's later argument. We would further say, as we have said before , that we believe that in this instance, no doubt in perfectly good faith, he has erred on the side of caution. It is for those reasons, which I have spelt out at greater length-I do not repeat them now-that I believe he is an inappropriate person to act as the once and for all filter in this respect.

We now come to the high ground, the constitutional argument-the argument that it is wrong of Parliament to seek to exercise itself or through some third person acting as a parliamentary delegate functions which properly belong to the Executive; that this amounts to some breach, according to Senator Chaney, of the separation of powers doctrine. Let me say at the outset that the whole argument of the Minister and the Government is founded on a false premise, the false premise being that the Senate is seeking, itself, to 'enforce the laws of the Commonwealth'. Of course the Senate by this resolution is not seeking to do anything of that kind at all. Rather, it is seeking the tabling of papers, as it has done on numerous occasions-it is set out for the record in Odgers at page 585-in order to determine for itself whether the Executive arm has been discharging its constitutional responsibility to enforce and maintain the laws. It is because of the profound suspicion not only on this side of the Parliament but also in the community at large that the Executive has not been performing its functions in relation to the maintenance and enforcement of the revenue laws that the legislature, the Senate, has been led to take the present course of action-to exercise its constitutional function as part of the legislature to demand accountability to it by the Executive.

It is for those reasons-they are central to the argument-that we are seeking these papers. Indeed, tucked away on page 5 of the statement as it was circulated by the Minister, it is acknowledged that anything that the Executive does in its law enforcement role is subject to the conventions of responsible government. I know that those conventions are rather sick under the present administration, but I cannot believe that they are being torn up entirely and that we are having asserted to us today by the Minister a denial of the legislature's role in seeking that degree of accountability and responsibility from the Executive. On this same point, on page 4 of the ministerial statement the extraordinary suggestion is made that in calling for these papers but at the same time seeking to provide for an independent check to ensure that no harm is done to the public interest, the Parliament-the Senate-is itself 'deciding what Government documents of a legal or Executive character can be relevant' and that this is an exercise of the Executive law enforcement power, argued to be, constitutionally speaking, an improper exercise of that power.

There is so much fudging and so much conceptual confusion rolled up into that particular part of the ministerial statement that it is very difficult to untangle it. All I can really do is put two propositions. In the first place, for the Senate to require, by way of direction or through the delegation of the function, the release of papers in the way it is doing, can hardly itself be a law enforcement function. That proposition is so obvious as to hardly bear assertion in that form but, extraordinarily enough, that does seem to be what is being asserted by the ministerial statement. I add the rider that it seems to me that whether or not that function is performed directly by the Senate itself or by someone acting on the Senate's direction or at its request makes no difference to the force of that basic proposition. The mere seeking of the tabling of papers can hardly be the exercise, in any credible sense, of a law enforcement function.

The second thing I would say, and it is a very important proposition, is this: There may be some room in this whole matter for a claim by the Executive of Executive privilege to the extent that it can plausibly be claimed that the public interest is somehow at risk in relation to the tabling of some or all of these papers in an edited or unedited fashion. It may be that, given the quite rapid development of the law of Executive privilege in this area in recent years in cases such as the Sankey case, the defence papers case and the more recent Northern Territory case, the question of what the Executive can and cannot refuse to produce could fall ultimately for determination in the courts. That may be the case. But that consideration cannot operate right now at the threshold to deny the Parliament the power to require the production of documents in the first place.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is why I did not argue it.

—To make any such claim-and I have no doubt whatsoever, despite the interjection, that that is the claim being made in the ministerial statement -is to turn both law and convention on their head and to do so, of course, for a transparent political purpose.

SPEECH.PARA: I make one further point in relation to this argument about the separation of powers. Even if we accept, as I do not, that the Parliament here is somehow seeking to exercise itself an Executive function, it really is just claiming too much for the constitutional doctrine of the separation of powers as that doctrine is developed in Australia, to say that this in itself constitutes an absolute barrier to the Senate taking the action in question such as the Executive is entitled to resist. It is notorious that while the judicial power has been kept rigorously separate, and under the separation of powers doctrine as it is developed in Australia, not that that doctrine in the Boilermakers' Case and so on is uncontroversial, it is not the case that anything like the same stringency is involved in the separation of legislative and Executive power . The Executive has always, and without serious challenge, exercised certain legislative functions with its delegated legislation making role, and the legislature, of course, particularly these days with the operation of the investigative committee system, exercises many functions which are not remotely of a strictly legislative or law making character. The whole argument, the attempt to invent a new constitutional doctrine of separation of powers to justify the Government's failure to respond here, I think collapses in ignominy.

The final leg of the argument as it is put by Senator Chaney is that it is wrong of the Parliament in particular to purport to delegate its functions to a sitting practising judge. This is another high ground constitutional point that is being taken, not just an ordinary, common, garden debating point-we have moved beyond that in this particular statement today. It is argued that it is a separation of powers breach to 'nominate a Federal Court judge to perform a non- judicial function of a plainly Executive character'.

Let me make it clear that I am not denying for a moment that the function that the Senate has been endeavouring to designate of editing these papers is a non- judicial one within the meaning of that doctrine as it has evolved. I have no doubt that it is not an exercise of judicial power, properly so-called, that we are here seeking to have exercised. But so too was Sir Owen Dixon's acceptance of his wartime job as ambassador to the United States of America a non-judicial function; so too is Mr Justice Fox's acceptance of the chairmanship of the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry; so too is every judge's acceptance of a royal commission to investigate and report upon matters on behalf of the Executive.

Judges are constantly being asked to take off their wigs-in the case of Mr Justice Murphy I suppose one has to say his notional wig-and exercise at the request of one or other of the other branches of government non-judicial functions. There is even a phrase that has evolved in law to describe this state of affairs of which Mr Brazil was kind enough to remind me in the corridors outside the chamber today. When a judge is so acting he is acting as a person a designata. He is not acting as a judge. When he is acting as President of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, when he is holding and exercising a royal commission, when he is given a diplomatic job, as judges occasionally have been, he is not exercising his role as a judge; he has taken off his judicial hat and is wearing another one for this purpose. That is exactly, of course, what is being sought to be accomplished in the motion that I will later be moving-to get a judge to take off his judicial hat and to do a particular job which he or she as a judge will be peculiarly well equipped to do on behalf of the Parliament.

There is, of course, some doubt about the willingness of judges, particularly Federal Court judges, to accept these roles. There will be some doubt about their willingness to accept these roles in the future in the aftermath of the contemptible attempt by the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, to discredit Mr Justice Woodward recently in the meat inquiry-discredit, I might add, which reflected on nobody but the Prime Minister and the Government in the result. But the motion that I will be formally moving at the conclusion of this debate, having given notice of it yesterday, is a form of request to the Federal Court which is expressed as a request because we on this side of the chamber believe that it is both inappropriate and impolite to seek to direct judges or anyone else for that matter to perform the functions in question.

We hope that the Federal Court will comply with a resolution which is a solemn and a deliberate expression of the Senate's views and desires in this matter. But in the event that that does not come to pass, the further possibility is canvassed in my motion that a retired judge might be requested and nominated by formal process to perform that particular function. In the event that that becomes necessary we will cross that particular procedural bridge when we come to it. Certainly, of course, if we do resort to a retired judge in this particular way nobody can possibly object if there is any exercise of judicial power in any technical sense being there involved.

What I have said I hope is sufficient to demonstrate that, despite the very orotund way in which this statement by the Minister has been both compiled and presented, it really is just a not especially clever little exercise in dissimulated design to protect the Government from profound political embarrassment. The Government's and the Minister's constitutional arguments are nonsense and simply a smokescreen to hide the Government's political embarrassment. If there is any constitutional issue involved here it is the right of this Parliament to demand accountability from the Executive as to its stewardship in law enforement matters as in everything else and to require the tabling of all papers, subject to overriding considerations of public interest, which will demonstrate the quality of that Executive performance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think that the 1975 calling of the Solicitor-General to the Bar of the Senate is in the same category?

—One has to approach all questions of Executive accountability to the Parliament on a case by case basis. One has to look at both the motives of those who are seeking the accountability, seeking the evidence in question and the motives of those who are seeking to deny access to that particular material. The principles of Executive accountability and the principles of Executive privilege cut both ways. I readily acknowledge that there may be circumstances, and I have acknowledged in the course of this speech today that there are circumstances, in which Executive privilege can properly be claimed as it was claimed in 1975. But I also assert that there are circumstances where it is improperly claimed and claimed for spurious political reasons. I also assert, and this has been the nub of what I have been saying here today, that there is no question of some larger constitutional principle of the kind that is sought to be invented by the Government and its advisers which would in effect cut off this kind of exercise at the knees and in effect deny in the law enforcement area, or any other area that the Government chooses to invent, to add to the list if the mood so strikes it, the very possibility of such accountability being demanded. The Government cannot seriously expect us to stop pursuing this issue. I can assure it, on behalf of the Opposition, that we will not. The passage of my motion, which I hope will occur later today, will enable a further step to be taken in what has already, of course, become an unnecessarily protracted process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: — There are a number of aspects of the document before us today which are disturbing, not the least of which is the fact that it is so at variance with the document which was tabled in this chamber not an hour ago, which deliberately sets out to narrow the gap between the judiciary and the Parliament as far as the legislation and the Parliament's intentions are concerned and which aims specifically at directing the judiciary to take note of the intentions of the Parliament. Here we have a situation which is almost totally the reverse of that in which the Government is actively preventing, or attempting to prevent, the judiciary from getting involved in something which is of considerable concern to this Parliament, certainly to the Senate. I was concerned too at the sanctimonious and somewhat arrogant tone that pervades this document. I was concerned, as was the previous speaker, Senator Evans, at the often specious, generally misconceived and almost entirely tortuous arguments that were put forward in support of the Government's case.

SPEECH.PARA: Those misconceptions begin, in fact, with what appears to me to be a doubtful reading by Mr Costigan of what the Senate requested in its original resolution. In his letter which was appended to the Government's paper, Mr Costigan maintained that it was inappropriate to his present role as commissioner and beyond his terms of reference to undertake the role of editing, laundering, sanitising or filtering-whatever term one desires to put on it-the documents that the Senate has asked for. Mr Costigan said:
I must therefore with great respect to the Senate resolution decline the invitation implicit in it.

The Senate did not extend an invitation to Mr Costigan. The Senate instructed the Government to undertake certain action; namely, to arrange or to attempt to arrange with Mr Costigan, if he was available, for the editing of the documents that were mentioned on 23 September by Senator Evans. He was not asked to act in his capacity as royal commissioner, but because of the expertise that he has attained in the area of tax evasion, bottom-of-the-harbour schemes and so on. His declining, courteous though it was, would seem to be to be based on a misconception-I am sure not a deliberate one-of the intention of the Senate's original motion which was, as I said, a direction to the Government. The fact that certain parts of that motion which are referred to as 'subject to' sections were not able to be fulfilled does not invalidate the intention of the Senate in moving its original motion. The second statement that seems to be somewhat specious in its basis comes from the Commissioner of Taxation, again in relation to the documents that the Senate asked to have tabled. The Commissioner of Taxation said:
Section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act provides that an officer shall not, except in the performance of any duty as an officer, communicate to any person any information acquired as an officer.

I would have thought that an officer could act on an instruction from the Government that he produce the document in an edited, sanitised or laundered form in accordance with the performance of his duty. I found it more forceful for the Commissioner of Taxation to argue that it would be prejudicial to produce a document in an unedited form and pointless to produce it in an edited form. I am far more persuaded by that argument than any specious one that relates to section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

In addition to the arguments put by Mr Costigan and Mr O'Reilly, a series of arguments was put to us by the Government. I wish to deal with these in what I consider to be the order of importance-certainly not in order of weight-since there are probably more notable for their arrogance and tortuousness than for their validity. The first of those arguments is that there is no precedent for this impertinent action by the Senate. It would seem rather strange to me for anybody, but particularly a lawyer, to argue that because there is no precedent we cannot do something. We would all be stuck in the dark ages if we acted simply according to whether something had or had not been done before.

The second argument put forward is one which I have already partially dealt with. It concerns the original motion which contains 'subject to' clauses which could not be fulfilled. Therefore, the Senate is supposed to lick its wounds and retire suitably defeated. I maintain, as I think the previous speaker maintained , that simply because Mr Costigan apparently misunderstood the intention of the original motion and because that section of the motion was not fulfilled, there is no requirement on the Senate that it cannot pursue the matter. Having been frustrated once is no justification for throwing in the towel. It has the right to press on in its attempt to fulfill its own constitutional responsibilities of review and oversight of legislation and the maintenance and execution of that legislation.

The third argument that the Government put for refusing to table the documents was the separation of powers and responsibilities between the judiciary and the Executive, which would apparently be infringed upon if the amended motion of Senator Evans were accepted. Yet, as Senator Evans has already pointed out, that did not stop the Government from commissioning the services and the expertise of Mr Justice Fox or Mr Justice Woodward. To argue that this was done only with the approval of the Government is rather to miss the point that, in fact, the judiciary does have a role to play in these sorts of areas regardless of the feelings of the government of the day.

The most important argument put by the Government for refusing to table the documents in any form, edited or otherwise, is that the Senate is attempting to usurp the responsibilities of the Executive Government under section 61 of the Constitution. This is absolute and arrant nonsense. Section 61 of the Constitution invests responsibilities and powers in and with the Executive Government, but the Parliament itself-in this instance the Senate-also has responsibilities and powers enshrined in the Constitution. Those powers include reviewing the administrative and legislative behaviour of the Government and questioning any failures that it has to fulfil its own section 61 responsibilities. Otherwise there would be no point in having legislative and general purpose committees. There would be no point in having Estimates committees and the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills.

In effect, what we have in the papers before us today is the Government saying: 'We have certain responsibilities but if we choose not to exercise these, if we choose not to execute the laws of the Commonwealth, as we are expected to under section 61, no one, much less the Senate, can make us probe into why we have not done it or even establish if we have not done it. No one can question us. The Parliament has no right to question our lack of action or apparent lack of action or to ask us to prove that we have or have not acted as fully as possible in accordance with existing laws'. I suggest that that is central to the issue in front of us.

The request for these documents to be tabled boils down to this: The Senate, as is the other place, is soon to be faced with passing or rejecting new legislation which is aimed at prosecuting tax evaders. Yet we are being denied the documents which would indicate whether that legislation is even necessary, whether previous legislation was adequate to prosecute offenders under a variety of sections, including sections 160, 170 and 201 of the Income Tax Assessment Act and a variety of other sections, and whether the new legislation, which has been removed from the Notice Paper and which is to be attended to, laundered, filtered, sanitised or whatever by the Government, is only a face saving exercise on the part of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) to cover the fact that the Government has failed to act in the past, and, therefore, failed to fulfil its constitutional responsibility. Whether this Government likes it or not, the Executive is accountable to Parliament. Nothing in section 61 alters that. There is no reason why a Federal judge could not be commissioned to edit the requested documents. Therefore, the Democrats fully support the motion on this subject that Senator Evans is contemplating moving in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier in the debate Senator Evans made reference to the importance of statutory interpretation, even though that may be a somewhat legalistic concept. I agree with those comments but would like to say how important is the debate that we are having today, even though there are not many honourable senators in the chamber. This again may appear to be a legalistic debate but it is of considerable concern to this nation. I must say that when I heard Senator Evans's opening remarks I could not help thinking, 'Ah , we appear to be taking some steps along the route that was taken in 1975. Of course, it will be for the Opposition and the Democrats to decide how far down that path we go, but certainly from Senator Evans's opening remarks it seems that we might be going somewhere along it'.
—Does that prospect appal you?

—As far as I am concerned, it is a matter of politics. I observe that two very interesting matters arise from Senator Evans's proposals and the statement made today by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) on behalf of the Acting Attorney-General (Mr N. A. Brown). It seems to me, firstly, that we have here an extension of the working relationship between the Executive and the legislature in relation to the privilege question, in ensuring that material not to be released if so doing may prejudice the conduct of certain legal proceedings. I believe that represents an extension of the question of privilege, or working relationships, as it was described in a paper to which I will refer later. Also, we have had this very interesting proposition by the Government regarding the separation of powers. It seems to me, with respect, that Senator Evans and Senator Haines have confused the question of tabling the documents with the question of editing them. Sir Maurice Byers has said that the tabling of the documents would be harmful to the administration of justice. I shall come to that question later. The request that Senator Evans has made to the Senate is not only that a judge should vet or inspect the documents but also that the judge should edit them. That is an executive act. It seems to me that is what Senator Chaney, on behalf of the Government, is asserting. The Minister said in his statement:

SPEECH.PARA: We are dealing here not with a claim of Senate privilege versus executive privilege but a question of the separation of powers.
I should like to examine that aspect, but certainly do not want to express a final view upon it. The Minister also stated:
Section 61 of the Constitution commits the enforcement of the laws of the Commonwealth to the Executive Government.
That seems to be a correct assertion. The Minister continued:
. . . the manner, the method and the means of executing and maintaining Commonwealth laws are matters for the Executive Government to decide . . .
Again, that seems to be a right and proper assertion. The Minister states further:
. . . on one reading-
The Minister refers to the motion-
. . . the basis upon which the Senate resolution has been constructed and passed is that the decision on these matters can be assigned . . . to some third person.

I take up with the Senate what I would call the interesting use, or perhaps even misuse, of the judiciary by executive governments all over Australia, both State and Federal, over a period dating back to the last century. That has been an increasing trend during the last decade or so. I refer the Senate to an essay by Professor G. S. Reid, Deputy Vice-Chancellor and Professor of Politics at the University of Western Australia, entitled, The Changing Political Framework. The essay was written in 1978 but was reproduced in the January-February 1980 issue of Quadrant. That is probably the most convenient place for people to look it up . I strongly urge honourable senators and others interested in these questions, which are of great political moment, to give consideration to the essay, which is certainly excellent. Professor Reid, in the final part of the essay, refers to the great changes in the law in recent years, to the establishment of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, of the Administrative Review Councils, of the office of the Ombudsman, of legal aid commissions, of the Law Reform Commission and of the Human Rights Commission. He states:

In the midst and in the wake of this reforming turmoil two interesting trends are discernible-the first I shall call 'Judicial Imperialism' and the second ' Executive Imperialism.' The trends are inter-related but both are changing the framework of government in Australia.
Professor Reid refers to the action of the Chief Justice in advising the Governor-General back in 1975 and says:
In this case the exercise of parliamentary power was subordinated to Executive power by the Governor-General with the public support of the Head of the Judiciary.
Then he refers to the cases of Cormack versus Cope in 1974 and Victoria versus the Commonwealth in 1975, and states:

Here the Court held that some sections of the Constitution relating to the process for passing legislation in Parliament, which previously had been held to be matters of parliamentary procedural concern and thus the privilege of Parliament, were in fact justiciable before the Court. Thus, the High Court expanded its jurisdiction into subject matters previously considered to belong to the sphere of parliamentary politics.
He goes on further to talk about judicial imperialism and states:-

. . . also relates to the interest displayed by the Judiciary in the evolution of the legal reforms presently surrounding us. There is an unprecedented judicial activism in policy-making in Australian Government. Judges are taking a prominent role in the activities of Law Reform Commissions throughout Australia, and their enthusiasm to participate is taking them into membership of a wide range of Executive Commissions, Tribunals and Councils.

. . . The Executive Government in Australia has long sought to use members of the Judiciary to its own advantage, particularly to take the Chair of governmental enquiries and Royal Commissions established to report on vexing and complex social and political problems.
He points out that Chief Justice Irvine of Victoria said as long ago as 1923:

The duty of His Majesty's Judges is to hear and determine issues of fact and of law arising between the King and a subject, or between a subject and a subject presented in a form enabling judgment to be passed upon them . . .
Finally, Professor Reid goes on to point out:
The practice is fraught with dangers for a fearlessly independent Judiciary.

It seems to me that Professor Reid, in this paper, raises matters of great moment which are, in fact, supported by Sir Zelman Cowen. In a speech made on 24 May 1982, shortly before he finished his term as Governor-General, Sir Zelman Cowen said:
We have been involved in a massive reshaping of the law arising out of the way in which public administration has developed in a complex modern federal society .
What we have done is to give sweeping authority in such matters to judges to substitute their own view of what is good policy or a more just outcome for that of elected or administrative officers.
Debate interrupted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The final paragraph of what Sir Zelman Cowen said that I wish to quote is this:

SPEECH.PARA: I think that what has been done in Australia in the way of administrative law reform is exciting, remarkable and impressive, but in some respects I wonder whether it has not gone too far.

Of course, that is the point that Professor Reid was making. I find myself in some agreement with the points made by Professor Reid and Sir Zelman Cowen. But I find here a government asserting, or should I say re-asserting, its belief in the separation of powers. It seems to me that that is a matter which ought to be encouraged by the Senate. The Government is asserting that its proper role is to govern-to govern without the aid of some judge imposed upon it by the Senate; to make these decisions itself and to be responsible for them. It seems to me that there is some considerable merit in that proposal. As to whether the proposal put by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) today in this paper is in fact the law, or the way the law ought to be, I think I would have to defer to another date before offering my final view on the subject because it seems to me to be a new development, an interesting development which I would like to encourage but which may require further debate and consideration not only in this place but also in academic circles. However, Senator Evans and Senator Haines went on to talk about the matter which the Minister said he was not putting forward; that was the question of Crown privilege or Executive privilege . I turn now to that matter. Odgers, in the fifth edition of Australian Senate Practice, states at page 562:
This fifth edition contends that the Executive Government enjoys no privilege which puts it above Parliament, . . .
Then, on page 563, he stated:

Certainly there are affairs which in the public interest, or for reasons of national security, should be kept confidential; Parliament recognises that principle and the practice is not to press for certain disclosures, such as in relation to Cabinet documents and advice given by officers to Ministers.

Those proposals put by Mr Odgers at that point seem to me to have been expanded, as I mentioned earlier, by the proposal which is contained in the resolution of the Senate, that material should not be published which might prejudice the conduct of legal proceedings.

I now turn to the famous dissenting report of Senators Greenwood, Webster and Wright on matters referred to the Senate by resolution of 17 July 1975 and published by the Senate on 7 October 1975 in which the powers of the Parliament as opposed to the powers of the Executive were dealt with at considerable length . Again, I have some quotations which I would like to read. Referring to the basic question of parliamentary-executive relations, on page 49 the dissenting reports states:

The core of the question is the fundamental relationship which exists, or should exist, between the parliamentary and executive arms of government-a matter which is so fundamental to Parliament, and so steeped in the history of the Westminster style of parliamentary democracy, that it should not be overlooked.
The dissenting report went on to support the supremacy of the Parliament over the Executive. On page 50 the report states:
There may be some who would suggest that such a power is appropriate to a Lower House, but not to an Upper House.
. . . Such a suggestion clearly has no place in the Australian Commonwealth Parliament

Although Senator Evans would not say that he would have adopted this proposal, I think what he was putting today was very much along those lines. I would not disagree with the assertion put by this dissenting report. But it seems to me that the next paragraph of that dissenting report contains matters of fundamental importance to the Senate in its debate today. It states:

This assertion of power leads to the next basic issue-one which again goes to the core of the present matter-and that is the perennial problem, inherent in the possession of power, as to the exercise of power. The closer power comes to the absolute, the more difficult is the decision as to the proper exercise of it . Parliament's power-or, in this case, the power of each House of the Parliament -is paramount, but its exercise must be a matter of particular discretion. That this is so is evidenced by the 'working relationships' which have been developed over centuries of parliamentary experience, and it perhaps is proper to treat what has been described as Crown privilege as a working relationship between the legislative and executive arms of government.

We now turn to the fundamental question raised by Senator Evans and Senator Haines today-not by the Minister-and that is the question of whether, presuming that the Senate has the power to require the tabling of the documents, the power should be exercised. On that point I should like to draw attention to the motion which Senator Evans has proposed. It is a conditional request; in other words, the documents should not be produced if they might or would-I think he changed the word 'might' to 'would' which I think was to the detriment of the motion- prejudice the conduct of legal proceedings.

Sir Maurice Byers, the Solicitor-General, has advised the Government against the production and the Government has informed the Senate of this advice. The Government has made it clear that it accepts and agrees with that advice but the proposal now before the Senate does not accept that judgment. It seeks to have that decision made by some third person who will have no responsibility in the subsequent proceedings. It is very interesting to consider who that third person might be. He might very well be Mr Justice Ellicott. According to Senator Evans, as Solicitor- General Mr Ellicott would have been too close to the Government to make this decision, and as Attorney-General Mr Ellicott would not have been entitled to make the decision. But now that he is a judge of the Federal Court his opinion would be quite acceptable to Senator Evans. It seems to me that that is a perfect example of the sort of thing that I was talking about when I raised this paper by Professor Reid. So long as one can have an opinion by a judge, the opinion is acceptable. In other words, we put on the decision a veneer of respectibility by having the decision made by a judge. But if we have the decision made by the Executive Government, which is the body which ought to be making the decision, we do not accept that decision. It seems to me to be a perfect example of what Professor Reid was talking about, and that the responsibility ought to rest with the Minister and the Government. Here is the Government asserting its responsibility and being decried by Senator Evans for so doing.

Let us look at the question of Sir Maurice Byers. Senator Evans has given him praise. He has said that Sir Maurice is not prejudiced; he acknowledges that he is highly respected. Senator Evans highly respects his legal ability. It is just his judgment that Senator Evans does not accept.

I should like to refer to Senator Harradine's very fair and proper addition to Senator Evan's original proposals-that is, if there is to be any reference, any material which might prejudice any future prosecution of tax evaders should be withdrawn from the papers. But the Government has said that its view is that material cannot be laundered in this way; it cannot be edited so as to avoid its becoming known whom we are talking about. The reason is obvious. It is the McCabe-Lafranchi report, which has named so many companies and bodies that clearly anyone who applies his mind to that report and then to legal advice which is given-no matter how much that advice is laundered-would be able to work out who was involved in the proceedings and what the advice was about.

What would happen if this so-called third party, this so-called independent, this judge of a federal court, happened to blow the decision, perhaps, to make a mistake, and agreed to produce in the Senate material which prejudices the proceedings, such that some active journalist were able to analyse the material and to give it front page publicity, putting it all together and naming the parties, disclosing the material and laying it on the line, blowing it absolutely sky high so that everyone in Australia knew the nature of the advice that was given and knew the parties about whom the advice was given? This third person would have prejudiced the performance by the Government, the Executive, of the duties which the Constitution imposes upon it. The important point is that the Government would be excused because the decision would have been made not by the Government but by some so-called impartial third party.

In my view it is clear that the responsibility should rest with the Government. The Government claims that responsibility and asserts its responsibility in the matter. So, taking up the opinion of the dissenting senators in that very famous report-Senators Greenwood, Webster and Wright, who said that the question is as to the exercise of the power-in my view the Senate should make it perfectly clear that it would not exercise this power.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply- I thank Senator Lewis for his contribution to what has been, perhaps, a surprisingly brief debate on a matter of some significance. I must say that when the debate commenced, following my putting down of the statement, with Senator Evans claiming that the statement was somewhat fog-like or something like a fog machine, I thought that we were engaged in a little political hyperbole. He has a rather colourful turn of phrase in some of these debates. However, as the debate continued it became obvious that to some extent Senator Evans is somewhat confused about the statement put down and perhaps has misunderstood a couple of fairly fundamental points put forward in it.

SPEECH.PARA: I am particularly puzzled by the total failure of both Senator Evans and Senator Haines to come to grips with the problem posed by section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act concerning the production of the investigator's report . We are dealing here with a situation in which the Opposition is seeking, among other things, the production of the report of an investigative officer on a particular and, indeed, quite notorious case. To suggest that the disclosure of that is not a matter of some moment is to ignore current reality.

I should like to refer the Senate again to the statement by the Commissioner of Taxation in relation to document 12, which I had incorporated in Hansard as an appendix to my statement, because the Commissioner of Taxation makes two extremely significant points in that memorandum which should not be ignored by the Opposition or by the Australian Democrats, or by anyone else who will be voting on this motion or on the subsequent motion to be moved by Senator Evans on which we shall soon be voting. I should like to quote the two key paragraphs. The Commissioner states:

The document is an internal working document prepared within the Australian Taxation Office dealing with a particular company's affairs. It contains a full narrative of the case, details of evidentiary material and of admissions made on which a prosecution might be based and it canvasses the legal arguments available to support a prosecution. It contains several pages of verbatim evidence obtained during an interview of a person by a police inspector. It is a document which, by its very nature, reveals the whole substance of the case that might be made against certain people and in my view its tabling would be even more damaging to future prospects of prosecution action than the tabling of legal opinions.

So in that paragraph there is a statement of the concern by the Commissioner that the release of this document would be damaging to the future prospects of prosecution action. The public interest in seeing a proper orderly prosecution in that case cannot again be overstated. Clearly there is a very great public interest, and it is important in those circumstances not only that should the prosecution be in order but that, from the point of view of the defendants, nothing should be done which would in turn prejudice their position, and it is important that the whole matter is dealt with fairly.
The next paragraph of the statement, however, makes the point about section 16. I again quote the Commissioner's statement:

Section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act provides that an officer shall not, except in the performance of any duty as an officer, communicate to any person any information acquired as an officer. It is my view that I am prohibited by this provision from releasing the document in its complete form for the purpose apparently envisaged by the motion.
The Commissioner is saying that he does not believe that he can release it for the purpose of being vetted by some third person in the way that is currently being sought. He says:

In addition, it is a fact that a great many people are aware of the identity of the particular case dealt with. In these circumstances any deletions from, or alterations to, the document to conceal identities of people would not solve the problem and it is unavoidable that any information at all provided in a so- called 'sanitized' version would offend against section 16.

It seems to me to be a fairly important question to face. If the Commissioner's view is that he would be in breach of the law to comply with the request being made with respect to item 12, it becomes apparent that the Senate should not pass the motion or should not have acceded to the motion which it previously passed and it certainly should not be seeking to amend that resolution now to try to make it work. But in any event, it is clear from the statement of the Commissioner of Taxation that he sees himself as being unable lawfully to comply with the suggestion being made.

That is one area which either involves misapprehension or was simply not dealt with in the debate this afternoon. But the second point is one which appears to involve some misapprehension. Before dealing with it I would like to re- emphasise, as is set out in the statement, that we are here dealing with a situation in which the Government has responded in a very open way to a request for documents. In September we tables 85 documents many of which had not been specifically sought. They included all of the documents which could be found and which were thought to be relevant to the area of inquiry raised, namely, the internal handling of the bottom-of-the-harbour proposals-

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be very careful about the truth of that statement if I were you.

—I made that statement, having been a party to a number of discussions as to what was being sought to be achieved by the Government and I believe that to be the situation. We are here dealing not with a failure to disclose documents generally but a situation in which a limited number of documents has not been disclosed because the advice of the second law officer of the Crown, the Solicitor-General, is that to do so would cause harm to those who may be prosecuted and to those who may be proceeded against civilly or to the cause of the prosecutor or civil complainant. The only issue between the Government and the Opposition with respect to this matter is the issue of who ought to make the judgment or on whose advice the Government should be guided in coming to a decision as to what ought to be withheld in what is a commonly agreed interest to protect the integrity of subsequent legal proceedings. It is a narrow point of difference. I will not go over again. The material that Senator Evans and Senator Lewis went over and that I touched upon in my statement about the independence, status and ability of the Solicitor-General. That has been confirmed all around the chamber. I am therefore a little puzzled at this falling back on some vague question of judgment to suggest that the Government should not rely on the opinion of its second law officer.

SPEECH.PARA: That brings me to the fundamental point of misapprehension that was apparent in the remarks made by Senator Evans. Senator Evans made the point that the Senate, in passing the last resolution, was not trying to enforce the laws of the Commonwealth; it was seeking the tabling of papers. He made the point that the production of papers is not part of law enforcement. I understand the force of that comment. The key difference between us, therefore, is that we are not here talking about the tabling of papers; we are talking about the suggestion that there needs to be an editing or vetting of those papers before they can be tabled. The question at issue is who ought to be responsible for the determination of that vetting procedure. Senator Evans and the Opposition are seeking to throw the responsibility for giving advice which can be relied upon by the Government into the hands of some third party. They tried to throw it into the hands of Mr Costigan who declined. They are now seeking to throw it into the hands of some judge of the Federal Court of Australia or some ex-judge.

The important point is that the Government is alleging that this lies within the province of its Executive responsibility. It clearly has the responsibility for the conduct of these prosecutions. It clearly has the responsibility for ensuring that it and its officials behave in a way that is consistent with the probity of that prosecution. Therefore, we are saying that that being our clear responsibility, that is a matter for the Executive government and not for determination by the Senate. We are not here dealing with the question per se of the production of papers. We are dealing with which part of government has responsibility for determining how we meet the commonly agreed objective of ensuring that there is no prejudice to the legal proceedings which we know are before us.

It is quite true that I specifically say in the statement that this is not being put forward as a claim of privilege. It is also true that that is a claim which may rise to be argued at a later time. I accept that there may be another step-that I might be arguing the question of privilege solely. But I do not seek to do that this afternoon because in my view and in the view of the Government we have not reached that point. We have reached the point where we are dealing with a suggestion of the Senate that there should be some third party involved in the Executive's responsibility of determining what should be withheld to protect the integrity of those prosecutions. That is the point on which the statement focuses.

There are a number of other points on which I will touch quickly because I think they warrant some mention. Reference was made to the fact that it is not uncommon in Australia for judges to be assigned various roles. Reference was made to Mr Justice Fox and his inquiry with respect to uranium made on behalf of the Executive arm of government. Reference was made in somewhat different terms to the fact that Mr Justice Woodward recently undertook similar duties. Reference was also made to the fact that judicial opinion around Australia varies. For example, there is a view in the Victorian Supreme Court which differs from the view generally adopted by the judiciary in Australia about the correctness or otherwise of assuming functions as royal commissioners and so on. I think the distinction which needs to be drawn between the examples which were referred to in debate and what is being sought today is that in the cases referred to in the debate individuals holding judicial office have effectively accepted some delegation of executive functions from the Executive government. What has been sought today in the motion before us is a situation in which the legislature is seeking to delegate part of the Executive's function to the judiciary or to some other third party. I believe there is a very significant difference in a situation in which this House, or indeed any house of the legislature, seeks to delegate the Executive's responsibilities for it as against the Executive delegating part of its own responsibilities.

The clear responsibility is placed on the Executive under section 61 of the Constitution for the enforcement and maintenance of the laws. It is the interference with that and the attempt to interpose some third party to pick up part of the Executive's responsibilities that the Government sees as being an improper exercise of the Senate's power.

The other point which I think needs to be made is in respect of Mr Justice Woodward about whom some passing comment was made. I have said before in the Senate and I wish to repeat it so that it is part of the record of this debate that it is certainly my view and I believe the view of the Government that Mr Justice Woodward is one of our most distinguished Australians and a man of particular value. This is evidenced by his contribution across a whole range of activities. He has contributed to Australia as a lawyer and as the Aboriginal Land Commissioner-the role in which I first became aware of him. For a period he was head of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, an appointment which I understand had great bipartisan support. He has contributed as a judge and more latterly-I think it is his second contribution-as a royal commissioner.

However, I wish to make this point: Whatever respect one might have for any royal commissioner, no matter how well one might regard him as having done his job, the fact is that in any series of recommendations there can be differences of opinion. On an earlier occasion when there was a view put by a royal commissioner with which I disagreed I expressed the view that it is perhaps unfortunate that there is no court of appeal from the findings of royal commissioners since their findings can be as difficult and as damaging for an individual as any finding of a court at first instance. But the fact remains that royal commissioners make findings which do affect individuals and which reflect on people. One is entitled to examine those and to decide whether one accepts them as holy writ or whether one believes that they can be changed. I have, on an earlier occasion, challenged another view of a royal commissioner, meaning no disrespect to him. In exactly the same way the view which was taken about one finding of Mr Justice Woodward that was contested-it was not to be supported-was a view that the Government or indeed any person was entitled to take. I make it quite clear that no disrespect was meant to the Commissioner and no diminution of his reputation could be possible from that fact.

The key point, on which I conclude, is that we are here dealing with a situation in which I think Senator Evans said that he believed the Senate had the right to demand papers subject to the public interest. The Government objects to the notion that these particular papers can be demanded in an edited form, the nature of the editing to be determined by some third party, because it sees that as an attempt to take its responsibilities out of its hands and to vest them in some third party. In any event, I believe that most Australians would accept that the public interest requires the proper pursuit of legal remedies in the cases which have been exposed by McCabe-Lafranchi and by Costigan, and the various other disclosures which have been made over recent months. To do anything which would shake the ability of the Government successfully to bring those legal proceedings to fruition would, I think, be clearly against the public interest.

The second law officer of the Crown has advised us that he believes that both the parties who may be proceeded against and those who proceed against them could be harmed by the publication of the material which is now sought. I think this is the clearest possible case where the Senate should not insist on the request but rather should enable the Government to proceed with the most important task of pursuing these legal proceedings with expedition and, one would hope, success.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to thank the Whip for reorganising the business of the Senate so that I can make this short speech today. It relates to things that were said earlier by people who have been recently to Africa and South Africa. I decided to speak, having seen the editorial in the Australian today, which I think Senator Missen mentioned. I am not detracting from what he said about Qantas Airways Ltd flying into Zimbabwe, but I believe that one of the reasons Qantas will fly into Zimbabwe is that our Government does not want to be seen to be dealing with South Africa. It is rather incongruous that that announcement should be made on the day that it was also pointed out that our trade with South Africa over the last three years--
—It was made a fortnight ago.
—It was made on the same day that we were told that our trade with South Africa had increased threefold.
—We have known that for months.

—We can always get these figures. It is admitted by Qantas and by the Government that most passengers will continue on to South Africa, most probably to Johannesburg, and connections have already been arranged, I believe, with South African Airlines to transport passengers from Zimbabwe with a minimum of fuss. I think that is the expression that is being used in British Airways parlance. Yet we have to remember that many other Commonwealth countries-I think about 11-fly to Johannesburg. It seems to me that Australia is always trying to prove that it is purer than the driven snow and will not deal with South Africa. I believe that this is self-evident humbug, as was said in the editorial in the Australian today. As the editorial points out in part

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Qantas flies to other countries whose regimes, in their own way, are at least as repulsive as that of South Africa

I must voice my disapproval of the attitude of the Department of Foreign Affairs , which has really been the force behind stopping Qantas flying to South Africa for many years. I believe that our whole attitude to South Africa, an area which as Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Sir John Carrick) has said in this House is important to the defence of the West, is crazy. We appear to be captives and almost crawl to countries which, as I have said, are quite as oppressive as South Africa. Our Commonwealth Games Committee recently signed a document that I believe will cause it a great deal of concern and trouble. The minute it tries to interfere with the rights of individuals because of that document, it will certainly have my opposition. However, that is a different matter and something that I will deal with at a different time. I am disappointed with the Government's decision not to include South Africa in the proposed flights. I hope that that matter will soon be altered or, perhaps even better, Qantas will fly direct to Johannesburg, as it should, on a reciprocal agreement with the South African Airlines. I think it is time we gave Qantas a go and stopped bureaucratic interference in its attempts to get into the black.

The other matter I want to deal with very briefly is the matter of sitting hours. This was brought to my thoughts by a magazine I received today, the Sydney Chamber of Commerce journal, which carries on the front cover the statement 'Executive health overstressed and under- exercised'. Inside is a headline stating 'Overweight and underexercised', which made me think of the risks that politicians are still under in this place. I do not think we can blame our recent sitting hours for the lack of Government business getting through this chamber. It is simply that the Government now does not have the numbers. We now sit about 21 hours a week. Briefly, I believe we should alter slightly our sitting hours. On Tuesday we should sit for a slightly longer time, from 2 p.m. until 7 p.m. We should alter the arrangements for Wednesday so that we sit from 10 a.m until 1 p.m. and then 2 o'clock in the afternoon until 7 o' clock in the evening, and likewise on Thursdays. That would still give us a total of 21 hours.

This would create a few problems with some meetings but I believe it would make life a lot better for Ministers, who would have evenings available to them without interruption to do the work that they have to do, and it would be better for staff, for people such as those who work in Hansard and the cafeteria and the office staff who have a considerable amount of work to do. At the present, due to our sitting hours on Thursday, they do not really get the breaks that they need. Although I do not usually comment on the House of Representatives, I believe that it could well follow our example. We should all encourage members of the other House to look at their hours. We would all be a lot better off if we brought the sitting hours of this place into line with what the people of Australia would regard as being somewhat more sensible. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
CUSTOMS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1981 [No. 2]
Consideration resumed from 8 September 1981.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Customs Amendment Bill (No. 2) will require that any licence issued for the export of mineral sands from an area listed on the National Estate will need approval by both Houses of Parliament before it can come into force. This legislation will protect Moreton Island from sand mining. It was necessary to draft this Bill because this Federal Government cannot be trusted to protect Australia's heritage areas. The Fraser Government has refused to block the flooding of South West Tasmania's Gordon and Franklin Rivers. It has permitted the uranium mining enclaves of Koongarra, Ranger and Jabiluka in Kakadu National Park. It has refused to declare the entire Great Barrier Reef a marine park to protect it from oil drilling.

Section 30 of the Australian Herritage Commission Act calls on a Minister to take no action which would adversely affect a place listed on the Register of the National Estate unless there is no prudent or feasible alternative. This Bill will provide the additional safeguard of parliamentary approval for decisions by the Minister for Trade and Resources, who may have disregarded the Australian Heritage Commission Act. Only sand mining operations proposed for those areas deemed to be of national significance and so listed on the Register will come under the scrutiny of Parliament. Proposals in other areas will be dealt with by the normal processes of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act or under State procedures. It would be inappropriate for Federal Parliament to consider every minor sand mining proposal in areas of no particular environmental significance; for example, abandoned farmland.

Only eight areas will be covered by the legislation and most of these are already protected as national parks. Unfortunately, two important areas have been threatened-Moreton and Fraser Islands. The Queensland Government has issued sand mining permits on both islands. The Federal Government implemented the recommendations of the Fraser Island Inquiry and revoked export permits. Such an export ban protects Fraser Island only while the Federal Government adheres to that decision. While Fraser Island is currently protected, Moreton Island is not . In June 1981, the Queensland Government decided to allow Associated Minerals Consolidated Ltd and Mineral Deposits Ltd to mine sand from 6.4 per cent of Moreton Island. Recently, Associated Minerals Consolidated wrote to the Minister for Trade and Resources (Mr Anthony), stating that it will be applying for export licences.

Unlike Fraser Island, Moreton Island has never been mined. Moreton Island is the largest area of untouched recreational land close to Brisbane. It has the highest sand hills in the world, magnificent beaches and dunes, perched lakes and unspoiled vistas. This island is pristine, not blotted by sand mining areas and canal estates. During the 1970's, the Queensland Government proposed to allow sand mining on Moreton Island, but the outcry from the people of Brisbane prevented it. A recent poll in an electorate in Brisbane showed that 87 per cent of the people opposed sand mining on Moreton Island. Brisbane City Council opposes the sand mining but the Queensland Government removed the Council's ability to protect the island. The Island was nominated for the register of the National Estate and approved for listing in December 1980. It was not listed until August 1981 because of lack of funds for the Australian Heritage Commission.

In spite of the public opposition and the heritage value of Moreton Island, the Queensland Liberal-National Party Government approved sand mining on the island. There have been over 90 objections lodged with the Brisbane Mining Warden's Court over an application for a Moreton Island mining lease by Mineral Deposits Limited. The Queensland Branch of the Australian Labor Party, along with the Brisbane City Council, the Queensland Conservation Council and the Moreton Island Protection Committee, are appearing as objectors in the Mining Warden's Court. Unfortunately, even if the Mining Warden upholds the many objections, as the Charters Towers Mining Warden did with the Ben Lomond uranium mine, the Queensland Government can override the decision. The two mining companies will mine 6.4 per cent of the island but this includes 50 per cent of the eastern beaches and the area extends to the edge of the Blue Lagoon.

The Queensland Government made its decision based on the recommendations of the Cook report, which is six years out-dated. It ignored comments in an even earlier environmental study, the Heath report, that there may be no net national benefit from sand mining on the island, if mineral sand and prices are low. While the production rate of the proposed mining has not been published, recent figures extracted from the Heath report indicate that 36,000 tonnes of rutile and 32,500 tonnes of zircon will be produced annually, earning $14.4m in exports . Sixty million tonnes of sand will be ripped out of Moreton Island. Less than 200 people will be employed by the two companies and many are already employed in current operations. Associated Minerals Consolidated plans to ship sand to Stradbroke Island for processing at its plant. Actual new employment could total less than 100. Queensland will receive less than $500,000 per year from royalties, payroll taxes and rates from such a sand mining operation.

The benefits of recreation and tourism to the people of south east Queensland far outweigh those that would come from sand mining. Such activities would have to be within the environmental constraints of a proper management plan for the island. Under a management strategy proposed by the Moreton Island Protection Committee which allows for a variety of types of recreation and tourism, direct and indirect employment would be 416, with $4.25m generated from visitor usage of the island. Since then, estimates of visitor usage have been increased by one third. In addition, there are many non-monetary benefits of having such a recreational resource so near to Brisbane.

The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation recognised the value of Moreton Island and recommended that no export licences be issued for Moreton Island mineral sands unless a public inquiry was held under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. The Committee's report was tabled in Parliament on 1 October 1981 but the Government has not responded to it.

Last month, Associated Minerals Consolidated notified the Minister for Trade and Resources of its intention to apply for export licences for Moreton Island mineral sands. The Minister named Associated Minerals Consolidated as 'proponent ' under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. The Government has not decided whether it will have a public inquiry or even an environmental impact statement. Section 30 of the Australian Heritage Commission Act should force the Minister to refuse the application for the export licence but, on its present stance regarding Australia's National Estate, the Federal Government may issue it and claim that sand mining is a State matter.

The Federal Government cannot be trusted to meet its responsibilities and protect Moreton Island. This legislation is necessary to ensure that the island is protected from the Minister for Trade and Resources in his desire to permit development at all costs. The Queensland Government has ignored all the reasons to prevent sand mining on Moreton Island, so it becomes the responsibility of the Federal Government to act decisively to protect this piece of Australia's heritage. This legislation will accomplish this.

A Federal Labor government after the next election will not issue any export licences for Moreton Island's mineral sand and will not feel bound to continue such licences issued by the present Government. Since it is preferable to refuse export licences rather than revoke, and the present Government may issue them, the legislation which the Labor Party proposes would, it is hoped, obviate the need for revocation at a later date. I urge all honourable senators to support this legislation.
Debate (on motion by Senator Messner) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STUDENT ASSISTANCE (LOANS GUARANTEE AND SUBSIDY) BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 13 October, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Upon which Senator Button had moved by way of amendment:
Leave out all words after 'That', insert:
'(a) this Bill be referred to the Standing Committee on Education and the Arts for report by 16 November 1982;

(b) the Committee take into account (i) the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission reference to the declining participation rate in tertiary education and the contribution which the inadequacy of the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme (TEAS) makes to this alarming development, and (ii) the finding of the study on tertiary student finances that the proportion of tertiary students of less privileged backgrounds is declining; and

(c) the Committee report on (i) the proposed agreements between the Government and certain banks, and (ii) the need to provide for regular and automatic adjustments to TEAS to prevent the proposed loans scheme from replacing TEAS as the basic form of student assistance'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think eight speakers took part in the debate last night on the Student Assistance ( Loans Guarantee and Subsidy) Bill. I was fascinated by the very academic offering. All but one of the honourable senators who spoke were university graduates. In fact, five of the speakers had had professional associations with universities. There was certainly no lack of background in respect of those who contributed to the debate. I imagine that those honourable senators, with their experience, know what happens in universities. Some of them, of course, have had experience in using and giving out loans and I imagine that some of their statements were influenced by moderate vested interests and I think that helped the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Button, in leading for the Australian Labor Party last night, mentioned that this Bill was part of the Budget package and for that reason the Australian Labor Party was not going to oppose what the Government had put forward. I am not sure whether the Australian Democrats have adopted the same position. The argument is about how we should go about providing the support that students need to produce certain educational outcomes.

We had two main inputs to the debate. First of all, members of the Australian Labor Party said that although they did not like the proposal they would support it but they recommended that it be referred to a committee; the Australian Democrats said that they did not like the legislation, that they hoped to defeat it but in any event they would try to amend it if they had to in the Committee stage.
