The Australian Democrats' argument, as I understood it, went to the level of the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme benefit. I think I do Senator Macklin no disservice if I say that certainly from what the Australian Democrats have published and what they have said in other places they are worried about two things-the level of the TEAS benefit and whether or not that benefit was or should be indexed as an earnesto of our good intentions. I am worried because I am not sure how realistic those requirements are.

I cannot give a promise about the level of TEAS benefits. That is a matter which is considered each year in the Budget context. I will, as I will explain in a few minutes, inform Senator Macklin and the whole Senate that the Government is prepared to give an assurance now that TEAS will continue. If in fact the Australian Democrats oppose the loans scheme students who need extra support to study will not be helped; they will not have access to a higher or indexed TEAS benefit. Of course, such opposition would be one way of denying to students a resource which we are offering and which they could use to their benefit.

Senator Teague and Senator Martin in their contributions last night set out many of the arguments in favour of the scheme being promoted by the Government. I doubt whether it is necessary to restate these arguments. However, I mention just a couple of features. This is a new option. What is being proposed here is a benefit Bill to give to students something that they do not have at present, to provide something extra. This is a new option with an interest subsidy; a new option with a repayment holiday; and a new option with a long repayment period. Many benefits are available and, if necessary, I will refer to them during the Committee stage. However, in view of the debate that has taken place that may not be necessary.

Much was made during the debate about the concern of honourable senators that the TEAS allowance might be discontinued. I am able to give an assurance to the Senate on behalf of the Government that the TEAS benefit will be continued. We tried to signal this in this year's Budget with the substantial increases in TEAS. I am now able to give a formal assurance that TEAS will continue. I must say to honourable senators that the level of the TEAS allowance would be a matter for determination in the Budget context, as it always has been. Of course , as some honourable senators including Senator Teague, have pointed out, the benefits which are relevant to this Bill go beyond TEAS; they go to other benefits as well. However, the concern that has been expressed in public during debate has related to the TEAS allowance. Senator Teague made it clear that there was being offered to students an extra $50m that is not at present in their hands. Senator Teague made it clear that a $200m benefit pot would become a $250m pot and that this is a very substantial increase.

It is necessary in this summing-up to refer briefly to the various assertions about a failure to maintain the level of TEAS allowances in accordance with changes in the level of inflation. It is reasonable here to compare the performance of the Fraser Government with that of the Government which preceded us and to try to identify what happened to the level of TEAS allowance in relation to the level of inflation over the same period. I suppose one can worry about the sort of index that one can use for the purpose of making such a comparison. However, I will use the consumer price index. During the period of the Labor Government-Labor Budgets were brought down in 1973-74, 1974-75 and 1975-76-the at home rate of TEAS and the away from home rate or independent rate of TEAS went up by about a quarter-actually 25 per cent and 23 per cent respectively-at a time when the CPI went up by almost 45 per cent. In summary, during Labor's time the increase in the TEAS allowance fell 20 per cent short of the rise in the consumer price index. Just to get the record straight, during the years of the coalition government-that is, from 1977 through to the 1982-83 Budget-the rise in the TEAS allowance for the at home rate has gone up by 101 per cent. The independent rate has gone up by 94 per cent at a time when the CPI has risen by 99 per cent. So for the at home rate the increases in TEAS under our Government have just stayed with or just slightly ahead of the CPI and the independent rate has stayed just a little behind it.

The only point I want to make from those figures is simply that the rhetoric that the allowance has dropped behind under the Liberals and did not drop behind under Labor is not really sustainable. To be perfectly fair, I must say that if one looks at the means test, Labor had a better record than we have. Whereas our means test increase has been about two-thirds, Labor's means test increase was about 80 per cent. Labor stayed a bit ahead of the increase in average weekly earnings, which is the proper marker to use for the maximum adjusted family income, whereas our increase stayed a bit behind average weekly earnings. There is no truth in the argument which is put out sometimes that there has been a deliberate or regular diminution in the value of the TEAS allowance under the coalition parties. It is not true and it cannot be sustained by reference to figures.

The issue before the Senate is whether the Bill should be passed. This is a benefit Bill, a new option Bill. If it is not passed, the only people who will be harmed are students who are undergoing higher education. The only people who will lose out are students who might wish to use the benefit. That is a decision for the Senate. The argument has been put forward and I will not canvass it again. But there is another option before the Senate; that is, whether this Bill should be referred to a Senate committee. A reference to a Senate committee will not help. At present we require a number of administrative actions and regulations to be put in place. We have to make arrangements with the banks and take appropriate action with institutions on campus if we are to get the scheme going by the beginning of 1983. I think that Senator Martin has already addressed herself in some detail to the terms of reference and has expressed some concern about the terms of reference as they have been proposed. I commend honourable senators to read what she said last night because she set out some of the reasons that these terms of reference are improper. My concern is that if the Senate refers this matter to a committee it is doing so only to delay the introduction of the student loans scheme. There is no other reason for that action and it will put in jeopardy the introduction of a loans scheme in 1983. I am also concerned that there is no need for a reference to be made to a committee.

During the debate a large number of honourable senators addressed themselves to one or other of the inquiries that have taken place over the last few years on the question of loans and student finances. I am not sure that honourable senators understand just how many times this matter has been put under study. I refer to the work of Hayden Williams and his Committee for the Review of the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme. That Committee reported in May 1975. Also in 1975 the Australian Government Publishing Service published a document entitled 'Income and Expenditure Patterns of Australian Tertiary Students in 1974'. That was done to provide a detailed survey of student income and expenditure. In May 1977 the AGPS published another document entitled 'Student Loans'. This was a report of the Committee Appointed to Examine the Desirability and Feasibility of Introducing a System of Loans for Australian Post-secondary Students. That is another study on the question of loans which has been referred to in the debate.

There is a continuing study within the Department of Education on the analysis of TEAS application forms. That study will analyse data provided by beneficiaries in their TEAS application forms from 1979 onwards. This study was undertaken to give us information about the socio-economic characteristics of the people who are assisted, as well as their pattern of study and progress. In 1981 a review of recent literature and research was published by M. Hayden. This review was entitled 'Financial Assistance to Tertiary Education Students'. In May-June 1981 a 1979 survey of full time tertiary student finances was published by the Department of Education. A review entitled 'Validation study of the Costs of Full-time Tertiary Students' was conducted by Professor Gruen. This was published in May-June 1981. This year-late 1982-there is a review entitled ' Evaluation of TEAS: An Investigation and Review of Policy on Student Financial Assistance in Australia' conducted by the Centre for Study of Higher Education in the University of Melbourne. In late 1982 or early 1983 we expect a document to be produced from the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee on the review of student finances.

Each of those publications has addressed the question which it is now being suggested should go to a Senate committee. I put to honourable senators that this subject has been looked at by people who have been selected as being expert and equipped to do the job. They have had time to do it; they have published their results. The information is available. The question of a loans scheme has been included. It is simply not correct to say that we lack the information. What is required is that we use the information that is already available. We cannot argue that the reference to a committee is required to give to the Senate information which it does not have or could not have simply by going to the available literature. As I say, if we are to give to Australian students the benefit, the extra capacity which loans will give them for 1983-if we are to do that for 1983-we need to act and proceed now. Therefore, I urge the Senate not to proceed to refer this matter to a committee.

I remind honourable senators that many of the matters in this Bill will be settled later by means of subordinate legislation. Each piece of subordinate legislation will come before this chamber. Each piece of subordinate legislation can be disallowed in the usual way by the Senate. Therefore, the Senate will have a continuing role in examining a number of matters which the regulation making power in this Bill gives it a capacity to keep examining. The Senate will not yield its capacity to review and oversight the question of student loans by passing this Bill today. It will allow the process to get started. It will allow us to get underway. The beneficiaries will be the students who will be ready to use the loans next year. I put to honourable senators, with the best will in the world, that to move to delay this Bill by sending it to a committee will not serve any useful purpose. Senator Martin has already set out in some detail why the terms of reference are inappropriate to the committee. In fact, as the honourable senator pointed out they are nonsensical.

TALK.START.PARA: —Inappropriate.

—As the honourable senator points out, they are inappropriate. The political point scoring and the chance to hold up loans without actually voting against them will not be worth it. This is an occasion on which a Bill offering a benefit should be passed by the Senate. I thank honourable senators for the many matters which were raised during the debate. In the time available I believe it is not appropriate for me to try to repond to each on those matters seriatim. I commend the Bill to the Senate and hope that honourable senators will pass it. I hope that the Bill proceeds through the second reading stage and into the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make a contribution on the proposal that the Bill be referred to a committee. The Senate has before it an amendment proposed by the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Button, to the motion for the second reading which would refer the Bill to the Standing Committee on Education and the Arts for inquiry and report by 16 November 1982. The amendment asks:

SPEECH.PARA: (b) the Committee take into account (i) the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission reference to the declining participation rate in tertiary education and the contribution which the inadequacy of the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme (TEAS) makes to this alarming development, and (ii) the finding of the study on tertiary student finances that the proportion of tertiary students of less privileged backgrounds is declining; and

(c) the Committee report on (i) the proposed agreements between the Government and certain banks, and (ii) the need to provide for regular and automatic adjustments to TEAS to prevent the proposed loans scheme from replacing TEAS as the basic form of student assistance.

I do not propose to canvass this matter at great length. I have had the opportunity of considering all the submissions that have been made to the Senate and the arguments advanced last night. I have had the benefit of reading the Hansard record of last night's debate and, in the light of all that has been said to this point, I intend to move an amendment to Senator Button's motion if the first part of it-'Leave out all words after ''That'' '- is carried. I will then propose the insertion in his original motion of certain words which will have the effect of replacing paragraphs (b) and (c) of Senator Button's amendment with the following paragraphs:

(b) the Committee take into account the likely effect (if any) on the Commonwealth Post-graduate Awards Scheme; the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme; the Adult Secondary Education Assistance Scheme; and the Aboriginal Study Grants Scheme; and
(c) the Committee report on ther proposed agreements between the Government and certain banks; and
(d) the Committee report on suggestions from secretarial, commercial and other colleges that the maximum loan per annum be increased to $2,500; and
(e) The Committee report on the limitation of the scheme to grantees specified in section 2 of the Bill.

I believe that Senator Martin disposed, to a certain extent, of some of the reasons advanced for the wording in the original reference to the Committee. However, first let me deal with the allegation that any reference to the Committee, of even this short duration, would jeopardise the loans scheme coming into existence. The point is that the Opposition has stated categorically that it is not opposed to the Bill. Senator Button said last night:

We are not going to oppose this Bill, in spite of the dreadful shortcomings and the sort of stunt element in it which is just a hangover from bygone days of heady rhetoric. It is not our task to oppose this Bill.

In fact, the Opposition has indicated to the Government that the scheme will be allowed to pass into law. Therefore, I assume that the Government will take certain steps with the banks to ensure that the scheme it has proposed is ready to go when the Senate passes the legislation. However, I believe that it is important to give Government members of the Committee in question, in particular , but also non-Government members an opportunity to address the aspects that I am raising. I support the referral of this Bill to the Standing Committee on Education and the Arts for inquiry and report by 16 November 1982. That is a very short time. Senator Button would ask the Committee to take into account a number of matters, which may well have meant that it could not adequately canvass them in the time available. Indeed, already the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission is preparing a study on the participation of young Australians in tertiary education. That study is required by the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) to be undertaken against the background of enrolment patterns and the availability of tertiary education opportunities. It will be most interesting to see what the Commission's findings are in that respect.

The ambit of Senator Button's proposal is too broad. The purpose of my proposed amendment is to refine, as it were, the areas to be taken into account by the Committee and provide it with a manageable task in the time to be allotted to it . My amendment refers not only to the likely effect on the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme, which is the only form of assistance referred to in Senator Button's motion, but also to the likely effect that the measure would have on the Commonwealth Post-graduate Awards Scheme, the Adult Secondary Education Assistance Scheme and the Aboriginal Study Grants Scheme as well. Surely the Department concerned would be able to give the Committee information on this matter. Also it is important, if at all possible, that the Committee report on the proposed agreements between the Government and certain banks. Reference to that is made in Senator Button's proposal, and as a member of the Senate I would like to see precisely what those agreements would consist of before making a final judgment on this measure.

Another aspect of my amendment, concerning which honourable senators have received representations, is the suggestion of secretarial, commercial and other colleges in regard to the maximum amount on loan. Probably it is reasonable that this question also should receive consideration prior to the measure again coming before Parliament. I would like to know the views of the Committee and, indeed through it of the Government and the proposers of the Bill, as to why the scheme is to be limited to the grantees specified in section 2 of the Bill. Why limit it to those particular grantees? What is the philosophy behind that? Indeed, in going to that point, it may well be that we will be able to see the philosophy behind the whole of this measure. In short, so as not to delay the Senate, at this moment I flag my intention to move accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether I need to obtain leave, having already spoken in this debate, but, of course, an amendment has been moved since I spoke .

—Mr President, I am seeking guidance. Am I correct that at a later stage Senator Harradine will in fact move an amendment and that at that stage there is a capacity for honourable senators who may wish to express a view to contribute?
—Yes.
—It may be that that is a better stage at which--
—For me it is not.

—There is to be a series of motions now. The first motion will be that certain words be left out. When that motion is disposed of there will be a motion that certain words be inserted, at which time Senator Harradine will move his amendment and at which stage different groups in the Parliament may wish to make their views known. I understand that procedurally that is the appropriate way. If Senator Button wants to speak now, I will not oppose him.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Button

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose the first motion, that certain words be deleted, can be put and then we can proceed in accordance with what the Minister has proposed . I do not want the whole process to take too long.

INTERJECT.PARA: That the words proposed to be left out (Senator Button's amendment) be left out .

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that the words proposed to be inserted be inserted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —To the amendment moved by Senator Button, I move the following amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out all words after '1982;' and insert in lieu thereof the following:

(b) the Committee take into account the likely effect (if any) on the Commonwealth Post-graduate Awards Scheme; the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme; the Adult Secondary Education Assistance Scheme; and the Aboriginal Study Grants Scheme; and
(c) the Committee report on the proposed agreements between the Government and certain banks;
(d) the committee report on suggestions from secretarial, commercial and other colleges that the maximum loan per annum be increased to $2,500; and
(e) the Committee report on the limitation of the scheme to grantees specified in section 2 of the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already spoken in this debate. I want to speak only very briefly in relation to the amendment that Senator Harradine has moved. We think the Opposition amendment is a preferable amendment to the motion. We understand Senator Harradine's concern that the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts should not take on an enormous reference, with the time available to it, and his apparent desire in paragraph (b) of his amendment to limit the terms of the inquiry in a very significant way. It is a sort of two-card trick. I do not attribute any dishonesty to Senator Harradine in saying that, but it is a sort of two-card trick because he has expanded in a sense what the Committee would be required to do by inserting all those other schemes, and at the same time he has asked the Committee to take into account the effect of the scheme on all these other schemes. I suspect very much that the answer that the Committee will find is that it has no effect at all on any of those schemes. So although it is an expanded reference, it is very limited in its scope.

SPEECH.PARA: In our view, it is a matter of regret that Senator Harradine has in effect deleted from our proposal the reference to declining participation rates in tertiary education and the question of the socio-economic background of students participating in tertiary education and the fact that those of less privileged backgrounds are a declining number participating in post-secondary education.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do you not oppose his amendment and join us in opposing the Bill and killing it?
—There is a variety of reasons for that. Perhaps I can deal with Senator Harradine and save you up, Senator Chipp. I would prefer to do that.
—You mean you cannot think of an appropriate answer now.
—Order! I suggest to honourable senators that they address themselves to the Chair, and perhaps Senator Button may care to make his speech to the chamber.
—I am indebted to you, Mr President, as lawyers say. I say that it is a matter of regret that Senator Harradine's proposal does not address itself in any way to those questions.
—It has been done by the study.

—I am in the happy position-I rarely say this to other senators- of saying that I have been here longer than you, Senator. I remember the Williams Committee of Inquiry into Education and Training addressing itself to this matter. I recorded last night, during the second reading debate, the fact that the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission has twice expressed views about this matter. The inquiry into the validation of tertiary assistance schemes, the other inquiry quoted from last night, also expressed a view about the changing socio-economic background of students, indicating that that change was adverse, certainly from my point of view.

SPEECH.PARA: Should we wait for another sort of recycling of this issue on the basis of yet another inquiry set up by this Government? It has been the most monumentally historic government in terms of the number of inquiries that it has launched and the very few results on which it has acted. I should have thought that at this stage of the present Government's history it would be getting a bit sick of inquiries of one sort or another, but apparently that is not so. I am sceptical about another inquiry, which is, of course, just postponing a decision about this matter, about what ought to be done as regards access in education and about what ought to be done by the less well off who seek access to education.

TALK.START.PARA: —Its report will be down next month. It was due to report by August 1982 and it has been given an extension of time.

—The Williams report on education and training was put down about four years ago. Not much has happened since then. I chide Senator Harradine in a friendly spirit. All I am saying is that it is a matter of great regret that he has not included in his motion a reference to these important matters. Senator Chipp asks why we do not oppose the Bill outright. There is a full-blooded roar from the Democrats on this issue. The reason why we do not oppose the Bill outright was explained by me last night, I thought.
—You did not explain it.
—Perhaps you had gone home, Senator.
—We are not allowed to go home. We are the only party that is not paired. Fourteen other senators are away right now. Fourteen senators are absent from this chamber. Do you want me to say it again?
—Order! I suggest that we cannot have two debates in the chamber at the one time. The Leader of the Opposition is on his feet.

—Senator Chipp has addressed, as I have said, a full-blooded question to me, and I hoped that he might give me the courtesy of listening to the answer. The reason why we will not oppose this legislation is that the view that the legislation should be opposed outright is really based on certain slightly paranoid assumptions that this scheme is the thin end of the wedge. That may have been so. We are not sure that it still remains the thin end of the wedge, because any wedges that the present Government establishes are reduced to splinters. What we are saying is that, if there is a further attempt in any way to expand the loans scheme at the expense of the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme, we will oppose that very strongly at the time.

SPEECH.PARA: But as I said last night, we see this scheme giving some marginal benefit to some students. It is not the function of the Opposition in this place, the next government, which will have the opportunity to deal with these things, to be carried along on a sort of wave of paranoia on the basis of thin end of the wedge arguments. Although that may be something in which the Australian Democrats can indulge themselves, it is not something in which we can indulge ourselves. As I said last night, we in government will repeal this legislation in the context of the provision of adequate assistance for students.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a very anaemic answer to a full-blooded question.

—Many people are passing judgment on personal moral scenes. I am explaining the position of the Opposition. I think that the Minister for Education, Senator Baume, understands that. That is the reason why we shall not be joining the Democrats ultimately in relation to the preferred position of Senator Chipp. I began by seeking only to explain that we would encourage the Senate to support the amendment moved by me. I am not so blind to realities that I might be precluded from having the thought that my amendment might be defeated . If it is defeated, we will support the--
—Senator Harradine's amendment gets voted on first.
—Is that the position? I am indebted to the Minister.
—You might as well know in what order the votes will take place.
—I think this matter will be referred to the Committee, and the Committee will do the best that it can with it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It appears that the Senate will see the numbers with the amendment moved by Senator Harradine. Therefore, it appears that the heads of these various matters-(a), (b), (c), (d) and (e)-will come to the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts, of which I am Chairman. There is always benefit in extra information that relates to a Bill, but I do not believe that it will greatly inform or add to the basic information that is available to us now about this loans scheme. This has been referred to by all those who have spoken at the second reading stage. But if the Senate wishes it to go to a Senate Standing committee, who am I, as one Senator, to oppose the majority of the Senate?

SPEECH.PARA: Another matter flows from this amendment being passed. I take this opportunity to point out to all the interested parties that for this to work within five weeks, any submission relating to the various factors involved in the amendment would need to come to the Senate Committee by the end of October so that public hearings may be conducted in the recess week-the first week of November-in order that we can meet the deadline, 16 November, that is required by the amendment. That means putting on notice not only the Commonwealth Department of Education, the banks, the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission and other interested student bodies but also any member of the public who needs to respond. Five weeks is a very short time frame in which to conduct the considerations a Senate committee. In that respect I welcome the amendment by Senator Haradine which seeks the deletion of the two quite immense matters. One is the alleged decline in participation rates. There has been a decline in school leaver participation rates in higher education but there has been an increase in mature age participation and an increase in part time student participation. The matter, of course, is subject to a full investigation by the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission at the moment which will report in December. The second matter, the socio-economic background of students, being no longer part of this reference, is also welcomed for practical reasons. How could such an immense question be dealt with, even by a Senate standing committee with the reputation of the Senate Standing Commitee on Education and the Arts, within five weeks?

I take the opportunity also to refer to my speech last night and my references to the unrepresentative nature of the Australian Union of Students. The president of the AUS, Mr Paul Carrick, spoke with me after I made my speech last night and wanted to give his response to the statement that I made. The Acting President of AUS changed the convening of the executive meeting of AUS last week because of a Communist student meeting to be held at a certain time. The date of the AUS executive meeting was changed. I was more specifically concerned about the fact that the Acting President of the AUS had, on AUS letterhead, convened a group called the Executive Caucus. It is an Executive Caucus with a capital E and a capital C. It is not known to the students of Australia. It was convened as a covert body to look at the whole agenda of the meeting that would transpire the next day. To be fair to the President of the AUS, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard his letter to me dated today which refers to these matters.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Senator Baden Teague,
Parliament House,
Canberra. A.C.T. 2600
Dear Senator,
Pursuant to our discussion of last evening, Wednesday 13th in Kings Hall, I wish to confirm and elaborate on a number of points I made at that meeting.

Certainly, there are meetings of the various political groupings, tendencies and factions from across the political spectrum prior to meetings of the A.U.S. Executive. Like the Senate, the A.U.S. Executive is elected by proportional representation. This method of election allows the representation of minority views such as those of the National Civic Council (N.C.C.), the Communist Party and even the Liberal Party. In the same way that Liberal and N.C.C. representatives meet to discuss means of best representing their particular minority interest prior to Executive meetings, so do the Communist Party. Surely , in a democratic society, the right to hold such meetings should be afforded regardless of whether we may personally disagree with such minority views.

If one is to be consistent in asserting that the A.U.S. Executive is not ''open and representative'' because its members enter Executive Meetings with ''pre- formed views'', then one must also denounce the practice of the Parliamentary Liberal Party, in meeting prior to sessions of the Senate and so entering the Senate with similarly ''pre-formed views''.

In my opinion, it was inappropriate for the Union's letterhead to be used in the manner that it was, a view that I also held when Liberal and N.C.C. members of the Executive also used A.U.S. letterhead for their own particular factional purpose. This matter is currently under internal review and I am confident that students will democratically resolve against such practices in the future. I should however seek to point out that responsibility for the scheduling and conduct of Executive meetings normally resides with the President. However, due to my absence from the Secretariat, the E.V.P. sought to alter the scheduling of the Executive due to a mix-up in dates. Communist students had planned their meeting well in advance of the Executive meeting. In precisely the same way that the date of the Executive meeting would have to have been changed if it clashed with the Australian Liberal Students Federation Conference. The E.V.P. acted in good faith.

In the spirit of our discussion last evening, it would seem appropriate to have this letter incorporated into Hansard so as to clarify the position, and I would formally request that you ensure this happens.

I conclude in expressing concern at the grave upset your actions have caused the particular individual concerned, and the quite erroneous impression given with regard to the conduct and organisation of the Executive meetings.
Regardless of this particular incident, students have consistently opposed the Government's proposed loan scheme, as will A.U.S., until students direct us to do otherwise.
Respectfully yours, PAUL CARRICK, National President, Australian Union of Students, Canberra. 14 October 1982.
c.c. Senator P. Baume
Senator J. Button

TALK.START.PARA: —In my remarks last night I was not in any way setting out to upset any individual who is involved in public affairs but rather to clarify for the students of Australia and indeed for the Senate whether or not, in the light of such activity by the AUS, it is seen to be acting constitutionally or in a way which is open and representative of Australia's students. My allegation in this matter and some other matters is that it was not. I wish that the AUS were representative of students and acted constitutionally and openly so that all of the students could have more and more confidence in it. I believe that over the last few years this confidence has been sadly lacking. I think that the situation in AUS may be improving. I hope that there will be more accountability in that body so that the representations that it makes to honourable senators in a matter such as the Student Assistance (Loans Guarantee and Subsidy) Bill may be taken as a more credible statement on behalf of the students of Australia. I am glad that I have had the opportunity to clarify that matter. I will leave it to the students of Australia to read the material from last night and today that is in Hansard to make their own judgments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts, chaired by Senator Teague, will do an admirable job in the time that is available to it with the reference that has been made to it. Last night I expressed the Australian Democrats opposition to the Student Assistance (Loans Guarantee and Subsidy) Bill. It is of regret that the Senate will not be voting against it. There is merit in the Senate Standing Committee, that impartial body which has produced such extraordinary reports recently. I am quite sure that it will be able to present a correct report which will show the points I raised last night.

SPEECH.PARA: I find the position expressed by Senator Button somewhat hard to follow. Apparently the Australian Labor Party will vote for the legislation in 1982 but will repeal it in 1983. I would have thought that if the Labor Party was prepared to vote for it in 1982, it could wait to see what actually happens, but we have been given a promise that it will be repealed. I would have thought that if it was to be repealed it would save the country a lot of money not to pass the legislation in the first place. The setting up costs will be revealed to the Senate Estimates Committee. There will be a great deal of organisation involved in setting it rolling. I presume it is a firm promise of repeal. I am not quite sure because at the last platform which I shared with the ALP spokesperson on education Mr Dawkins, who is from another place, he promised that his Party would vote against the legislation. It may well be that when it comes to the crunch the Australian Labor Party will not repeal this legislation. I believe that that will probably be the case. Once things are installed they tend to remain which is why we have taken the opposition that we have to this Bill. I believe that if it is voted into legislation some time next month-which presumably will be the case-it will be operable. I cannot see the Labor Party Cabinet operating any differently from a Liberal Party Cabinet when it gets around to discussing this matter.
Amendment (Senator Harradine's) to amendment (Senator Button's) agreed to.
Amendment, as amended, agreed to.
Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 22 September, on motion by Senator Messner:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The second reading speech for the Liquefied Petroleum Gas (Grants) Amendment Bill 1982 is a useful, though incomplete, assortment of the Fraser Government's political opportunism and economic idiocy. It is a fine example of the Liberal Party of Australia eating its own policies and eating its own propaganda. The Bill extends for one further year the $80 a tonne subsidy on liquefied petroleum gas used for certain purposes first introduced in March 1980. As a result of this 12-month extension of that subsidy the subsidy will continue to be paid until March 1984. In other words, the reason that this Bill is before the Senate today is that the Government felt a political need to extend the subsidy just long enough to get it past the next general election. It is a product of what the recently returned prodigal son, Andrew Peacock, described as the 'manic determination' of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser)-in this particular instance, the Prime Minister's manic determination to have an election before the end of 1982, a manic determination I think diminished somewhat by the events of the last couple of months.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1980 the initial subsidy was introduced. That was for the purpose of the last election, the 1980 election. The subsidy was introduced in March; the election was held in October. A subsidy of $80 a tonne was paid for LPG for household use and was later extended to certain types of industrial use. In respect of the industrial usage, the Government has now discovered that the subsidy provisions have been abused, something which the Opposition and, I would expect, even some of the more rational people inside the Government itself, told the Government at the time they would be. The LPG subsidy is not paid on LPG used as a motor fuel or as a feed stock for petro-chemical industries. The policy, therefore, directly contradicts the Government's stated policy on energy and the use of LPG. The stated policy is that LPG should be reserved for its premium uses as a motor fuel and a petro-chemical feed stock. For that purpose it is sold at market prices. For other purposes, low grade industrial use and crude space heating, the crudest of all purposes, a subsidy of $80 a tonne is paid. It is one manifestation of this Government's competence in the area of economic management!

The apologia advanced in 1980 for the existence of the amending Bill, which contradicted the Government's stated energy policy in general and its stated policy on LPG in particular, was that the measure was necessary to cushion households against the sudden rise in LPG prices which had then recently occurred, as a direct result I add parenthetically, of the Government's import pricing policy. So we have two tiers of contradiction.

As the second reading speech said, the LPG subsidy was introduced for three years in March 1980 with the objective of providing sufficient time for household users to adjust to rapidly rising LPG prices. Since then, the price of LPG in real terms has fallen by nearly 30 per cent. The 1980 apologia was no longer tenable. In these circumstances, the Government has concocted and repeats in the second reading speech a breathtaking piece of fiction which says that the subsidy is being extended 'to cope through a period of uncertainty in world LPG prices, expected to occur in the next year or two'. Expected by whom to occur in the next year or two? For what reason? Who says that? Does the National Energy Advisory Committee suggest that we are about to enter a period of substantial instability in world LPG prices? Everything I have read and everything I have been told suggests to me that the more likely outcome, the more likely result, over the next 18 months is that the real price of LPG will either remain constant or will fall slightly. I do not know whether the NEAC is the author of that piece of brilliant, creative writing or whether at some time after the NEAC gave an opinion the opinion was doctored by somebody in the Government. It should get the parliamentary award of the month for creative writing, completely divorced as it is from reality. The second reading speech states:

On the other hand the Government does not intend that the subsidy encourage new scale industrial use of LPG. This policy was clearly stated in 1980 when the subsidy was made available to industrial and commercial users in areas where natural gas was not readily available.

The Government has now discovered that moral suasion is not a successful antidote for tampering with market prices. The economic theorists of the Liberal Party are apparently astounded to learn that if the price of one commodity is subsidised then that commodity becomes more competitive than it would have been if it had not been subsidised. As a result, LPG has become more competitive after subsidy than certain other fuels. It has been used to replace certain other fuels. The economic theorists of the Liberal Party are apparently startled that this wholly predictable and predicted outcome has eventuated. The second reading speech states:

Over the last two years the competitiveness of LPG as an industrial fuel has created a situation where large industrial consumers with heavy reliance on fuel oil could be encouraged to convert to LPG.

It would be astonishing if they were not encouraged to do so, in marginal cases at least. That was a wholly predictable result of paying the subsidy to industrial users in the first place. Then we see in the second reading speech:
The Government does not wish to encourage such conversion for a number of reasons.

How is it proposed to stop it? If we look a little deeper into the second reading speech we see how. The Minister for the Capital Territory and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr Hodgman) states:

The considerations that I have just mentioned led the Government to announce on 25 September 1981 its intention to impose limitations on the amount of subsidised gas to which industrial and commercial enterprise would be entitled.

He goes on to say that as from 1 October 1982 most industrial enterprises will be restricted to a subsidy on a maximum of 1,000 tonnes of LPG per annum. The Government started with a tough policy-that it was going to stop this astonishing, this startling, substitution of a subsidised fuel for an unsubsidised fuel, by restricting the amount of fuel which would qualify for subsidy. It was a tough and rational policy. It then decided that it would fix that limit at 1,000 tonnes a year-not quite so tough. The second reading speech goes on to say:
The Government does recognise, however, that on 25 September 1981 some users were already using or were committed to use LPG in excess of the equivalent of 1 ,000 tonnes per annum.

How does the Government propose to cope with that difficulty? We are told later in the second reading speech that it will cope with that problem by giving the Minister arbitrary power to decide which industrial users will get a subsidy on more than 1,000 tonnes of LPG a year and which industrial users will not. That is a repudiation, I would have thought, of what are supposed to be two of the fundamental tenets of liberalism. Firstly, it repudiates the supposed fundamental tenet of liberalism that market forces should be allowed to determine choices made by individuals between alternatives, rather than bureaucrats of governments. Secondly, it repudiates what is thought was supposed to be a second fundamental tenet of liberalism, that arbitrary power should not be placed in the hands of politicians or bureaucrats. that to the extent that the power of the State was to be used in the market place or anywhere else, it should be enshrined in legislation and not left to the arbitrary and perhaps capricious or even, dare I say it, on occasions corrupt judgment or abuse of politicians or bureaucrats. Yet that is precisely what the Government proposes to do with this Bill.

In conclusion, despite some reservations about this policy and a very grave reservation, of course, about the flat contradiction between the existence of the policy and the Government's fundamental energy policy, and graver reservations about the industrial limitations component of the Bill before us tonight, the Opposition is concerned that some of the people living in some parts of Australia have access to relatively cheap natural gas whereas other people living in other parts of Australia do not have access to relatively cheap natural gas. Therefore, we will not be opposing the Bill. I think it is fair to observe, given the blatently opportunistic nature of this piece of legislation and the fact that the subsidy is to be extended by it for a 12-month period only , that in the highly unlikely event of the Fraser Government being returned at the next election, which it now appears almost certain will be in 1983, the fact that this Bill extends for one year a subsidy previously provided for a three- year period is an excellent, indeed I would say infallible, indication of the fact that this subsidy will cut out completely at the end of March 1984.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Liquefied Petroleum Gas ( Grants) Amendment Bill 1982 is to extend the period applying to the subsidy for liquefied petroleum gas of $80 per tonne for another 12 months. The subsidy was introduced in 1980 for a three-year period with the aim of providing sufficient time for household users to adjust to the rapidly escalating price of LPG brought on by the second oil shock of 1979. So LPG has become an important primary energy source in many rural areas in Australia. Without the subsidy it would be difficult for these areas to secure adequate heating. From that point of view the subsidy is very important.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important also to realise that LPG has become a very important alternative to petrol. The Australian Democrats believe that this usage of LPG as an alternative to petrol should be encouraged. Its price is only half the price of premium fuel. Many taxi drivers in the country report that they get better engine life from the use of LPG. Certainly it is less polluting and is in very many ways a much better fuel than petrol. It is significant to note, however, that three-quarters of our production of LPG at present is being exported, mainly to Japan and it is to this aspect that I wish to draw the attention of the Senate. We believe that it is necessary to introduce a Bill such as this to extend the subsidy for another 12 months, and for that reason we will not be opposing this Bill. However, it does raise the issue of what fuel we will use for our motor cars after the oil reserves in Bass Strait run out. We all know that these reserves are limited. They will probably begin to dry up about 1988, the year of the bicentenary. Do we have any plan as to what fuel we will use after that? Will we import oil? If so, where will we get the foreign exchange to pay for it? The Government, in other words, has not come up with any basic planning on energy over the next decade or so. It seems to me very short sighted of the Government to be allowing three-quarters of the production of LPG in this country to be exported to Japan. That means in effect that our very limited resources of crude oil in Bass Strait are being refined in our own refineries and an important by-product of those refineries, LPG, which could be used to run our motor cars and to extend the life of the Bass Strait oilfields is not being used for those purposes.

The Democrats are very concerned about the whole state of the petroleum industry in this country. We believe that the industry needs a thorough investigation from top to bottom. We have been drawing attention to the fact that while the oil companies have control of the retailing of petrol, they are in a dominant position to dictate to the Australian people and in fact to the Australian Government what should happen with regard to the pricing of petrol. I believe the fact that there is no marketing strategy in this area is the reason why three-quarters of the LPG produced in Australia currently goes to Japan. It goes to Japan simply because the Japanese are prepared to pay a higher price for it than we can get on the Australian market. This takes no account of the fact that it is a very scarce resource in this country and plans should be made to use it in the most economical way. If we do not plan now we will face a very serious problem in a few years time. The facts of the matter are that we could plan to use alternative fuels for our motor cars. We have large quantities of natural gas in the North West Shelf. That gas could be used to produce ethanol to run our motor cars. We could decide that that is the way we want to go in the future. If we do decide that that is the way to go then we have to plan now to modify our motor cars, to give the manufacturers of motor cars sufficient time to put a vehicle on the market that is suitable for the use of a mixture of ethanol and petrol. We do hope that eventually these very big problems will be faced up to by the Government, that there will be a total divorcement of the retailing of petrol from the oil companies and that a long term plan will be brought down so that it is clear to everybody just what will happen as our scarce resources of petroleum dry up.

Turning to the specific matter before us, we believe that the widespread use of liquefied petroleum gas in this country should be encouraged and for that reason we support the 12 months extension of time applying to the subsidy. It is needed . We just hope that the Government will make use of this extension of time to do something fundamental about the long term problems of which the usage of LPG is one aspect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for the somewhat equivocal support that the Liquefied Petroleum Gas ( Grants) Amendment Bill has received. I understand that, notwithstanding the lack of direct oral support, it will have the voting support of honourable senators. I do not wish to speak at length; indeed, I could not speak at length in light of the hour. However, I want very quickly to mention a couple of points raised by Senator Walsh. He expressed concern about that passage of the Bill which permitted an exception to the 1,000 tonne limit for certain industries and, in the way which is fairly characteristic of him, he raised inferences that there could be corruption at the political or bureaucratic level in respect of it.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to refer very quickly to the Bill, which provides in clause 7 for the limitation of subsidised use by industrial users. It lays down the limit of 1,000 tonnes which has been referred to in the second reading speech and in debate this evening. The provision makes a very sensible exception for a situation where, on the basis of the law as it applied without this limitation, industries have undertaken usage greater than 1,000 tonnes per annum. In sub- clause (6) there is a provision that where that is the case or where contractual obligations have been entered into before 25 September 1981 relating to either the purchase of gas or the purchase, construction or modification of a plant, then an exception can be made. That exception is one which depends on the words of the clause, which require either the prior greater use of gas or the entering into of firm commitments. In respect of the administration of that clause, a later clause in the Bill provides for the decision to be subject to review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. So the matter is subject to appropriate controls. It is quite specific and it is subject to an appeal.

The only other thing I wish to say is that there is a marked difference between the approach adopted by Senator Walsh in this place and the speech made by the Opposition spokesman, Mr Keating, in the other place. One would be hard pressed to conclude after comparing the two speeches that both could represent the official views of the Australian Labor Party. I can only ask those people who might be concerned about the attitude of the Labor Party to take their chance on whether Senator Walsh or Mr Keating accurately set out the attitude of the Labor Party to this subsidy. Senator Walsh gave us a lecture on the economic undesirability of maintaining this sort of subsidy, pointing out that it was contrary to the wish of the Government to divert this resource to automotive use . On the other hand, Mr Keating acknowledged the difficulties which are felt by communities which do not have access to the natural gas pipeline. He made a speech which, as I say, sits at complete odds with the comments of Senator Walsh this evening. I commend the legislation to the Senate and trust that it will have a speedy passage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to point out that if the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) cares to look at Hansard tomorrow he will see that I also acknowledged the difficulties of those people who do not have access to a natural gas pipeline. He must have been inattentive at the time I said that.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Chaney) read a third time.
Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Chaney) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to give effect to the special Commonwealth drought assistance measures announced on 31 August 1982. They are a subsidy on interest payments over 12 per cent made by eligible drought declared farmers and a subsidy on fodder purchased to be fed to drought affected sheep and cattle. The fundamental aim of these measures is to help prevent drought affected farmers from walking off their properties because of difficulties in servicing their debt, and reduce the cost of drought feeding and so enable graziers to retain stock, particularly breeding stock. This will also contribute to a more rapid economic recovery in the rural sector when the drought breaks.
It would be disastrous for the nation if the drought was allowed to cause a major exodus of farmers from the land, or a serious depletion of sheep and cattle breeding stock.

There are currently an estimated 100,000 farms across Australia that are drought affected. Already the net value of rural production is forecast by the BAE to be some $1,300m below last year's level. If the drought does not break very shortly, the Bureau believes the net value of rural production could fall to half of last year's level.

The effect on the cash surpluses of farmers will be extremely severe. The BAE estimates that in 1982-83 cash surpluses in the Eastern States will be down by at least 50 per cent in both the agricultural and grazing industries and the horticultural industries. In NSW, currently the worst affected State, cash surpluses could be down by at least 70 per cent.

Both the interest payment and fodder subsidies will be totally funded by the Commonwealth. They are special initiatives for the duration of the current drought only, and they are both effective from 1 September 1982, for eligible farmers. They are a recognition of the fact that we are now facing potentially the worst rural disaster in our history.

This Bill provides specific funding for the two subsidies. Needless to say, it is extremely difficult to estimate what the overall actual cost might be, particularly as it is impossible to predict how long the drought will continue. consequently, the funds appropriated in this Bill are based on the best available estimates of the effects of the drought, and the depressing assumption that the situation will not ease over the remainder of this financial year.
I should mention that there is nothing particularly unusual about not having firm estimates for natural disaster relief programs of this nature.
It is not possible to budget for natural disasters and when they do occur it is the duty of the Government, and the whole community, to be prepared to provide adequate assistance.

Let me also stress that adequate provisions are being provided with regard to the administration of both of these subsidies to ensure that they are not abused . In particular, we will not allow Pitt and Collins Street farmers to take advantage of the interest rate subsidy. We are not in the business of helping part time farmers who also have outside incomes. We are in the business of helping the nation's full time farmers to stay on their properties through this very difficult period.
I now turn to the detail of the two subsidy arrangements.
Interest Payment Subsidy
This scheme will be subject to strict eligibility criteria:
It will only be available to those involved in the business of primary production who are also, in normal circumstances, predominantly dependent on their farm for their living.
The farm must be drought declared by the State.

To obtain the Subsidy on debt existing at 31 August both the applicant and all other individuals with a direct or indirect beneficial interest in the farm must not have, in aggregate, readily available liquid assets exceeding 12 per cent of the eligible debt. This will allow eligible farmers to hold sufficient liquidity to meet their share of the interest payments. Furthermore, a farmer can become eligible at a subsequent date, if evidence is provided that readily available liquid assets have been used to reduce debt to meet the 12 per cent eligibility criterion.

Examples of readily available liquid assets are cash deposits, term deposits, various forms of Government bonds and securities, stocks and shares traded on the share market, and Income Equalisation Deposits. An individual with a direct or indirect beneficial interest in a farm is anyone who by virtue of being a partner or share holder or trustee, derives some form of income from the farm operation.
Providing a farmer meets all the eligibility criteria, he will pay the first 12 per cent of interest on eligible debt and the Commonwealth will pay the balance.

The Subsidy will apply to interest payments on interest which is accrued since 1 September 1982 on eligible debt held at 31 August 1982. Debt must be for the purpose of primary production, and most types of formal loans will be eligible, including solicitors' funds and hire purchase. Leasing is not included. The Subsidy will also be paid on new debt advanced by banks and pastoral houses after 1 September, where these lenders certify that it was for the purposes of carry-on necessitated by the drought. The Subsidy will not be paid on loan charges, stamp duty, State loan taxes, etc; only on interest payments.
With regard to administration, application forms will be available from Post Offices, and farmers will apply direct to the Department of Primary Industry in Canberra.

Claims cannot be made until interest has either been paid, or debited to the farmer's account; claims cannot be made more frequently than once a month; and payments will be made directly to the applicant by mailed cheque.

Farmers who believe they are eligible will need to complete detailed application forms and a claim form in respect of each loan on which the subsidy is being claimed. The farmer will also be required to complete a statutory declaration attesting to the truth of all the information he provides, and lenders will also be required to certify as to the details of the debt and that the interest has been paid.

These arrangements are necessary to ensure that there is no abuse of this subsidy. There are severe penalties for false declarations or attempts to defraud the Commonwealth, including fines and up to 4 years gaol under the Crimes Act.

The Commonwealth will provide $36m for this subsidy. This provision is based on estimates by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics that there are currently some 30,000 drought affected farmers with average interest rates exceeding 12 per cent.

These farmers have average debts just over $32,000 per farm. Estimates prepared by my Department indicate that some 10,000 farmers may qualify immediately for the interest subsidy with an estimated further 17,000 likely to qualify if the drought continues for another 12 months.
Fodder subsidy

This subsidy will apply to all fodder purchased from 1 September 1982 for feeding to drought affected sheep and cattle. it will be claimable once a month and there will be upper limits of 80 cents per sheep per month and $8 per cattle beast per month, that can be claimed.

The subsidy will be administered by the States under conditions and guidelines agreed with the Commonwealth. Claim forms will be available from, and claims should be submitted to, State agencies administering drought relief.

A farmer will have to purchase the fodder and complete an application form together with appropriate documentation and receipts before being paid the subsidy. A common form will be used throughout Australia and will be available through State administrations before the end of the month.

If farmers sell fodder after 1 September then receipts from these sales will be debited against any subsidy entitlement before actual subsidy payments are made. Farmers will have to include as fodder sales feed wheat and feed barley. They will not have to include other wheat delivered to the Australian Wheat Board or its receival agents, or sales of malting barley.

When making a claim for the subsidy the farmer will be required to sign a statutory declaration certifying the truthfulness of all the information included on the claim form-in other words, that he has purchased the fodder to feed to drought affected sheep and cattle that he owns; the number of sheep and cattle he is feeding; and details of any fodder sales.
The subsidy will not be available on fodder purchased for feeding to sheep and cattle held in commercial feed lots.

The subsidy will be paid on all grain, fodder and manufactured stock feed purchased for feeding drought affected sheep and cattle. In the case of wheat, the subsidy will be 50 per cent of the purchase price, ex source. For other feeds, the subsidy will be calculated on the basis of the feedstuff's nutrient value relative to wheat.

Commonwealth and State officials have agreed to a three category system for nutritive values, and this will operate uniformly throughout Australia. Category one will include fodders that are taken to have the same nutritive value as wheat; category two will include those that are taken to have a nutrient value of 67 per cent of wheat; and category three will include fodders with a nutrient value of 50 per cent of wheat. In no cases will the subsidy payment exceed 50 per cent of what the farmer paid for the fodder. Details of the relative nutrient values will be widely publicised, and will also be included on the back of the claim forms.

The Commonwealth's general philosophy is to allow the subsidy to be paid on all feed and supplements which are normally used or required in a particular State or region to keep sheep and cattle alive in a drought.

The scheme is designed to prevent fodder prices from escalating abnormally. As the wheat price cannot be manipulated, if other fodders become too expensive, then logically farmers will switch to wheat.

The Commonwealth will provide up to $320m for the fodder subsidy. This provision is based on current livestock numbers of about 14 million cattle and 94 million sheep on drought affected farms, and the assumption that there will be a need to subsidise around 70 per cent of feed and grain fed to those sheep and cattle.

The Government believes that these measures, together with changes and additions that it has suggested to the States to the core measures operating under the Natural Disaster Relief Arrangements will provide much needed additional relief to drought stricken farmers.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robertson) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Telegram Services-South Australian Timber Industry
Motion (by Senator Chaney) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want very briefly to bring to the attention of the Senate the concern of members of the Tasmanian community at the prospect that the public telegram service could be reduced to virtually a non-service to the Tasmanian community. It is apparent when one looks at the statistics that, with some 136,000 households in Tasmania and only 96,000 private telephone connections, only some 71 per cent of Tasmanian households have a telephone service in order to carry out those communications with other persons which are so essential for the conduct of social life and those commercial transactions which are undertaken from home. There are many cases, therefore, where the telegram service is an essential link to persons in households without a telephone.

SPEECH.PARA: It appears from information which has been given to me, particularly in a submission from Mr Alan Riseley, the Tasmanian Branch Secretary of the Union of Postal Clerks and Telegraphists, that the telegram service in Tasmania may be under threat of extinction. There has been some discussion in certain circles to the effect that the service may be cut out altogether on 8 February 1983. Therefore, it is a matter of some urgency that Tasmanian senators express their views on this matter.

It is clear that the public telegram service has served the Australian and Tasmanian communities very well in the 100 years in which it has been operating. But it also seems clear from documentation that has been provided to most honourable senators that there has been a breakdown in co-operation or trust between Telecom Australia and the unions concerned in this area. When those unions on 10 August 1982 asked the Chief General Manager of Telecom very pertinent questions as to the plans of Telecom in relation to this network, Telecom replied that it was reviewing its total approach to the structure of the service including staffing arrangements. It stated:
As a result of that review, it is not possible to answer the detailed questions . . . which you have posed.

In other words, there is a refusal by Telecom management to answer the very reasonable questions of the union which has a concern for the general community and, of course, for the livelihood of its own members.

Certain management studies have been undertaken by W. D. Scott and Co. Pty Ltd. If that company's recommendations were put into operation, particularly those in regard to the greeting telegram service, it could well be that there would be an increase in revenue to Telecom of some $6m. That respected management consultancy firm predicted that Telecom would gain an additional $1,160,000 as a result of a strong promotions campaign for greetinggrams over each year of the first two years of the campaign. That proposal has not been taken up by Telecom. This seems to indicate that the Telecom management has made its own decision that the public telegram service ought not to continue because, it has to be admitted, losses are being made in the conducting of that service. But, as I say , steps which have been recommended by respected outside consultants to reduce that loss have not been undertaken. In any case, as I have already put to the Senate, I think it is apparent from the number of households in Tasmania without a telephone that there may be a strong case for the community subsidising the operation of such an essential service. In other words, some losses may be quite properly borne by the community and by general tax revenue in order to ensure that people are not totally isolated in this respect.

The other matter to which I wish briefly to give some attention is the case of Mr Solomon Gebreab, an Eritrean, who has fled his country and who has been travelling as a merchant seaman around the world for the last half dozen years. He has resided in Australia for the last 12 months during which time he has made an application for refugee status. I understand that some recommendation has been made by the Determination of Refugee Status Committee to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hodges) in relation to that application, though I do not know the nature of the recommendation before the Minister. As one of the sponsors of the Eritrean Relief Committee-Senator Missen from Victoria is another-I would like to make a special plea on behalf of this man. To require him to return to Ethiopia would be to condemn him to the fate of other people in that country who are subjected to indiscriminate and brutal killings and suppression by the military dictatorship in Ethiopia which is backed by Russian generals who plan and devise military campaigns which are genocidal in their effect. To send Mr Gebreab back to Ethiopia would be undoubtedly to condemn him to death.

I understand that there has been some talk in the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to the effect that this gentleman ought to be returned to Italy. The basis for that seems to be that at various times in his career as a merchant seaman Mr Gebreab has worked for Italian companies and spent some time necessarily in Italian ports. But the fact is that he has spent the last 12 months of his life in Australia. In fact, he has not developed any longer standing relationship with any other country. In other words, he has spent more time in Australia than in Italy. Here he has developed friendships with Australians, a good understanding of the Australian way of life and could settle well into this community. The fact is-and this needs to be noted-that repatriation to Italy would not be a suitable or acceptable alternative, because whilst that country is a signatory to the 1961 Geneva Convention and the 1976 Protocol it appears from information supplied to me that Italy has restricted its commitments under these conventions to events in Europe prior to 1951 and therefore is not committed to accepting African refugees.

If the Government is thinking that it can place Mr Gebreab on a vessel of the line from which he jumped ship some 12 months ago in Australia with some undertaking by that shipping line that it will land him in Italy, that plan is bound to founder. As I say, in any case Italy has no obligation under any international convention to accept this man. But quite apart from that, the Government should exercise its humanitarian concern on behalf of this Eritrean who is a refugee from his country through no fault of his own but because of the persecution of the Eritrean people which is the subject of a reference to the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. I will not go into the actual substance of the conflict in that country, but it is well known to the Government. I hope that the Government, in view of its knowledge of this situation, will grant to this man the humanitarian asylum which he deserves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I speak on the matter on which I advised the Minister at the table, the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney), I would be speaking tonight, I think I would be remiss in my duty as a member of parliament if I did not express my gratitude to the Premier of South Australia, Mr David Tonkin, for acceding to my request which I made by way of notice of motion yesterday to call an immediate State election to allow the South Australian electors to re-elect a Labor government so that the State can be restored to the prosperity and the level of population that it enjoyed prior to the election of 1979. About 24 hours after I gave that notice of motion the Premier has announced that election today.
—Senator, I suggest that if you wish to remove your notice of motion from the Notice Paper you will have to wait until next week to do so. You are at present speaking on the adjournment.

—Mr President, I think I will leave it where it is until about 9 November. For the fifth time since 24 August I am forced to raise the plight of the timber industry in the south-east of South Australia. Because of large imports of New Zealand and North American timber the local industry is suffering a huge loss of income with the resultant loss of employment and others in the work force being put on short time. I first raised this matter in the Senate by way of a question to Senator Chaney on 24 August. It was quite a long question and the Minister gave me a much longer answer. I then had to ask a supplementary question. I remind Senator Chaney of what he told me on 24 August. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I have no information in my brief on this matter and I have no independent recollection of it. I will have to check that point and let Senator McLaren have a further reply.

I am still awaiting that further reply from Senator Chaney, despite the fact that during the adjournment debate on 16 September and 23 September I again raised the matter. On Tuesday of this week, that is, 12 October, again on the adjournment debate, I had to raise the matter again. As I say, tonight is the fifth occasion on which I have raised the matter in this chamber. I want to be as brief as I can, due to the lateness of the hour, to put on record that on 11 June this year I sent telegrams to the following Ministers: The Minister for Trade and Resources, Mr Anthony; the then Minister for Industry and Commerce, Mr Lynch; the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Nixon; the Minister for Social Security, Senator Chaney; the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Macphee and the Minister for Transport and Construction, Mr Hunt. All of those telegrams were addressed to those Ministers at Parliament House. The text of the telegram is thus:

Respectfully draw your immediate attention to the pending economic crisis in the Mount Gambier Area of South Australia, due to the loss of pay to Workers in the Timber Industry because of the introduction of a four day week by the Timber Producers.
This reduction in working time has been caused by the lack of orders for the local product due to the large imports of Timber, particularly from New Zealand.
Your urgent action is necessary to relieve the extreme anxiety and financial problems facing the Workforce and Business people in the South East of this State.

Mr President, you are a South Australian and you would be well aware that since I sent that telegram on 11 June this year the industry has suffered much graver problems in the months that have gone by. I did receive an acknowledgment to my telegram from each of those Ministers. Some came fairly quickly. The last one was dated 3 August. It took Mr Macphee from 11 June, when he received my telegram, to write to me on 3 August acquainting me that he was aware of the problem and the Government intended to do something about it. I have had no reply as to what the Government is actually intending to do except, as I said here on Tuesday night, that I have heard on the grape vine that there is a proposal to set up a Temporary Assistance Authority inquiry. I have received no official information and neither has the South East Trades and Labour Council of South Australia, which I introduced as a deputation to Mr Lynch back in July-it may have been August-in his office in Melbourne. We have received nothing official about that.

What concerns me is that although the Government has been aware of the problems for all of this time, it has not yet told us officially what it intends to do to help the problem in the south-east. During the Estimates committee hearings I posed a few questions about the use of consultants. I found that the department which is mainly concerned with the timber industry was Mr Lynch's department, as it was then. Of course, there has been a change there. During the last 12 months the Department of Industry and Commerce has engaged 12 consultants at a cost of $235,217. Surely some of those consultants would have been looking at the plight of the industry in Australia as a whole but particularly in the south-east. Senator Chaney's own Department engaged the services of seven consultants at a cost of $249,299 for that 12 months' period. Surely they must have looked at some of the aspects of what the problem of unemployment was going to cause to the Department of Social Security. I am sure that the consultants would have been aware of the huge increase in unemployment in the south-east without having to wait for me to tell the Senate about it some weeks ago.

If we look at the overall total of consultants engaged by this Government for the preceding 12 months we will find that 2,699 consultants were engaged at a huge cost of $52,051m. That is a huge amount of public money. Yet we cannot be told officially that the consultants have come up with any answer as to what ought to be done; it might not be successful. One of the things which they ought to be doing is preventing this timber coming in from New Zealand and North America. It is of great concern to me as a person who spends a lot of time in the south-east of South Australia and it is of great concern to the mill proprietors, the timber growers and, of course, the employees whose wage packets are decreasing. In turn, they do not have the spending power which was once available. As a result the small business people in Mount Gambier, Millicent and to a lesser extent in Tarpeena are suffering great financial loss.

There is a three-year history of what is happening in the south-east insofar as the State Government goes. I will give a brief background of what has happened in the last three years. The last three years have been years of missed marketing opportunities for the South Australian Woods and Forest Department and falling employment and profits both for the Department and the industry as a whole.
