The woodchip and pulp contracts have been cancelled by the Tonkin Government and subsequent market downturns have deterred possible interest in the utilisation of the pulp wood resource. Lack of stimulation of the building industry has also had a depressing effect on the initiatives in the soft wood construction materials that had been developed by the previous Labor Government. Australian Paper Manufacturers Ltd, which is the owner of the Cellulose Australia Ltd paper mill, has continued its program of consolidating its production in its larger eastern States paper mills and has decided to close the No. 2 paper mill at Cellulose, which of course, is very near to Millicent, with the loss of 130 jobs and a related downturn in the prosperity of the township of Millicent. The Tonkin Government has not pursued opportunities for overseas forestry consultancies involving South Australian forestry expertise and the building of complete tree nurseries which were in the process of negotiation between the previous Labor Government and the governments of Algeria and Iraq.

Diversified markets for sawn timber products have not been explored. This failure to develop the marketing side of the Department's operations by the Tonkin Government, through product and market research, has contributed markedly to the downturn in activity in the timber industry. It means that the south-east regional economy is not getting the full benefits in terms of jobs and profits from the forestry resource that is there. Over the last three years of the Tonkin Government, the Department of Woods and Forest, coasting along on the initiatives of the previous Labor Government, has generated millions of dollars for the State Treasury Department. Most of this money has been taken into general revenue by the Tonkin Government and none of it has been invested into sales and development areas. Apart from the investment in a new green mill which was initiated and fully funded under the previous Labor Government, no new capital investment of any magnitude has been undertaken by the Tonkin Government . This anti-development strategy by the Tonkin Government in the timber industry has reduced the ability of the Department of Woods and Forest to compete with imports. The recent decision of the Tonkin Government to divert surpluses to subsidise private farm forestry will contribute to the present oversupply of timber and reduce even further the Department's competitiveness on domestic and export markets.

During the Estimates committee hearings I was alarmed to note under one of the headings of the Department of Primary Industry that it was anticipated that somewhere near to an income of $3m would be received from the States. That would be by way of interest payments under the softwood forestry agreements-that is, where the loans have been made available to the various States. The Commonwealth Government has a vested interest in seeing that the timber industry in Australia remains viable because those States which have borrowed money will be unable to pay the interest on the loans. If the downturn in the timber industry continues we will find that those States will not be able to repay any of the principal off the loans and also the interest accrued. That will bring about a further drag on the taxpayers of this community. It is in the interests, not only of the mill owners in the south-east of South Australia, at which I am directing my attention this evening, as I have done on four previous occasions, but also of the employers, the small business people and, at the end of the scale the Commonwealth Government, to do something to protect this industry.

To save the time of the Senate I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the policy of the South Australian Labor Party on the forestry industry of that State. It occupies some two typewritten pages.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Labor's Policy
A Labor Government will vigorously pursue markets for South Australian forestry products and expertise in order to maximise job opportunities and profits in the S.E. of the State.
In particular:

Labor will seek markets in Australia and overseas for surplus forestry thinnings either as woodchips or pulp. The disposal of surplus thinnings will not only create additional jobs and income for the State but is crucial to the good management of the forests and the supply of sawlog in future.

Labor will explore overseas markets for sawn timber and pre-cut components in order to reduce the Woods & Forests Department's dependence on the ups and downs of the Australian building market. Diversified markets will provide greater security of employment for workers in the industry. Labor will also assist other producers to seek alternative markets for products such as particle board.

Labor will follow up the many enquiries from countries in the Middle East and North Africa seeking S.A. forestry expertise. These projects aimed at controlling soil erosion and landscaping new town development will provide jobs for South Australians and export opportunities for South Australian firms supplying equipment for forestry.

Labor will change the investment priorities of the Woods & Forests Department away from the provision of subsidies for private farm forestry and return it to the continual updating of the Department's sawmills. Unless the Department is kept in the forefront of modern technology it will be unable to compete with the flood of imported timber and more jobs will be lost.
Labor will increase investment in new product research and development. This work is essential if timber and timber products are to hold and expand their share of the market.

Labor will make strong representations to the Federal Government to provide adequate safeguards against unfair competition from New Zealand under C.E.R. Unless the Federal Government is prepared to insist on the New Zealand Government removing export incentives royalty subsidies and other artificial forms of assistance, Labor will develop with the other major forestry States of New South Wales and Victoria ways to give preference to Australian timber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. In conclusion, I hope that by next week, when Parliament meets, Senator Chaney will have been able to prod those departments that should have supplied him with answers to the questions I have asked here over the weeks and that some consolation will be forthcoming for the proprietors of mills, employees and small business people in South Australia-an indication that the Government will do something to assist them to overcome the problem they are now experiencing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply- Mr President, it is not only the mills of God that grind slowly and exceeding small, I must say. In any event, this is the fourth or fifth time that Senator McLaren has raised this matter at Question Time, on the adjournment, or in the Estimates committee hearings. A fair amount of information has been provided to this point. The former Minister for Industry and Commerce gave me information concerning it some time ago. I passed that on in the course of one of these debates. It concerned the discussions that were taking place at interdepartmental level between New Zealand and Australia in relation to the difficulties about which Senator McLaren has been expressing concern.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, it is very simple to respond that a very easy way to handle these problems is simply to cut off imports. No country is more dependent upon its ability to export than is Australia. If we were to reach a situation in which our automatic reflex action was to stop all imports, clearly Australia itself would soon be in even more significant difficulties. For that reason, we do not have a policy of simply responding by totally closing off imports. Rather, we have procedures which enable a reference to be made to the Temporary Assistance Authority or other action to be initiated of the sort originally taken here, in respect of which there was international consultation on the point. However, I do have some additional information that will be of interest to the Senate in regard to this matter.

As was mentioned previously, the industry sought a dumping action against square dressed structural softwood of New Zealand origin. The investigation has progressed to the stage at which New Zealand has been notified formally that the 60-day consultation period required under Article 10 of the New Zealand- Australia Free Trade Agreement was deemed to have commenced on 27 September. Furthermore, in accordance with standard dumping procedures, a meeting of parties has been arranged for 18 October 1982, a matter of days from now, to discuss certain factual aspects associated with the determination of normal values. Towards the end of last week, the Softwood Timber Producers Council sent additional information to the Department of Industry and Commerce, together with a request that its application for a TAA reference be re-activated. The Minister expects the Department to analyse this information and prepare a report for him by the end of this week on the industry's request for a reference to the TAA. That further information may be of assistance to the honourable senator.

Reference has also been made to my own Department. I was in South Australia a week or so ago and had an opportunity to meet my State director and also other officers of the Department. The general view put to me is that the Department is managing well in the circumstances it faces-an increased volume of activity in the unemployment area. The Government is being careful to respond to the additional staffing needs. I believe that the Department itself has responded well to the additional demands that are being made upon it. I would be disappointed if that generalisation, which I would apply to the State of South Australia, and indeed to the States generally, could not be applied to the south -east region of South Australia. Other things need to be done by us to respond to those pressures, but I assure the Senate that, given the differing circumstances we face, with an increase over a period of perhaps a little more than half a year of some 100,000 in the volume of unemployed on our books we are facing the challenge of presenting an appropriate service to those who need the assistance the Department provides. I think that position is being fairly satisfactorily covered. To the extent that it is not I would appreciate that being drawn to my attention because the Department would wish, of course, to deliver entitlements efficiently and effectively.

Senator Tate raised matters in the fields of immigration and telecommunications . I will see that the matters he raised are directed to the attention of the appropriate Ministers. The matter of the refugee status of a named individual from Eritrea is one that is already formally being dealt with by the processes which the Department has established to deal with refugee status. However, I will ensure that Senator Tate's remarks are referred to the officers of the respective Ministers.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What has been the rate of growth in the money supply since 1976-77.
(2) What has been the rate of growth in the Gross Domestic Product over the period since 1976-77.
(3) Is the rate of growth in the value of transactions related to the growth in GDP.
(4) Has the rate of growth of the money supply been sufficient to finance the increased level of transactions since 1976-77 without putting undue pressure on the cost and availability of credit.
(5) What is the evidence used to determine pressure on the cost and availability of credit.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Average rates of growth of the standard measure of the money supply (M3) in each year-to-June from 1977 are given in the following table:
Growth rate
(2) The latest estimates of rates of growth in gross domestic product at current and constant prices in each year from 1976-77 are given in the following table:
(per cent) 14.2 8.6 13.0 12.2 13.9 13.6 Constant Prices

(3) Gross domestic product (GDP) during a particular period is a measure of the total market value of goods and services produced in that period after deducting the cost of goods and services used up in the process of production but before deducting allowances for the consumption of fixed capital. Transactions (sales) may occur at the input, output and various intermediate stages of production, depending on the manner in which production is organised, while transactions involving existing physical assets, financial assets and transfer payments may be undertaken quite separately from current production. There need therefore be no precise relation between the total value of transactions and the value of GDP . Nonetheless if the overall patterns of production and of transactions in the economy are relatively stable, the two might be expected to grow at broadly similar rates.

(4) and (5) The total value of transactions depends on the prices at which they are carried out. The rate of increase in total transactions therefore responds to changes in the rate of growth of the money supply through the impact of the latter on inflation. At the same time, there has been a long term tendency for M3 to grow less rapidly than nominal GDP (and so presumably the total value of transactions) due to increasing efficiency in monetary use due to technological, institutional and other changes. The cost and availability of credit need to be assessed in terms of interest rates and the growth in relevant monetary aggregates in relation to current inflationary expectations. If expectations are slow to adjust to changes in the rate of growth of monetary aggregates, pressures may be placed on the cost and availability of credit. Any such pressures are not considered to have been undue in the period since 1976-77.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 19 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are tools of trade exempt from sales tax when their purchase is necessary for a person to carry out their trade.
(2) Are professional musicians not allowed exemption from sales tax when purchasing musical instruments, even though the purchase of these instruments is a prerequisite to them being employed.
(3) Will this anomaly be removed and sales tax exemption allowed to professional musicians when purchasing musical instruments.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The sales tax law does not provide a general exemption for tools of trade. A person who is carrying on business as a manufacturer is entitled to exemption from sales tax in respect of machinery, implements and apparatus used in the manufacture of goods. There is also provision which exempts hand tools of the kinds used for industrial purposes. It happens that hand tools covered by this item are exempt irrespective of whether they are used by persons carrying out their trade or are for use by non-tradesmen. However, in the Budget Speech the Treasurer announced that it is proposed that some goods which are at present exempt will be made taxable as from 1 January 1983 at a rate of 7.5 per cent. This broadening of the sales tax base is to include goods such as hand tools.
(2) Musical instruments purchased by professional musicians are not exempt from sales tax.
(3) It is not considered that an anomalous situation exists.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry , upon notice, on 20 May 1982.

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Who or what body is responsible for export inspection of primary produce.
(2) Is export inspection now carried out by officers of the Department of Primary Industry.
(3) How many prosecutions have been initiated by the Commonwealth following reports from export inspectors since 1901.
(4) How many prosecutions have been initiated by the Commonwealth following reports from export inspectors since August 1981.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Export Inspection Service of the Department of Primary Industry.

(2) Officers of the Department of Primary Industry carry out export inspection of meat, dairy products (including edible oils and eggs), honey, fish, canned and frozen fruit and vegetables, and dried fruit.

In the case of grains, fresh fruit and fresh vegetables inspection is carried out by officers of the State departments responsible for Agriculture under the direction of senior Department of Primary Industry officers.

(3) The Crown Solicitor's Office advise that its statistics in regard to prosecution matters do not itemise prosecutions into primary produce categories and for this reason it is unable to provide relevant information.

Records held within the Department of Primary Industry indicate that between 1921 and 1979 there were in excess of 13,600 minor offences against regulations. The then Part XV of the Customs Act 1901 provided for relatively minor contraventions to be dealt with administratively and these offences were handled in this manner. The administrative procedures resulted in the imposition of fines or the issue of warnings in all cases.

Departmental records further indicate that in the past 10 years there have been 12 occasions on which more substantial proceedings have been brought under the Crimes Act 1968, the Customs Act 1901 and the Exports (Meat) Regulations.

(4) On the basis of Australian Federal Police investigations since August 1981, 5 prosecutions have been initiated by the Commonwealth. Four of these have been concluded resulting in fines being imposed. Other prosecutions may result following investigations flowing from the Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Campbell Inquiry into the Australian Financial System

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 26 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Campbell inquiry into the Australian Financial System state at paragraph 35.40 that: '. . . the Committee notes that, within an overall policy framework of monetary restraint, higher rates of capital inflow (channelled into resource development) might entail a lower availability of finance for certain groups in the community, such as small businesses and home buyers. This in turn might create some social tensions'.
(2) Does the Government agree with this statement; if not, why not.
(3) Has the Government stated a view on this statement; if so, what is that view, and if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The final report of the Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System did include the words referred to by the honourable senator.

(2) and (3) It is not a case of the Government agreeing or disagreeing with the first part of the statement. It is merely axiomatic that, within the context of a given growth in the monetary aggregates, if more funds are attracted to a particular sector of the economy then other sectors in aggregate must get less.

As to the second part of the statement, it should be noted that it is qualified by use of the word 'might'. That qualification may have been designed to recognise that the Government, through various policies available to it, may secure certain objectives which purely market forces would not produce. Elsewhere in the report, the Committee of Inquiry gives more explicit recognition to this; for example it is stated in paragraph 1.43 that ''For equity or other social reasons, governments may choose to assist particular classes of savers or borrowers''; and paragraph 1.44 goes on to state that ' Social priorities are basically matters for governments to determine'.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of the ease with which school children in the United States have been able to crack the codes of some of the most sophisticated and confidential computers in that country.
(2) Is it possible for people in Australia to perform the same feats of these American school children and gain access to information stored in computers used by the Minister's Department.
(3) What security precautions have been taken to prevent such invasions of privacy.
(4) Does this ability to penetrate the secrecy of computers pose a grave security risk and leave hundreds of thousands of Australians open to blackmail and blatant invasion of privacy.
(5) Can the Minister give an assurance that confidential information related to his departmental files cannot be obtained by this method of 'plugging in' to computer systems.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Minister is not aware of the particular circumstances of the situation in the United States to which Senator Jones refers. However, the Minister is aware that, where telecommunication facilities are used to interrogate computer systems, cases have been reported of unauthorised access to data.

(2) It is acknowledged that persons with special expertise and the necessary time might be able to gain access to data stored by the bureau that presently provides the Department of Communications with 'on line' computing facilities. However, the access would be extremely limited as indicated in (3)-(5) below.

(3) Extensive security arrangements are employed by the commercial computer bureau which provides services to the Department, to ensure that unauthorised access of data stored on behalf of the Department is prevented and that access is restricted to Departmental staff using 'dial up' terminals located at Central Office and State Offices. These arrangements include the use of dynamic password protection to gain entry to the system, coded file names to inhibit access to data and removal of files from the system when not in use.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 19 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Australian Bureau of Statistics conducted surveys of the income levels, employment, health and living standards of Aborigines; if so, on what dates were the surveys released.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) has not conducted specific surveys of the Aboriginal population. However, Aborigines have been identified in a number of ABS collections which have obtained information in the areas of income, employment, health and living standards. Particulars of these collections, including information about availability of results, are given below.

Data on the employment status and characteristics of Aborigines have been collected in each census of population and housing since 1966. Data on income levels were collected in the 1976 and 1981 censuses. The results of these censuses up to 1981 have been released progressively in forms such as publications, microfiche and computer tapes. With the release of data for New South Wales on 15 September 1982, some data have now been released for all States and Territories from the 1981 census.

An ongoing collection of statistics about hospital inpatients is conducted in conjunction with State health authorities. Aborigines are identified in this collection in New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia, Western Australia and the Northern Territory. Annual results are published for New South Wales by the ABS and are available on request from State health authorities in other States. The most recent figures for New South Wales, which were released on 26 February 1982, relate to the year 1980.

Aborigines are also identified in a Cause of Death collection conducted in Western Australia and the Northern Territory. Data on Aborigines from this collection are not published by the ABS but are made available on request.

A question designed to identify Aborigines was included in the September 1979 population survey on a trial basis. However, analysis of the survey results indicated the quality of the data to be unsatisfactory and consequently it was decided that the statistics could not be released.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 25 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the anticipated annual revenue from the $2 charge for admission to the Australian National Gallery.
(2) How will this charge affect access for the general public to the Australian National Gallery bookshop, the restaurant and coffee shop, and the auditorium.

(3) How will this charge affect the rationale of the Australian National Gallery which has been set up not as a one-day entertainment centre, but as an educational institution intended to make available to the general public a whole educational introduction to artistic achievement, with daily lunchtime lectures and educational tours.
(4) Can the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment be more specific about the possibility of waiving this charge in certain 'instances'.
(5) What was the result in attendance when the Heath Government in the United Kingdom introduced admission charges to the major national art collections in London.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The anticipated annual revenue from charges for admission to the Australian National Gallery in 1982-83 is $600,000.

(2) The design of the Gallery building does not allow separate access to certain facilities such as the Gallery shop, restaurant and auditorium. Normal admission charges will apply to users of the Gallery's various facilities.

(3) It is anticipated that the bulk of visitors to the Gallery will be one-day visitors (Australian Capital Territory tourist figures indicate that 72 per cent of visitors to the Australian Capital Territory stay for a maximum of three nights and visit facilities once during that stay).

The ANG has developed an on-going programme of education courses and lecture series. Some of these will be available on a drop-in basis, others will require prior booking. Admission to the Gallery will be inclusive in the programme cost.

For Gallery patrons who undertake frequent visits, a number of initiatives apply. These include a unique membership programme offering yearly and season memberships. These will permit unlimited acess to the Gallery during hours when the Gallery is open to the public.
Sufficient flexibility exists to enable the Gallery to increase the number and frequency of its programmes to meet demonstrated need.
(4) As yet the Gallery Council has not formulated a clear policy as to when and on what occasions, admission charges will be waived.

(5) Admission charges to the Tate and National Gallery in the United Kingdom were introduced in January 1974 and withdrawn three months later. It is therefore not possible to draw conclusions on the effects on admissions. However , for several years prior to January 1974, attendance at the major United Kingdom arts institutions revealed a significant down trend. It is also important to note that under the United Kingdom proposal funds raised from admissions were not available for the purchase of works of art.

It needs to be borne in mind that the majority of United Kingdom institutions have well developed collections, whereas the ANG is a very young institution and needs to build as rapidly as possible a collection of richness and excellence in national and international terms. The fact that the net revenue from admission charges will be used exclusively for acquiring additional works of art will greatly facilitate this.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Australian Financial System: Interest Rates on Housing Loans

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 November, 1981 (Hansard, page 2262) Senator Bolkus asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice which contained a number of figures dealing with recent movements in housing loan repayments.

ANSWER.PARA: The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

From the information provided by the honourable senator it is assumed that he was referring to the interest rate on a savings bank loan for a home for owner- occupation. Since April 1980, savings bank housing loan interest rates have increased in five steps from 9.5 per cent per annum to 13.5 per cent in March 1982; they have remained at that level since then. These interest rate charges would have increased the repayment on a mortgage of $30,000 taken out over 30 years by about $90 per month. The increase in average weekly earnings during the same period was of the order of $350 per month.

Moreover, as the honourable senator will be aware, many recent borrowers will be shielded for a time from the increase in interest rates announced on 18 March 1982 by policy measures adopted at that time and all homebuyers will be assisted by the introduction in the Budget of tax rebates on all interest payments in excess of 10 per cent.

Senator Bolkus also asked whether nominal and real interest rates had reached an 'all-time-high'. The following table prepared by the Treasury shows annual movements in the nominal and 'real' savings bank housing loan interest rates since June 1960. While nominal rates are at an historical high, it can readily be seen that recent 'real' rates were well below the levels recorded in the early 1960s and early 1970s; even higher 'real' interest rates were recorded at times during the 1930s and 1950s.
'Real'
Savings bank savings bank
Inflation housing loan housing loan
rate* interest rate* interest rate
* Change in consumer price index, June quarter over June quarter of previous year.
* Maximum nominal rate at 30 June.

Senator Bolkus also quoted figures which suggested that house prices in Sydney had risen more rapidly than average weekly earnings in the period since December 1975. It should be noted, however, that Sydney house prices are generally higher and have generally increased at a faster rate than in other areas of Australia. Nevertheless, estimates of the Sydney house price figures indicate that increasing housing prices have been a significant factor in increasing the loan repayment burdens confronting new home buyers in Sydney; the same has been true, generally to a lesser degree, in most other areas. Indeed, in areas such as Sydney where house prices have increased relatively sharply in recent years, increasing house prices have been more significant in adding to housing loan repayment burdens for new home buyers than have rising interest rates.

The figures quoted by Senator Bolkus clearly indicate that the most effective assistance any Government could provide to home buyers is to bring about sustainable reductions in interest rates and in the rate of increase in house and land prices, both of which will only occur with a sustained fall in the rate of inflation. Needless to say, this is a central objective of the Government's economic policies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 April 1982 (Hansard, page 1353) Senator Lajovic referred me to a newspaper article on Eastern Bloc countries' loan defaults and asked me a question without notice concerning details of credits granted by Australia to Eastern Bloc countries.

ANSWER.PARA: The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:
I have seen the article referred to by the honourable senator.

Australian exchange control policy generally does not permit direct loans to non-residents by Australian residents. Proceeds of most exports are required to be received in Australia no later than six months after exportation, but the Government has no detailed knowledge of trade credit provided by Australian residents, other than that insured by Export Finance Insurance Corporation as referred to below. It is understood that the overseas-based offices of Australian banks are involved in some limited degree of lending to Eastern bloc countries. Details of such lending, however, are commercial matters that are generally confidential to the banks concerned.

With regard to the operations of EFIC I am advised that as at 30 June 1982 it had outstanding one loan to an Eastern Bloc country under its Export Finance Facility. This facility is given in support of export of Australian capital goods and related services and provides credit of up to a maximum of 10 years. The one loan was to Romania for $1,037,000 of which $933,300 remains to be repaid.

In addition EFIC has insured normal trade credit on terms up to 180 days from date of shipment. As at 30 June 1982 the estimated outstandings of such credit supported by EFIC totalled approximately $197m made up as follows:
$'000 USSR 155,271 Romania 1,295 Czechoslovakia 3,489 Bulgaria nil Hungary 287 East Germany nil Poland 36,563

The only direct involvement of the Australian Government in the above relates to EFIC insurance of exports to Poland of wool, hides and skins (shown above) which the Government has agreed to underwrite under the national interest provisions of the EFIC Act.

With regard to guarantees of repayment, EFIC has advised that the repayment obligations are assumed by State trading organisations or State banks in these countries and consequently no specific guarantees are obtained.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 August 1982 (Hansard, page 22) Senator Sibraa asked me, as the Minister representing the Treasurer, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I ask the Minister whether she is aware of a Sydney tax consultancy service which offers its very large ethnic clientele tax refunds before their income tax returns are even lodged with the Australian Taxation Office in exchange for the clients signing over their income tax refund entitlements to the agency. As a result, the agency is pocketing large sums of money since the true Taxation Office refunds are usually a great deal more than the original sum paid to the unsuspecting clients by the agency. Further, I ask the Minister: What are the powers of the Tax Agents Registration Board in dealing with such an agency? I ask this because I have good reason to believe that the Board has known about this agency's operation for some time but has not done anything about it. Will the Minister agree that the practices mentioned in my question are completely unethical? If so, will the Government take steps to immediately outlaw these exploitive practices?
I would like to add the following to my answer to the honourable senator's question on 7 August last:

The registration of tax agents is a matter for the Tax Agents Boards, which are independent bodies located in each State capital. One of the grounds on which an agent's registration may be cancelled is that the agent is guilty of misconduct.

The practice of discounting income tax refund cheques is known to both the Commissioner of Taxation and the Tax Agents Board in Sydney. It is understood that the practice is confined to a very small number of tax agents whose clients are drawn largely from the ethnic community.

Although the discounting of refund cheques is considered undesirable, legal advice received by the Australian Taxation Office is to the effect that it is purely a private matter between the agent and the client. However, where a Tax Agents Board receives information that a person is carrying on discounting (or any other aspect of a tax agent's business) in such a manner as to render that person no longer a fit and proper one to be registered as a tax agent, the appropriate action would be taken. Naturally any such action could only be taken on the basis of reliable evidence received by the Board.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Australian Bureau of Statistics: Surveys of Foreign Ownership in Australia

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 19 August 1982 (Hansard, page 287) Senator Siddons asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I refer to a Press release by the Treasurer, Mr Howard, on 20 January 1982, in which he stated:

I am requesting the Australian Bureau of Statistics to reintroduce the surveys measuring the extent of foreign ownership and control in sectors of the Australian economy that were discontinued in 1978.

Is it correct that now, eight months after that statement was made, these surveys have not been reintroduced. Is it correct that the Australian Bureau of Statistics has in fact not even received any instructions to reintroduce them? I ask the Minister whether the Treasurer intends to keep to his public undertaking? If so, when does he propose to take appropriate action?
The answer to the honourable senator's question is contained in Press release No. 182, dated 7 September 1982, issued by myself as Acting Treasurer. That statement reads as follows:
Resumption of Foreign Ownership and Control Statistics

In January 1982 the Treasurer announced that he had requested the Australian Bureau of Statistics to reintroduce the studies, discontinued in 1978, of the extent of foreign ownership and control in sectors of the Australian economy.

The Statistician has now advised me that he has examined a number of matters related to the resumption of such studies, including a review of experience with the earlier studies, the views of potential major users of the figures, the range and frequency of possible studies and the most appropriate concepts, definitions and measures to be used. He has also given attention to how to accommodate work on these statistics within the resources available to the ABS and without disrupting other high priority statistics.

As a result of this examination, the ABS is to recommence a program of foreign participation studies. In order to retain simple and objective criteria for classifying companies, the concepts, definitions and measures used for the new series will be similar to those used in previously published statistics of foreign ownership and control. The main change will be that, as far as possible, separate aggregates will be published for the following categories which would otherwise come within the statistical definition of foreign controlled:
naturalised and naturalising companies;
joint Australian/foreign controlled enterprises.

Steps are being taken to staff positions in the Bureau in order to carry out these studies. The first publication, which is planned for release in the second half of 1983, will relate to foreign ownership and control of the mining industry and selected mineral processing industries for the year ended 30 June 1982. Work will also be started on the preparation of foreign participation statistics for other sectors including manufacturing and possibly agricultural industries.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 14 September 1982 (Hansard, page 860) Senator Watson asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Can the Minister representing the Minister for Communications explain why advertisements deemed by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to be unsuitable for television viewing can be shown as news items and what further powers the Tribunal has in such situations? Finally, is the Minister aware that it is planned to release the advertisement in question, involving Ronald Biggs, on the cinema circuit?
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice from the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal:

The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal considers the advertisement for 'Cafe de Rio' featuring Ronald Biggs to be unacceptable in terms of its Television Program Standards. The Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations agrees with the Tribunal's interpretation and has rejected the advertisement for use on television. As this action created considerable interest it was to be expected that the use of the advertisement in the context of a news item was acceptable on a once only basis. The public, otherwise, would not have been in a position to appreciate the motivation of the Federation and the Tribunal in deciding on the prohibition of the advertisement on television.
The matter of the release of the advertisement on the cinema circuit does not come within the area of Commonwealth Government responsibility.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 15 September 1982 (Hansard, page 921) Senator Tate asked me, as the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I ask the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General whether the Treasurer, Mr Howard, announced yesterday that in the past few weeks the Government had received $171,000 from the shareholders of one company that would come within the ambit of fore-shadowed legislation to recover tax avoided through use of bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. Are the secrecy provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act now to be read as permitting the Treasurer to be acquainted with the details of the discharging of tax liability in one particular case? Has the Attorney-General or the Crown Solicitors given any legal opinion to the Australian Taxation Office or the Treasurer as to the legality of this relevation to the Treasurer of the discharge of a particular tax liability rather than, as hitherto, the aggregating of a number of unnamed cases to reveal some trend or the gravity of a particular problem?
The Acting Attorney-General has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question without notice:

I confirm that the Treasurer made a statement along the lines indicated. The answer to the other parts of the question is no. It is not correct to infer from the Treasurer's announcement that the information was given to him in a form that would enable the Treasurer to identify the shareholders who had paid the amount referred to in the announcement or that the information given to the Treasurer was in breach of section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 16 September 1982 (Hansard, page 1002) Senator Colston asked me, as the Minister representing the Treasurer, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: In the event of the Student Assistance (Loans Guarantee and Subsidy) Bill being passed by this Parliament, will a student who repays a student loan after graduation be able to claim either loan repayments or interest payments as income tax deductions?
The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

The Commissioner of Taxation has stated that, in the absence of the relevant legislation, it is not possible to express a firm opinion on this question. By way of general comment he stated that, where a student repays a loan after graduation, the question whether he or she will be entitled to an income tax deduction for repayments of principal and interest will be governed by the general deduction provisions of the income tax law. So far as is relevant they provide a deduction for losses and outgoings incurred in gaining or producing assessable income other than losses or outgoings of a capital, private or domestic nature.

The repayments of the loan would be of a capital nature and, consequently, precluded from deduction. Interest on borrowed moneys qualifies for deduction when the moneys borrowed are used for the purpose of gaining or producing assessable income. Under the proposals relating to the Tertiary Student Loans Scheme, the loans are intended for the maintenance of the student and his or her dependants. In these circumstances the interest paid would not qualify for income tax deduction.
Government Information Unit: Access to Parliamentary Library Facilities

The President-On 27 May 1982 (Hansard, page 2498) Senator Evans asked a question without notice concerning access by the Government Information Unit to services of the Parliamentary Library. The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

The staff of the Government Information Unit have been users of the Library services for some years. The question of their status was first investigated early in 1979 when it was determined that where they are working for a member of the Parliament the rules of access provide that service is to be given.
That status was confirmed by the meeting of the Principal Officers of the Library to which Senator Evans referred.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 17 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of the ease with which school children in the United States have been able to crack the codes of some of the most sophisticated and confidential computers in that country.
(2) Is it possible for people in Australia to perform the same feats of these American schoolchildren and gain access to information stored in computers used by the Minister's department.
(3) What security precautions have been taken to prevent such invasions of privacy.
(4) Does this ability to penetrate the secrecy of computers pose a grave security risk and leave hundreds of thousands of Australians open to blackmail and blatant invasion of privacy.
(5) Can the Minister give an assurance that confidential information related to his departmental files cannot be obtained by this method of 'plugging in' to computer systems.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) Security features in use ensure that it is highly unlikely that unauthorised access could be gained to information stored in computers used by my department.
(3) The Department employs various security measures to guard against unauthorised access, including:
(i) limiting access through unique security codes and passwords
(ii) frequent and irregular changes of passwords
(iii) password protection of stored data in certain cases
(iv) physical security of equipment and terminals
(4) See answer to (2) above.

(5) It is not possible to give an unequivocal assurance that information cannot be accessed from departmental computer files by unauthorised means, but the Department has taken all practicable precautions to prevent such unauthorised access occurring.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 22 September 1982:

TALK.START.PARA: —On 14 September 1982 (Hansard, page 863), Senator Harradine asked me a question without notice in relation to my statement on 17 August 1982 which described certain groups who would now be eligible for free treatment. Senator Harradine asked:

ANSWER.PARA: Could that very small group of Australian citizens who served, for example, in the British forces side by side with Australian troops and who were prisoners of war in Japan also be included in this extension?
I undertook to obtain further advice and my answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

It is the policy of this Government that each country should bear responsibility for the welfare of former members of its forces. I understand other governments also share this view. However, provision exists for certain Australian citizens who served in the forces of other British Commonwealth countries to be regarded as former members of the Australian forces.
The above provision extends to a person who:

having been appointed or enlisted before 1 July 1947, served before 1 July 1951, in the naval, military or air forces of a part of the Queen's dominions, other than the Commonwealth, on active service outside that part of the Queen's dominions or in a theatre of war;
satisfies the Commission that he was, immediately before his appointment or enlistment, domiciled in Australia or an external Territory; and
is resident in Australia or an external Territory.

If the ex-servicemen mentioned by Senator Harradine wish to test their eligibility for free treatment under these arrangements, they should apply for individual consideration to a branch office of my Department in the State in which they reside.
